children.name: Metabolism
children.description: The properties contained within this category describe the various metabolic pathways by which organisms transform chemicals in the processes of life.

children.name: Biosynthesis
children.description: The process of creating complex biomolecules from simpler starting materials.

children.name: Natural products biosynthesis
children.description: The biosynthesis of complex biomolecules generally as polyketides, non-ribosomal peptides or polyisoprenoids (terpenoids). Often these molecules are extensively modified by methylation, oxidation/reduction, cyclization, epimerization and rearrangement reactions. Common functions for such compounds are as siderophores and toxins (antibiotics). Most often these compounds are exported from the cell.

children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 1337066, Title: Studies on the biosynthesis of bialaphos (SF-1293). 14. children.description: Phosphonacetaldehyde is a precursor of natural products, lipids and polysaccharides containing phosphonates (C-P linkages). Often this is converted by an aminotransferase to the most common naturally occuring phosphonate, 2-aminoethylphosphonate.

children.name: Quorum-sensing, autoinducer-2 system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16101288, Title: Mutational analysis of a nucleosidase involved in quorum-sensing autoinducer-2 biosynthesis., Authors: Lee JE, Luong W, Huang DJ, Cornell KA, Riscoe MK, Howell PL;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2005;44:11049-11057., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 15456522, Title: Is autoinducer-2 a universal signal for interspecies communication: a comparative genomic and phylogenetic analysis of the synthesis and signal transduction pathways., Authors: Sun J, Daniel R, Wagner-Döbler I, Zeng AP;, Citation: BMC Evol Biol. 2004;4:36.]
children.description: S-ribosylhomocysteine lyase (LuxS) is an iron(2+)-containing protein. Its immediate product, 4,5-dihydroxypentan-2,3-dione, cyclizes spontaneously and binds borate to become autoinducer-2 (AI-2), a quorum-sensing molecule produced and recognized by a wide range of bacteria. LuxS serves as a marker for this system, while MTA/SAH nucleosidase is essential both for this and other systems.

This Genome Property represents a recognizable subclass of bacteriocin-biosynthesis and export system with a characteristic immunity protein modeled by TIGR01654.

children.name: Lantibiotic system, gallidermin/epidermin family
children.description: A specialized ABC transporter occurs both in species that make lantibiotics in the gallidermin family and as orphans in species that lack both the lantibiotic precursor molecule and the corresponding synthases. It appears these transporters are responsible for self-protection in species that make lantibiotics, and defense in those that do not.

children.name: Bacteriocin system, NHLP (nif11/nitrile hydratase leader peptide) transport group
children.description: Model TIGR03793 describes a leader peptide region (homologous to the nitrile hydratase alpha subunit) for peptides subject to modification by bacteriocin-like maturation enzyme clusters, typically including either a cyclodehydratase and a dehydrogenase (producing TOMMS - Thiazole/Oxazole-Modified Microcins) or a lantibiotic synthase. Radical SAM enzymes are commonly found as well. While sequences of the mature peptides are highly variable, as are their modification clusters, the leader peptide region shows a close phylogenetic correlation to a three gene transporter operon, one subunit of which includes a protease domain for cleavage at the Gly-Gly motif at the end of the leader peptide region. This property describes the transport operon as well as the leader peptide family.

children.name: Post-ribosomal natural product synthesis system, Burkholderia TOMM-type
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 20500830, Title: Expansion of ribosomally produced natural products: a nitrile hydratase- and Nif11-related precursor family., Authors: Haft DH, Basu MK, Mitchell DA;, Citation: BMC Biol. 2010;8:70.]
children.description: This system describes a novel system of a bacteriocin-like metabolite found in multiple species of Burkholderia (in Acidovorax avenae subsp. citrulli AAC00-1 and Delftia acidovorans SPH-1, and in multiple copies in Sorangium cellulosum). It features a probable two-chain bacteriocin precursor, a fused cyclodehydratase/docking scaffold fusion protein, and a kinase and cyclase homology domain-containing multidomain protein.

children.name: SCIFF/radical SAM Clostridial gene pair
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 21478363, Title: Biological systems discovery in silico: radical S-adenosylmethionine protein families and their target peptides for posttranslational modification., Authors: Haft DH, Basu MK;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2011;193:2745-2755.]
children.description: This property describes a radical SAM protein and its 45-amino acid partner with six conserved cysteine residues. The system appears to be universal in the Clostridia, and rare outside the Clostridia. This pattern suggests a house-keeping role rather than a role such as bacteriocin production. Meanwhile, among all characterized radical SAM proteins, those closest by homology to the member of this system are modification enzymes for short peptides.

children.name: Radical SAM pair and His-Xaa-Ser repeats peptide
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 21478363, Title: Biological systems discovery in silico: radical S-adenosylmethionine protein families and their target peptides for posttranslational modification., Authors: Haft DH, Basu MK;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2011;193:2745-2755.]
children.description: This Genome Property represents a pair of radical SAM proteins that occur as tandem genes in bacteria. The most likely function for this system is post-translational modification of ribosomally produced peptides. TIGR03979 describes a family with low levels of sequence similarity overall, a C-terminal putative peptidoglycan-binding domain, but also a striking region with five to seven repeats of His-Xaa-Ser. This family only occurs next to the radical SAM pair. Surprisingly, a search based on the His-Xaa-Ser repeat region and just a few flanking amino acids finds that essentially every radical SAM pair has a His-Xaa-Ser repeats region peptide nearby. TIGR03976 describes an additional protein in this system, including one branch of the family with the signature motif LLNDYxLRE.

children.name: Bacteriocin system, sporulation delay protein group
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 19775247, Title: Cannibalism enhances biofilm development in Bacillus subtilis., Authors: López D, Vlamakis H, Losick R, Kolter R;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2009;74:609-618.]
children.description: This Genome Property describes a three-gene system of antimicrobial peptide and two export proteins modeled on SdpC (sporulation delay protein C) from Bacillus subtilis, a killing peptide that allows cannibalism to obtain nutrients and avoid the irreversible sporulation cascade. Related systems are sparsely but widely distributed. Additional components of the SdpABC system itself, such as immunity protein SdpI and regulatory proteins, were not recognized as universal to such systems by phylogenetic profiling mechanisms and are not modeled within this Genome Property.

children.name: Radical SAM-cylized peptide, Pep1357C family
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 17921293, Title: Control of the transcription of a short gene encoding a cyclic peptide in Streptococcus thermophilus: a new quorum-sensing system?, Authors: Ibrahim M, Guillot A, Wessner F, Algaron F, Besset C, Courtin P, Gardan R, Monnet V;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2007;189:8844-8854.]
children.description: Pep1357C from Streptococcus thermophilus is a secreted modified peptide whose 9-amino acid mature form AKGDGWKVM is cyclized between residues 2 (Lys) and 6 (Trp), probably via a dehydrogenation catalyzed by the adjacent radical SAM enzyme. Similar peptides with the same core sequence KGDGW and pairing with a radical SAM enzyme occur elsewhere, such as Lactococcus lactis subsp. cremoris MG1363. The Pep1357C system probably provides signaling rather than bacteriocin activity.

children.name: Methanobactin biosynthesis, Mb-OB3b family
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 20961038, Title: A comparison of methanobactins from Methylosinus trichosporium OB3b and Methylocystis strain Sb2 predicts methanobactins are synthesized from diverse peptide precursors modified to create a common core for binding and reducing copper ions., Authors: Krentz BD, Mulheron HJ, Semrau JD, Dispirito AA, Bandow NL, Haft DH, Vuilleumier S, Murrell JC, McEllistrem MT, Hartsel SC, Gallagher WH;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2010;49:10117-10130.]
children.description: Methanobactins are siderophore-like copper chelators. The charter member for this Genome Property is Methylosinus trichosporium OB3b, in which the methanobactin is made from a 30-residue ribosomally translated precursor. The only other system known so far is in Azospirillum sp. B510.

children.name: Radical SAM maturase system, FibroRumin system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 21478363, Title: Biological systems discovery in silico: radical S-adenosylmethionine protein families and their target peptides for posttranslational modification., Authors: Haft DH, Basu MK;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2011;193:2745-2755.]
children.description: This rare system consists of a peptide-modifying radical SAM enzyme and its cysteine-rich targets. In this system, the targets are encoded by tandem gene pairs. The maturase is similar in sequence, and the targets in their cysteine richness, to the analogous components of the SCIFF (Six Cysteines in Forty-Five) system. This system is known so far in Fibrobacter succinogenes subsp. succinogenes S85 (targets missed in gene-calling) and in Ruminococcus albus 8.

children.name: Radical SAM maturase system, GG-Bacteroidales group
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 21478363, Title: Biological systems discovery in silico: radical S-adenosylmethionine protein families and their target peptides for posttranslational modification., Authors: Haft DH, Basu MK;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2011;193:2745-2755.]
children.description: This Genome Property is one of many in which a ribosomally translated peptide is modified post-translationally. Many of the natural products generated are bacteriocins, although bacteriocin activity cannot be presumed. An odd feature of this system is the pairing of a radical SAM enzyme (TIGR04148) with a degenerate radical SAM (pseudo-SAM) protein (TIGR04150). Despite full-length homology in family TIGR04150, some members have but others lack the radical SAM signature 4Fe4S-binding site. However, all members are best conserved at the C terminus, where the signature motif for the SPASM (Subtilosin, PQQ, Anaearobic Sulfatase and Mycofactocin maturases) domain homology 4Fe4S binding site is invariant. This system occurs, so far, only in the Bacteroidales.

children.name: 3-methylarginine biosynthesis
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 20190091, Title: Identification of the biosynthetic gene cluster for 3-methylarginine, a toxin produced by Pseudomonas syringae pv. syringae 22d/93., Authors: Braun SD, Hofmann J, Wensing A, Ullrich MS, Weingart H, Völksch B, Spiteller D;, Citation: Appl Environ Microbiol. 2010;76:2500-2508., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 24907335, Title: Biosynthesis of the β-methylarginine residue of peptidyl nucleoside arginomycin in Streptomyces arginensis NRRL 15941., Authors: Feng J, Wu J, Gao J, Xia Z, Deng Z, He X;, Citation: Appl Environ Microbiol. 2014;80:5021-5027.]
children.description: 3-methylarginine can be a natural product in its own right, or a precursor of another natural product, such as arginomycin. The aminotransferase catalyzes the first and third steps of the pathway, removing the alpha-amino group from arginine, later replacing it on the beta-methylated form. The second step is catalyzed by a C-methyltransferase that acts on 2-ketoarginine at the 3-position.

children.name: D-alanyl-lipoteichoic acid biosynthesis
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 19324056, Title: Crystal structure of Bacillus cereus D-alanyl carrier protein ligase (DltA) in complex with ATP., Authors: Osman KT, Du L, He Y, Luo Y;, Citation: J Mol Biol. 2009;388:345-355., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 16885447, Title: A functional dlt operon, encoding proteins required for incorporation of d-alanine in teichoic acids in gram-positive bacteria, confers resistance to cationic antimicrobial peptides in Streptococcus pneumoniae., Authors: Kovács M, Halfmann A, Fedtke I, Heintz M, Peschel A, Vollmer W, Hakenbeck R, Brückner R;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2006;188:5797-5805.]
children.description: The DltABCD operon, responsible for D-alanylation of LipoTeichoic acids (hence DLT) is near-universal in low-GC Gram-positive bacteria, although absent in Clostridium perfringens, Oceanobacillus iheyensis, etc. This Genome Property describes the DltABCD system, rather than LTA biosynthesis itself. Note that lipoteichoic acids (LTA, anionic polymers) are variable among species or strains, with backbones that often consist of polyglycerolphosphate (e.g. Staphylococcus aureus) but with additional modifications. LTA are covalently linked to membrane components, and differ from wall teichoic acids (WTA), such as the polyribitol phosphate WTAs in S. aureus and B. subtilis W23.

children.name: Biosynthesis of UDP-N-acetyl-D-mannosaminuronic acid (UDP-ManNAcA)
children.description: UDP-ManNAcA is a precursor in the biosynthesis of the entobacterial common antigen.

children.name: Biosynthesis of UDP-N-acetyl-D-mannosamine (UDP-ManNAc)
children.description: UDP-ManNAc is a donor of N-acetylmannose for polysaccharide biosynthesis, and a precursor of other sugars such as N-acetylmannosaminic acid, N-acetylfucosamine. The final enzyme, UDP-N-acetylglucosamine 2-epimerase carries a variety of gene symbols (WecB, gne, RffE, FnlC) depending on its context.

children.name: UDP-N-acetylglucosamine biosynthesis from fructose-6-phosphate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 8407787, Title: Identification of the glmU gene encoding N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphate uridyltransferase in Escherichia coli., Authors: Mengin-Lecreulx D, van Heijenoort J;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1993;175:6150-6157.]
children.description: This pathway converts fructose-6-phosphate in four steps to activated N-acetylglucosamine. GlmS produces glucosamine-6-phosphate. GlmM isomerizes this product to glucosamine-1-phosphate. GlmU, which is bifunctional, adds an acetyl group from acetyl-CoA, then acts as N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase [1]. The product, UDP-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine, is then used both for murein biosynthesis and (in species with LPS) for lipopolysaccharide biosynthesis.

children.name: Biosynthesis of Und-PP-GlcNAc
children.description: N-acetylglucosamine-1-pyrophospho-undecaprenol (Und-PP-GlcNAc) is synthesized by the WecA enzyme in E. coli from UDP-GlcNAc and undecaprenyl phosphate.

children.name: UDP-N-acetylglucosamine biosynthesis from fructose-6-phosphate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 8407787, Title: Identification of the glmU gene encoding N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphate uridyltransferase in Escherichia coli., Authors: Mengin-Lecreulx D, van Heijenoort J;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1993;175:6150-6157.]
children.description: This pathway converts fructose-6-phosphate in four steps to activated N-acetylglucosamine. GlmS produces glucosamine-6-phosphate. GlmM isomerizes this product to glucosamine-1-phosphate. GlmU, which is bifunctional, adds an acetyl group from acetyl-CoA, then acts as N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase [1]. The product, UDP-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine, is then used both for murein biosynthesis and (in species with LPS) for lipopolysaccharide biosynthesis.

children.name: Biosynthesis of undecaprenyl phosphate (Und-P)
children.description: Undecaprenyl phosphate (Und-P) is synthesized de novo from farnesyl diphosphate via eight successive additions of isopentenyl diphosphate followed by a final removal of one phosphate. Und-P is used as a carrier for polysaccharide units via a pyrophosphate linkage. Removal of the polysaccharide results in Und-PP, so the phosphatase is also used in the recycling back to Und-P.

children.name: IPP biosynthesis
children.description: Isopentenyl pyrophosphate (IPP) is the common intermediate of isoprenoid metabolism which includes the biosynthesis of terpenoid natural products, sterols, bile acids, carotenoids, vitamins K and E, isoprene and other prenylated compounds. IPP may be synthesized via one of two separate pathways, the mevalonate pathway is typical of eukaryotes while the deoxyxylulose pathway is typical of prokaryotes. This property summarizes the states of the two child properties, IPP biosynthesis via mevalonate and IPP biosynthesis from deoxyxylulose.

children.name: IPP biosynthesis via mevalonate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10894743, Title: Identification, evolution, and essentiality of the mevalonate pathway for isopentenyl diphosphate biosynthesis in gram-positive cocci., Authors: Wilding EI, Brown JR, Bryant AP, Chalker AF, Holmes DJ, Ingraham KA, Iordanescu S, So CY, Rosenberg M, Gwynn MN;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2000;182(15):4319-4327., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 11042147, Title: Biosynthesis of isoprenoids via mevalonate in Archaea: the lost pathway., Authors: Smit A, Mushegian A;, Citation: Genome Res. 2000;10(10):1468-1484.]
children.description: Isoprenyl pyrophosphate (IPP) is synthesized in eukaryotes, archaea and certain bacteria by the mevalonate pathway (which is in contrast to the non-mevalonate pathway found more generally in prokaryotes).The bacteria containing this pathway are believed to have acquired it by lateral transfer, possibly in more than one independent event [1]. Archaea are believed to possess a mevalonate pathway for production of IPP, but several of the steps are divergent from the known enzymes in eukaryotes and have not yet been conclusively identified [2]. In eukaryotes this pathway is highly regulated to control the production of steroids which require IPP as a precursor. IPP is also required for the synthesis of menaquinone, ubiquinone, terpenoids, isoprene and prenylated proteins. The pathway begins with synthesis of (S)-3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA) from acetyl-CoA and acetoacetyl-CoA by HMG-CoA synthase. The pathway contains 5 steps all of which are included as required elements in this property. Some organisms contain a pathway-specific acetoacetyl-CoA synthase which is described in this property, but is not a required step. It is likely that other species obtain acetoacetyl-CoA from beta-oxidation of fatty acids or related processes.

children.name: IPP biosynthesis via deoxyxylulose
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 22216001, Title: Five questions about non-mevalonate isoprenoid biosynthesis., Authors: Odom AR;, Citation: PLoS Pathogens. 2011; 7(12):e1002323.]
children.description: Isoprenyl pyrophosphate (IPP) is synthesised in most bacteria by the non-mevalonate pathway (also known as the MEP pathway, the glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate(GAP)-pyruvate pathway and the deoxyxylulose pathway). This is in contrast to the mevalonate pathway found in eukaryotes. This non-mevalonate pathway contains six characterized enzymes and may involve additional proteins as well. IPP is a basic building block of isoprenoids, also known as terpenoids [1].

A small protein encoded nearby in a couple of cases, is Cys-rich because of two CXXCG motifs, but that arrangement suggests ligand activity rather than post-translational modification.

children.name: Nodulation factor production
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 8986807, Title: The common nodABC genes of Rhizobium meliloti are host-range determinants., Authors: Roche P, Maillet F, Plazanet C, Debellé F, Ferro M, Truchet G, Promé JC, Dénarié J;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 1996;93:15305-15310., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 8930915, Title: The NodA proteins of Rhizobium meliloti and Rhizobium tropici specify the N-acylation of Nod factors by different fatty acids., Authors: Debellé F, Plazanet C, Roche P, Pujol C, Savagnac A, Rosenberg C, Promé JC, Dénarié J;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 1996;22:303-314.]
children.description: The gene trio nodABC, found in non-photosynthetic rhizobia such as Rhizobium meliloti that form root (not stem) nodules, produce the enzymes that create Nod factors. These mono-N-acylated chitooligosaccharide signals not only trigger the establishment of nitrogen-fixing root nodules, but also vary in ways that determine host range.

children.name: 2,3-dihydroxybenzoate biosynthesis
children.description: 2,3-dihydroxybenzoate is made in three steps from chorismate by the action of enzymes isochorismate synthase (EC 5.4.4.2), isochorismatase (EC 3.3.2.1), and 2,3-dihydro-2,3-dihydroxybenzoate dehydrogenase (EC 1.3.1.28). It can then be activated by (2,3-dihydroxybenzoyl)adenylate synthase (EC 2.7.7.58) to become a substrate for nonribosomal peptide synthases (NRPS) such as those that make catecholate siderophores.

children.description: Aah and TibC are protein O-heptosyltransferases that glycosylate certain repeat-rich proteins at multiple sites. Their targets are the autotransporter (T5SS) proteins AIDA (autotransporter adhesin involved in diffuse adherence) and TibA, respectively. Similar tandem gene pairs occur in Burkholderia vietnamiensis G4, Granulibacter bethesdensis CGDNIH1, Cronobacter sakazakii ATCC BAA-894, and Bradyrhizobium sp. ORS278. In Burkholderia mallei, the heptosyltransferase occurs next to BimA, an autotransporter virulence factor involved in actin-based motility, suggesting glycosylation, although BimA lacks the repeat structure recognized by model TIGR04415.

children.name: 2,3-diaminopropionic acid biosynthesis

A fourth pyrophosphate-dependent kinase from Entamoeba histolytica., Authors: Reeves RE, Guthrie JD;, Citation: Biochem Biophys Res Commun. 1975;66:1389-1395., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 16080684, Title: Characterization of the acetate-producing pathways in Escherichia coli., Authors: Dittrich CR, Bennett GN, San KY;, Citation: Biotechnol Prog. 2005;21:1062-1067.]
children.description: Acetate may be generated from acetyl phosphate by hydrolysis (EC 3.6.1.7, acylphosphatase) or by a reversible ATP-dependent reaction (EC 2.7.2.1, ATP:acetate phosphohydrolase). The literature also refers to a reversible pyrophophate-dependent reaction in Entamoeba histolytica [1] although the sequence of the enzyme responsible is not yet known.

children.name: Lycopene biosynthesis from IPP
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16669779, Title: Vitamin synthesis in plants: tocopherols and carotenoids., Authors: DellaPenna D, Pogson BJ;, Citation: Annu Rev Plant Biol. 2006;57:711-738.]
children.description: Lycopene is one of the most commonly occurring carotenes (nonoxygenated carotenoids). Carotenoids are synthesized via the isoprenoid biosynthetic pathway, of which isopetenylpyrophosphate (IPP) is an intermediate. IPP undergoes a series of condensation reactions to form geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GGDP), a key intermediate in the synthesis of carotenoids. In plants, the first committed step in carotenoid synthesis is the condensation of two GGDP molecules, producing phytoene. Multiple desaturation steps then occur to yield lycopene. These desaturation steps vary slightly between plant and bacterial pathways [1].

children.name: IPP biosynthesis via deoxyxylulose
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 22216001, Title: Five questions about non-mevalonate isoprenoid biosynthesis., Authors: Odom AR;, Citation: PLoS Pathogens. 2011; 7(12):e1002323.]
children.description: Isoprenyl pyrophosphate (IPP) is synthesised in most bacteria by the non-mevalonate pathway (also known as the MEP pathway, the glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate(GAP)-pyruvate pathway and the deoxyxylulose pathway). This is in contrast to the mevalonate pathway found in eukaryotes. This non-mevalonate pathway contains six characterized enzymes and may involve additional proteins as well. IPP is a basic building block of isoprenoids, also known as terpenoids [1].

children.name: IPP biosynthesis via mevalonate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10894743, Title: Identification, evolution, and essentiality of the mevalonate pathway for isopentenyl diphosphate biosynthesis in gram-positive cocci., Authors: Wilding EI, Brown JR, Bryant AP, Chalker AF, Holmes DJ, Ingraham KA, Iordanescu S, So CY, Rosenberg M, Gwynn MN;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2000;182(15):4319-4327., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 11042147, Title: Biosynthesis of isoprenoids via mevalonate in Archaea: the lost pathway., Authors: Smit A, Mushegian A;, Citation: Genome Res. 2000;10(10):1468-1484.]
children.description: Isoprenyl pyrophosphate (IPP) is synthesized in eukaryotes, archaea and certain bacteria by the mevalonate pathway (which is in contrast to the non-mevalonate pathway found more generally in prokaryotes).The bacteria containing this pathway are believed to have acquired it by lateral transfer, possibly in more than one independent event [1]. Archaea are believed to possess a mevalonate pathway for production of IPP, but several of the steps are divergent from the known enzymes in eukaryotes and have not yet been conclusively identified [2]. In eukaryotes this pathway is highly regulated to control the production of steroids which require IPP as a precursor. IPP is also required for the synthesis of menaquinone, ubiquinone, terpenoids, isoprene and prenylated proteins. The pathway begins with synthesis of (S)-3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA) from acetyl-CoA and acetoacetyl-CoA by HMG-CoA synthase. The pathway contains 5 steps all of which are included as required elements in this property. Some organisms contain a pathway-specific acetoacetyl-CoA synthase which is described in this property, but is not a required step. It is likely that other species obtain acetoacetyl-CoA from beta-oxidation of fatty acids or related processes.

children.name: ThiF-ThiS complex
children.description: Catalyses the initial steps of thiamine (vitamin B1) pyrophosphate synthesis by donating the sulfur for the synthesis of the intermediate thiazole phosphate moiety. This step is ATP-dependent as ThiS is temporarity adenylated by ThiF. A further persulfate group is donated to the intermediate products by ThiI (P77718).

children.name: Chorismate biosynthesis via shikimate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12636087, Title: The biosynthesis of shikimate metabolites., Authors: Knaggs AR;, Citation: Nat Prod Rep. 2003;20:119-136.]
children.description: Chorismate is the final common intermediate in the biosynthesis of phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan (the aromatic amino acids) as well as menaquinone, ubiquinone, salicylate and phenazine.Chorismate is synthesized via a seven-step pathway starting from the precursors D-erythrose 4-phosphate and phosphoenolpyruvate.This pathway is widely distributed among microorganisms[1]. Certain methanogenic euarchaeota appear to be missing the first two steps of the pathway - these may be catalyzed by as of yet uncharacterized enzymes.

children.name: Tryptophan biosynthesis from ribose-5-phosphate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12966138, Title: Ancient origin of the tryptophan operon and the dynamics of evolutionary change., Authors: Xie G, Keyhani NO, Bonner CA, Jensen RA;, Citation: Microbiol Mol Biol Rev. 2003;67:303-42.]
children.description: The essential amino acid tryptophan is synthesized in prokaryotes, plants, and fungi via a conserved six step pathway from the branchpoint compound chrosimate, a common precursor in the biosynthesis of aromatic amino acids. Seven catalytic domains and two alpha/beta subunit complexes comprise this pathway. Individually expressed in some organisms, gene fusions encoding single proteins possessing two or more of these catalytic domains have been observed for every trp gene. Although the occurance of gene fusions have been shown to be phylogenetically unrelated, a conserved gene order can be discerned within the domain Bacteria. Occasionally gene(s) dissociations disrupt gene order as in Campylobacter jejuni and Deinococcus radiodurans, or the pathway is found split between two separate chromosomes as in Rhodobacter sphaeroides. In cyanobacteria, such as Nostoc and Anabaena, it is not uncommon to observe paralogous trp genes as part of a larger "supraoperon" including other aromatic amino acid synthesizing genes as well as their trp counterparts [1].

children.name: Histidine biosynthesis from ribose-5-phosphate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 8852895, Title: Histidine biosynthetic pathway and genes: structure, regulation, and evolution., Authors: Alifano P, Fani R, Liò P, Lazcano A, Bazzicalupo M, Carlomagno MS, Bruni CB;, Citation: Microbiol Rev. 1996;60:44-69., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 11842181, Title: Mechanism of action and NAD+-binding mode revealed by the crystal structure of L-histidinol dehydrogenase., Authors: Barbosa JA, Sivaraman J, Li Y, Larocque R, Matte A, Schrag JD, Cygler M;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2002;99:1859-1864.]
children.description: Histidine is synthesized from phosphoribosyl-pyrophosphate in a ten step pathway found in bacteria, archaebacteria, fungi, and plants. The early stage of this pathway takes a ribose and transforms it into imadiazoleglycerol phosphate. Once the imadiazole ring is formed, glutamate donates the a-amino group and the newly formed amine is oxidized to histidine [1]. In Salmonella typhimurium and Escherichia coli, this pathway is carried out by the eight genes in the 'his' operon. hisI, hisB, and hisD are bifunctional enzymes, hisF and hisH form a monofunctional dimer, and the rest are monofunctional enzymes [2].

children.name: Proline biosynthesis from glutamate
children.description: The amino acid proline is synthesized in three steps from glutamate via L-glutamate-5-semialdehyde which non-enzymatically cyclizes to delta-1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate. Glutamate semialdehyde can also arise from transamination of ornithine. Proline may also be synthesized directly from ornithine by the action of ornithine cyclodeaminase. These alternate paths are not covered by this property.

children.name: Arginine biosynthesis from ornithine, carbamoyl-p and aspartate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 9501170, Title: The crystal structure of Pyrococcus furiosus ornithine carbamoyltransferase reveals a key role for oligomerization in enzyme stability at extremely high temperatures., Authors: Villeret V, Clantin B, Tricot C, Legrain C, Roovers M, Stalon V, Glansdorff N, Van Beeumen J;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 1998;95:2801-2806.]
children.description: The arginine biosynthesis pathway is a three step process and a part of the urea cycle. The first enzyme, ornithine carbamoyltransferase (OTCase) carries out the reaction anabolically in arginine biosynthesis, but in some cases, it carries out catabolic reactions. Most OTCases are homotrimers, but the homotrimers are organized into dodecamers built from four trimers in at least two species; the catabolic OTCase of Pseudomonas aeruginosa is allosterically regulated, while OTCase of the extreme thermophile Pyrococcus furiosus shows both allostery and thermophily [1]. The third step of the pathway yields L-arginine by argininosuccinate lyase, and the amino acid can be cleaved by arginase, yielding urea and reconstituting ornithine.

children.name: Ornithine biosynthesis from glutamate, acetylated branch
children.description: This pathway results in the creation of ornithine for use in the biosynthesis of arginine and in the urea cycle. Ornithine can also be interconverted with glutamate semialdehyde from the proline biosynthetic pathway. This pathway represents one of two possible branches for the creation of ornithine from glutamate.

children.name: Threonine biosynthesis from aspartate semialdehyde
children.description: Threonine is synthesised from aspartate semialdehyde, a branch point intermediate in the synthesis of lysine. The aspartate semialdehyde is derived from aspartate, which in turn is derived from the Krebs cycle intermediate oxaloacetate. Homoserine, an intermediate in this pathway is a branchpoint for the biosynthesis of methionine. Threonine itself is utilized as a starting point for the biosynthesis of isoleucine.

children.name: Aspartate semialdehyde biosynthesis from aspartate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 2892836, Title: Structure of the yeast HOM3 gene which encodes aspartokinase., Authors: Rafalski JA, Falco SC;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1988;263:2146-2151.]
children.description: Aspartate semialdehyde biosynthesis is a two step pathway. The product of this pathway can be used in lysine biosynthesis, or in the pathway leading to homoserine, which is involved in threonine, isoleucine and methionine biosynthesis. There are three isozymes that differ in their sensitivity to regulation by Lys, Met and Thr in Escherichia coli [1].

children.name: Isoleucine biosynthesis from threonine and pyruvate
children.description: The branched amino acid isoleucine is biosynthesized from the central intermediary metabolite pyruvate and the amino acid threonine via a five step pathway. Four enzymes in this pathway are common to the pathways for the biosynthesis of leucine and valine, although specialized versions of these enzymes may exist in certain species which have a narrowed substrate range or amino acid-specific regulatory mechanisms. Unlike those other two pathways in which two molecules of pyruvate are condensed, here threonine is converted first to 2-oxobutyrate and then condensed with pyruvate. Thus, the enzymes common to the pathways are acting on distinct substrates. 2-oxobutyrate for this pathway may also be generated by a separate path from glutamate via mesaconate in certain organisms. The penultimate intermediate in this pathway, 2-oxo-3-methylvalerate may also be incorporated into branched-chain fatty acids

children.name: Valine biosynthesis from pyruvate
children.description: The branched amino acid valine is biosynthesized from the central intermediary metabolite pyruvate via a four step pathway. All four enzymes in this pathway are common to the pathways for the biosynthesis of isoleucine from 2-oxobutyrate and leucine from pyruvate, although specialized versions of these enzymes may exist in certain species which have a narrowed substrate range or amino acid-specific regulatory mechanisms. The product of the third step in this pathway, 2-oxoisovalerate is a branchpoint metabolite required for the biosynthesis of Coenzyme A, branched-chain fatty acids, and leucine. Similarly, the product of the first step, (S)-2-acetolactate is common to the pathway to (R,R)-2,3-butanediol in the mixed-acid fermentation of pyruvate. The first step of the pathway, acetolactate synthase, requires thiamine pyrophosphate and two molecules of pyruvate, one of which is decarboxylated to the acetoacetate adduct, 2-(alpha-hydroxyethyl)-ThPP.

children.name: Leucine biosynthesis from pyruvate and acetyl-CoA
children.description: The branched amino acid leucine is biosynthesized from the central intermediary metabolites pyruvate and acetyl-CoA via a seven step pathway. Four of these steps are shared with the valine and isoleucine pathways, although specialized versions of these enzymes may exist in certain species which have a narrowed substrate range or amino acid-specific regulatory mechanisms. The product of the third step in this pathway, 2-oxoisovalerate is a branchpoint metabolite required for the biosynthesis of Coenzyme A, branched-chain fatty acids and valine. Similarly, the product of the first step, (S)-2-acetolactate is common to the pathway to (R,R)-2,3-butanediol in the mixed-acid fermentation of pyruvate. The first step of the pathway, acetolactate synthase, requires thiamine pyrophosphate and two molecules of pyruvate, one of which is decarboxylated to the acetoacetate adduct, 2-(alpha-hydroxyethyl)-ThPP. The acetyl-CoA required for the fourth step, 2-isopropylmalate synthase, may also derive from this ThPP adduct by oxidation.

children.name: Glycine cleavage system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11286922, Title: The glycine decarboxylase system: a fascinating complex., Authors: Douce R, Bourguignon J, Neuburger M, Rebeille F;, Citation: Trends Plant Sci. 2001;6:167-176.]
children.description: The glycine cleavage system (GCS), also known as the glycine decarboxylase system (GDC) consists of a set of four enzymes, which are involved in a multi-step reaction to catalyse the cleavage of glycine molecules. The constituents enzymes are, P protein, H protein, T protein, and L protein (dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase)[1].

children.name: Lysine biosynthesis
children.description: The basic amino acid lysine may be synthesized by one of two types of pathways in prokaryotes, diaminopimelate (DAP) pathways and the alpha-aminoadipate (AAA) pathway. DAP pathways have several variants including the dehydrogenase (reductive) pathway which requires ammonia and NADPH, and the acetylated and succinylated pathways which do not. A non-reductive pathway which uses neither acetate or succinate protecting groups is found in plants but has not been observed in prokaryotes. The AAA pathway has a variant found in fungi and plants which has not been observed in prokaryotes.

children.name: Lysine biosynthesis via diaminopimelate (DAP)
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 17093042, Title: L,L-diaminopimelate aminotransferase, a trans-kingdom enzyme shared by Chlamydia and plants for synthesis of diaminopimelate/lysine., Authors: McCoy AJ, Adams NE, Hudson AO, Gilvarg C, Leustek T, Maurelli AT;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2006;103:17909-17914.]
children.description: The basic amino acid lysine is synthesized in most bacteria and plants via a nine step pathway from aspartate (via aspartate semialdehyde which is also used in a number of other pathways). Most species utilize succinate (from succinyl-CoA) to make an important amide linkage in the ring-opening of piperidine dicarboxylate. The succinate is then hydrolyzed several steps later. Other species carry out analogous transformations with acetate (from acetyl-CoA). Chlamydia and cyanobacteria have been shown to utilize a direct aminotransferase path without the acylation/deacylation steps, and a number of other species apparently also use this variant [1]. Each of these variants are included within this property. Certain obligate intracellular organisms such as Coxiella, Rickettsia and Wolbachia, contain all but the final step (diaminopimelate decarboxylase) of this pathway. Presumably these organisms have no need of lysine biosynthesis, being able to obtain it from their hosts. The products of the penultimate two steps however, LL- and meso-diaminopimelate, are required components of the bacterial cell wall, and so the rest of the pathway persists. There is a possibility that the decarboxylase exists in these organsims but is undetected.

children.name: Lysine biosynthesis via diaminopimelate (DAP), acetylated branch
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 20418392, Title: Methanococci use the diaminopimelate aminotransferase (DapL) pathway for lysine biosynthesis., Authors: Liu Y, White RH, Whitman WB;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2010;192(13):3304-3310.]
children.description: There are four known variations (branches) of the lysine biosynthesis pathway via diaminopimelate (DAP). The variations occur in the steps converting L-2,3,4,5-tetrahydrodipicolinate (THDPA) to LL-2,6-diaminopimelate. This property refers to the acetylated branch of this pathway which generates N-acetyl intermediates. This branch is limited to certain Bacillus species [1].

children.name: Lysine biosynthesis via diaminopimelate (DAP), succinylated branch
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 20418392, Title: Methanococci use the diaminopimelate aminotransferase (DapL) pathway for lysine biosynthesis., Authors: Liu Y, White RH, Whitman WB;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2010;192(13):3304-3310.]
children.description: There are four known variations (branches) of the lysine biosynthesis pathway via diaminopimelate (DAP). The variations occur in the steps converting L-2,3,4,5-tetrahydrodipicolinate (THDPA) to LL-2,6-diaminopimelate. This property refers to the succinylated branch of this pathway. This branch acylates THDPA with succinyl-CoA to generate N-succinyl-ll-2-amino-6-ketopimelate and forms meso-DAP by subsequent transamination, desuccinylation, and epimerization. This branch is utilized by proteobacteria as well as many firmicutes and actinobacteria [1].

children.name: Lysine biosynthesis via alpha-aminoadipate (AAA pathway)
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10613839, Title: A prokaryotic gene cluster involved in synthesis of lysine through the amino adipate pathway: a key to the evolution of amino acid biosynthesis., Authors: Nishida H, Nishiyama M, Kobashi N, Kosuge T, Hoshino T, Yamane H;, Citation: Genome Res. 1999;9:1175-1183.]
children.description: Lysine biosynthesis in fungi has been characterized and begins with the condensation of 2-oxoglutarate and acetyl-CoA to homocitrate and continues through the distinctive intermediate, alpha-aminoadipate. This pathway is distinct in every respect from the diaminopimelate pathway commonly found in bacteria and animals.Recently, an alpha-aminoadipate pathway closely related to the fungal version has been characterized in Thermus thermophilus [1] and appears to be widely distributed among the archaea.

children.name: Lysine biosynthesis via diaminopimelate (DAP) utilizing ammonia and NADPH
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 1906065, Title: A functionally split pathway for lysine synthesis in Corynebacterium glutamicium., Authors: Schrumpf B, Schwarzer A, Kalinowski J, Pühler A, Eggeling L, Sahm H;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1991;173:4510-4516.]
children.description: This pathway for the biosynthesis of L-lysine differs from the more common diaminopimelate pathway by the action of diaminopimelate dehydrogenase (ddh). This enzyme requires both ammonia as a nitrogen source (instead of an amino acid via a transaminase) and reductive power in the form of NADPH. Additionally, this pathway does not require the acetyl/succinyl protecting group transformations found in the standard pathway, nor does it require the action of diaminopimelate epimerase. This enzyme has been best characterized in Corynebacterium glutamicum and Bacillus sphaericus. One should note that the ddh enzyme is shown acting on the compound L-2-amino-6-oxoheptanedioate in EC and KEGG representations. This is merely the ring-opened form of 2,3,4,5-tetrahydropicolinate with which it is in equilibrium, and upon which the acyltransferases of the common pathway act.

children.name: Aspartate semialdehyde biosynthesis from aspartate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 2892836, Title: Structure of the yeast HOM3 gene which encodes aspartokinase., Authors: Rafalski JA, Falco SC;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1988;263:2146-2151.]
children.description: Aspartate semialdehyde biosynthesis is a two step pathway. The product of this pathway can be used in lysine biosynthesis, or in the pathway leading to homoserine, which is involved in threonine, isoleucine and methionine biosynthesis. There are three isozymes that differ in their sensitivity to regulation by Lys, Met and Thr in Escherichia coli [1].

children.name: Cysteine biosynthesis, tRNA-dependent
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15790858, Title: RNA-dependent cysteine biosynthesis in archaea., Authors: Sauerwald A, Zhu W, Major TA, Roy H, Palioura S, Jahn D, Whitman WB, Yates JR, Ibba M, Söll D;, Citation: Science. 2005;307:1969-1972.]
children.description: Methanocaldococcus jannaschii is a model archaeal species that lacks a direct cys--tRNA ligase. In a system analogous to pyrrolysine and (in many species) asparagine tRNA aminoacylation, the tRNA is misacylated and then the attached amino acid is modified. This two-step pathway is conducted by proteins in the families of MJ1660 (sepS) and MJ1678 (pscS). This pathway assumes 0-phosphoserine, whose biosynthesis is proposed to require D-3-phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase (TIGR01327) and an unidentified aminotransferase.

children.name: Cysteine biosynthesis from serine
children.description: The conversion of L-serine to L-cysteine requires two enzymatic steps as described here. The first step involves serine acetyl-transferase, and the second step involves acetylserine lyase which forms L-cysteine.

children.name: Methionine salvage from methylthioadenosine
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15102328, Title: Bacterial variations on the methionine salvage pathway., Authors: Sekowska A, Dénervaud V, Ashida H, Michoud K, Haas D, Yokota A, Danchin A;, Citation: BMC Microbiol. 2004;4:9.]
children.description: Methylthioadenosine (MTA) is a sulfur-containing by-product from the use of S-adenosylmethionine in spermidine or polyamine biosynthesis and certain other pathways. A series of reactions, with considerable species-specific variation, recycles MTA to methionine in a wide range of organisms. In a new nomenclature, these genes are now designated mtn (MethylThioNucleoside). An interesting enzyme in this system is MtnD, the aci-reductone dioxygenase. This enzyme has two different enzymatic activities, depending on whether Ni2+ or Fe2+ is bound. The action of the single enzyme MtnP is replaced by two enzymes, MtnN and MtnK in some species. Likewise, the enolase-phosphatase MtnC is replaced by MtnW and MtnX in the Bacillus lineage. The final step in the pathway, a transamination that generates methionine from 2-keto-4-methylthiobutyrate, apparantly can be catalyzed by a large number of functional analogs using different amino donors, and so is not included explicitly in the reconstruction.

children.description: In many species with methionine salvage from methylthioadenosine, a single protein (MtnC) acts as an enolase-phosphatase. However, in Bacillus subtilis and related species, the enolase and phosphate are separate proteins designated MtnW and MtnX. The former resembles RuBisCO and the latter belongs to the HAD superfamily hydrolases.

children.name: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase complex
children.description: Plays a key role in both pyrimidine and arginine biosynthesis by catalyzing the production of carbamoyl phosphate from one molecule of bicarbonate, two molecules of MgATP, and one molecule of glutamine. Consists of two polypeptide chains referred to as the small and large subunits, which contain a total of three separate active sites that are connected by an intramolecular tunnel. The small subunit harbors one of these active sites and is responsible for the hydrolysis of glutamine to glutamate and ammonia. The large subunit binds the two required molecules of MgATP and is involved in assembling the final product. Compounds such as L-ornithine, UMP, and IMP allosterically regulate the enzyme.

children.name: Cofactor biosynthesis
children.description: The biosynthesis of molecules utilized by enzymes to aid in chemical transformations.

children.name: Chorismate biosynthesis via shikimate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12636087, Title: The biosynthesis of shikimate metabolites., Authors: Knaggs AR;, Citation: Nat Prod Rep. 2003;20:119-136.]
children.description: Chorismate is the final common intermediate in the biosynthesis of phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan (the aromatic amino acids) as well as menaquinone, ubiquinone, salicylate and phenazine.Chorismate is synthesized via a seven-step pathway starting from the precursors D-erythrose 4-phosphate and phosphoenolpyruvate.This pathway is widely distributed among microorganisms[1]. Certain methanogenic euarchaeota appear to be missing the first two steps of the pathway - these may be catalyzed by as of yet uncharacterized enzymes.

children.name: Glutathione biosynthesis
children.description: Glutathione (GSH) is gamma-Glu-Cys-Gly, a thiol whose -SH group is an important reductant in many systems. Some species use thiols other than glutathione: mycothione in Mycobacterium tuberculosis, gamma-glutamylcysteine in Halobacterium, and trypanothione in trypanosomes. Cysteine and CoA may also serve. Glutathione biosynthesis is accomplished by two enzymes. First, glutamate--cysteine ligase links the gamma-COOH of Glu to the NH2 of Cys. Next, glutathione synthase creates a peptide bond from the COOH of Cys to the NH2 of Gly. Species that synthesize glutathione are likely to have a reductase for oxidized glutathione and a number of glutathione-dependent enzymes.

children.name: Biotin biosynthesis
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 21437340, Title: Closing in on complete pathways of biotin biosynthesis., Authors: Lin S, Cronan JE;, Citation: Mol Biosyst. 2011;7(6):1811-1821.]
children.description: Biotin is an essential cofactor for many carboxylation (addition of CO2) reactions. This property reflects biosynthesis of biotin from pimeloyl-CoA, although the source of pimeloyl-CoA may vary. 8-amino-7-oxononanoate synthase (also called 7-keto-8-aminopelargonic acid synthetase, AONS, gene BioF) converts pimeloyl-CoA to 8-amino-7-oxononanoate (AON). Adenosylmethionine-8-amino-7-oxononanoate aminotransferase (gene BioA) converts the product to 7,8-diaminononanoate, from which dethiobiotin synthase (gene BioD) makes dethiobiotin. Biotin synthase (gene BioB) then makes biotin itself[1]. Enzymes such as carboxylesterase (gene BioH), which are involved in pimeloyl-CoA biosynthesis typically receive biotin-related annotations, but may also appear in genomes in which biotin is not synthesized and pimeloyl-CoA is used for something else.

children.name: Tetrahydrofolate biosynthesis from GTP and PABA

children.description: Polyglutamylated tetrahydrofolate is the central cofactor of one-carbon metabolism, and is biosynthesized from GTP, para-aminobenzoate (from chorismate), and glutamate in a six step reaction [1]. The first enzyme (GTP cyclohydrolase I) catalizes dihydroneopterin triphosphate from GTP in the biosynthesis of tetrahydrofolate in prokaryotes, of tetrahydrobiopterin in vertebrates, and of pteridine-containing pigments in insects. This pathway is carried out by 6 enzymes, the complete pathway being absent in animals.

children.name: NAD(P) biosynthesis from L-aspartate and DHAP
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12496312, Title: Aspartate dehydrogenase, a novel enzyme identified from structural and functional studies of TM1643., Authors: Yang Z, Savchenko A, Yakunin A, Zhang R, Edwards A, Arrowsmith C, Tong L;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2003;278:8804-8808.]
children.description: Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADP+) also known as pyridine nucleotides, are cofactors involved in numerous redox reactions through reversible reactions to their reduced forms NADH and NADPH. In bacteria, NAD+ is synthesized in a 5 step reaction (NadABCDE) from L-aspartate, and NADP+ is made from NAD+ by the action of NAD kinase [1]. In mammals, an altenative pathway exists in which the intermediate quinolinate is made from L-tryptophan. NAD+ may also be recycled from nicotinamide after nucleosidease cleavage, or synthesized from imported nicotinate (niacin).

children.name: Pantothenate biosynthesis from aspartate and 2-oxoisovalerate
children.description: This genome property tracks four proteins of pantothenate biosynthesis from aspartate; PanB, PanC, PanD and PanE. In the simplest case PanB (3-methyl-2-oxobutanoate hydroxymethyltransferase) makes 2-dehydropantoate from 3-methyl-2-oxobutanoate. PanE (2-dehydropantoate 2-reductase) makes (R)-pantoate from 2-dehydropantoate. PanD (aspartate 1-decarboxylase) makes beta-alanine from L-aspartate, and PanC (pantoate--beta-alanine ligase) then produces (R)-pantothenate from beta-alanine and (R)-pantoate. The genes for three of the proteins (PanB, PanC and PanD) tend to be clustered in bacterial genomes. However, the protein family distribution for PanE, is very different. The production of (R)-pantoate from 2-dehydropantoate can occur in more than one way (NADH or NADPH-dependent), and may be catalyzed by enzymes that have additional important substrates (an example is the D-mandelate dehydrogenase of Enterococcus faecalis).

children.name: Ubiquinone biosynthesis from chorismate, aerobic
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10419476, Title: Yeast and rat Coq3 and Escherichia coli UbiG polypeptides catalyze both O-methyltransferase steps in coenzyme Q biosynthesis., Authors: Poon WW, Barkovich RJ, Hsu AY, Frankel A, Lee PT, Shepherd JN, Myles DC, Clarke CF;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1999;274(31):21665-72., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 23709220, Title: ubiI, a new gene in Escherichia coli coenzyme Q biosynthesis, is involved in aerobic C5-hydroxylation., Authors: Hajj Chehade M, Loiseau L, Lombard M, Pecqueur L, Ismail A, Smadja M, Golinelli-Pimpaneau B, Mellot-Draznieks C, Hamelin O, Aussel L, Kieffer-Jaquinod S, Labessan N, Barras F, Fontecave M, Pierrel F;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2013;288(27):20085-20092., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 365223, Title: Alternative hydroxylases for the aerobic and anaerobic biosynthesis of ubiquinone in Escherichia coli., Authors: Alexander K, Young IG;, Citation: Biochemistry. 1978;17:4750-4755., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 11583838, Title: Ubiquinone biosynthesis in microorganisms., Authors: Meganathan R;, Citation: FEMS Microbiol Lett. 2001;203:131-139.]
children.description: Ubiquinone (also known as coenzyme Q) is an electron and hydrogen transport cofactor important for aerobic respiration and photosynthesis. It is synthesized in bacteria from chorismate and polyprenyl pyrophosphates of varying lengths. The pathway is composed of 10 Ubi proteins which are named UbiA-I and UbiX. UbiG catalyses two O-methylation steps within the pathway, but with different substrates in each case [1]. UbiB is thought to be involved with the fourth step in the pathway, catalysed by UbiI [2], but is not included in the pathway diagrams. Knock-out of the three hydroxylation steps requiring molecular oxygen results in anaerobic synthesis of ubiquinone, indicating the presence of an alternative system [3]. In yeast and animals, a different pathway exists starting from 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate, having latter steps in common with the bacterial pathway [4]. In addition to ubiquinone, bacteria may contain menaquinone and/or phylloquinone which together make up their quinone pool.

children.name: Iron-sulfur cluster assembly systems
children.description: At least three different systems have been described for iron cluster assembly, the NIF system provides clusters to nitrogenase, the ISC system may provide both 2Fe-2S and 4Fe-4S clusters for various enzymes in Proteobacteria and the SUF system is capable of functioning in the presence of oxidative stress.

children.name: Iron-sulfur cluster assembly SUF system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12089140, Title: A third bacterial system for the assembly of iron-sulfur clusters with homologs in archaea and plastids., Authors: Takahashi Y, Tokumoto U;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2002;277:28380-28383., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12876288, Title: Biogenesis of Fe-S cluster by the bacterial Suf system: SufS and SufE form a new type of cysteine desulfurase., Authors: Loiseau L, Ollagnier-de-Choudens S, Nachin L, Fontecave M, Barras F;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2003;278:38352-38359., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 12554644, Title: SufC: an unorthodox cytoplasmic ABC/ATPase required for [Fe-S] biogenesis under oxidative stress., Authors: Nachin L, Loiseau L, Expert D, Barras F;, Citation: EMBO J. 2003;22:427-437.]
children.description: The iron-sulfur cluster assembly SUF system is one of three iron-sulfur assembly systems present in a wide range of bacteria, archeae, and plastids. The other two mechanisms for iron-sulfur cluster assembly are the ISC (iron-sulfur cluster) system, composed of at least six components and found broadly distributed from bacteria to higher eukaryotes, and the NIF (nitrogen fixation) system, which is required for nitrogenase maturation [1]. The SUF (mobilization of sulfur) system is composed of a six gene cluster with protein complexes responsible for cysteine desulfuration of sulfur atoms from cysteine, cytosolic ATPase activity, and a protein scaffold for iron and sulfur cluster assembly and transfer to protein targets [2]. Operational under stressful growth conditions, such as iron limitation and oxidative stress, the SUF system has been shown to be an important factor for bacterial pathogenicity [3].

children.description: At least three different systems have been described for 2Fe-2S cluster assembly. The NIF system provides an iron-sulfur cluster to nitrogenase in certain nitrogen-fixing species. SUF, described the most recently, can operate despite aerobic stress. This property describes the ISC system as found in E. coli and many other proteobacteria, containing at least the following elements: a characteristic cysteine desulfurase IscS, a characteristic ferredoxin, chaperones called heat shock cognate proteins A and B, and an assembly scaffold protein resembling the N terminus of the scaffold protein of the NIF system [1].

children.name: Iron-sulfur cluster assembly CsdA-CsdE system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15901727, Title: Analysis of the heteromeric CsdA-CsdE cysteine desulfurase, assisting Fe-S cluster biogenesis in Escherichia coli., Authors: Loiseau L, Ollagnier-de Choudens S, Lascoux D, Forest E, Fontecave M, Barras F;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2005;280:26760-26769.]
children.description: The heteromeric complex of CsdA and CsdE plays a role in iron-sulfur (Fe-S) cluster biosynthesis, as do the better-known systems ISC, SUF, and NIF. CdsA, a homolog of SufS, IscS, and NifS, is a cysteine desulfurase catalytic subunit. CdsE, a SufE homolog, physically interacts and accepts a sulfur at Cys-61 (numbered as in Escherichia coli). In contrast to sulfur-accepting components such as NifU and IscU, CsdE does not bind iron and is not viewed as a scaffold on which Fe-S cluster biosynthesis can be completed prior to transfer to other proteins. Rather, the simplicity of this system may reflect a limited role for the maturation of specific Fe-S cluster-containing proteins.

children.name: Iron-sulfur cluster assembly NIF system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10639125, Title: NifS-directed assembly of a transient [2Fe-2S] cluster within the NifU protein., Authors: Yuvaniyama P, Agar JN, Cash VL, Johnson MK, Dean DR;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2000;97:599-604., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 15667274, Title: NifU and NifS are required for the maturation of nitrogenase and cannot replace the function of isc-gene products in Azotobacter vinelandii., Authors: Johnson DC, Dos Santos PC, Dean DR;, Citation: Biochem Soc Trans. 2005;33:90-93.]
children.description: Iron-sulfur (FeS) cluster assembly systems include the NIF system, which is part of nitrogen fixation clusters in a number of bacteria, as well as the ISC and SUF systems. The latter two make FeS clusters for a wide variety of proteins, while NIF and a related system called CsdA-CsdE may produce FeS clusters for only a small range of target proteins. The defining components of the NIF-type systems described here are the cysteine desulfurase NifS and the FeS cluster assembly scaffold protein NifU. The terms NifS and NifU are applied not only to components of nitrogen fixation systems, but also to tandem gene pairs in other organisms such as Helicobacter pylori. These NifU-like and NifS-like proteins largely fall into separate clades, and are best modeled by separate HMMs, but are included in this Genome Property as components of NIF-type systems. NifS/NifU or NifS-like/NifU-like pairs may produce FeS clusters for a limited range of target proteins, as in Azotobacter vinelandii, or uniquely within the cell, as in Helicobacter pylori.

children.name: SufBCD complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 20857974, Title: SufD and SufC ATPase activity are required for iron acquisition during in vivo Fe-S cluster formation on SufB., Authors: Saini A, Mapolelo DT, Chahal HK, Johnson MK, Outten FW, Citation: Biochemistry. 2010;49:9402-9412, Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12941942, Title: The SufE protein and the SufBCD complex enhance SufS cysteine desulfurase activity as part of a sulfur transfer pathway for Fe-S cluster assembly in Escherichia coli., Authors: Outten FW, Wood MJ, Munoz FM, Storz G, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2003;278:45713-45719]
children.description: Scaffold complex that assembles an Fe-S cluster. The SufB protomer of the SufBCD complex accepts the atomic sulfur from the sulfur transfer protein SufE (CPX-2125 [SufE dimer], EBI-8844754 [transfer interaction]) and incorporates it into an [4Fe-4S] cluster in an as yet undiscovered manner. SufBCD further transfers the Fe-S cluster to the carrier protein SufA (CPX-2142 [dimer], EBI-8805910 [transfer interaction]). SufBCD is a component of the sufABCDSE operon, which is activated and required under specific conditions such as oxidative stress and iron limitation. The SufBCD complex is a putative ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter complex, inferred by its structural similarity with other ABC transporters. SufC has been shown to be an ATPase whose activity is enhanced by the presence of SufB and SufD [1]. The precise function of FADH2 is not yet clear. Under aerobic conditions FADH2 is oxidised to FAD and dissociates from SufBCD.

children.name: Coenzyme PQQ biosynthesis
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 18371220, Title: The pyrroloquinoline quinone biosynthesis pathway revisited: a structural approach., Authors: Puehringer S, Metlitzky M, Schwarzenbacher R;, Citation: BMC Biochem. 2008;9:8.]
children.description: Coenzyme PQQ (coenzyme pyrrolo-quinoline-quinone) is a cofactor of certain alcohol dehydrogenases and glucose dehydrogenases. PQQ biosynthesis is associated with an operon that includes PqqA, a small protein proposed to act as a molecular precursor. At least 6 genes are located within the PQQ-operon, all of which are required for PQQ biosynthesis, although in some cases the exact mechanism of the gene product is not known [1].

children.name: Coenzyme A biosynthesis from pantothenate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15893380, Title: Coenzyme A: back in action., Authors: Leonardi R, Zhang YM, Rock CO, Jackowski S;, Citation: Prog Lipid Res. 2005;44:125-153.]
children.description: This property represents a 5-step pathway for the biosynthesis of coenzyme A (CoA) from pantothenate. Most species produce panthothenate but some must import it. The first step described here is a sodium/pantothenate symporter. The first required step, catalyzed by pantothenate kinase, is carried out by at least two different known protein families. One is found in most bacteria, including E. coli (TIGR00554). Another is present in eukaryotes and in a few Gram-positive bacteria (e.g. Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus anthracis) (TIGR00555). The enzyme, if present, has not been identified in a number of species. The second and third enzymes are usually found together in a multifunctional protein, phosphopantothenoylcysteine decarboxylase/phosphopantothenate--cysteine ligase, once thought to affect DNA metabolism as well. In Streptococcus and allies, and some other species, the enzymes are encoded in tandem genes rather than fused. CoaD and CoaE are, respectively, pantetheine-phosphate adenylyltransferase and dephospho-CoA kinase [1].

children.name: Hydroxyethylthiazole (HET) biosynthesis from 1-deoxy-D-xylulose-5-phosphate, Cysteine, and either Tyr or Gly
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12376536, Title: Comparative genomics of thiamin biosynthesis in procaryotes. New genes and regulatory mechanisms., Authors: Rodionov DA, Vitreschak AG, Mironov AA, Gelfand MS;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2002;277:48949-48959., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12410317, Title: Thiamine derivatives bind messenger RNAs directly to regulate bacterial gene expression., Authors: Winkler W, Nahvi A, Breaker RR;, Citation: Nature. 2002;419:952-956.]
children.description: This property describes de novo synthesis of the thiazole moiety of thiamine, hydroxyethylthiazole (HET). This requires more distinct proteins than that of the pyrimidine moeity, hydromethylpyrimidine (HMP). Phosphorylated forms of HET and HMP are connected by ThiE as thiamine phosphate and converted eventually to the active form thiamine pyrophosphate, TPP. HET biosynthesis requires the small ThiS protein, the C terminus of which becomes modified transiently by a sulfur atom from cysteine [1]. ThiG is required, along with either ThiH in species where tyrosine is a precursor or ThiO in species where glycine is a precursor. ThiF, although required biosynthetically, is not readily separated from MoeB, a molybdopterin biosynthesis protein, and so is not considered a required component. The ThiI gene is required, but also serves in formation of a tRNA modified site in species that do not make HET [2]. This property represents and alternative to HET uptake as a means to obtain the thiazole component for thiamine biosynthesis.

children.name: 5-aminolevulinate biosynthesis
children.description: 5-aminolevulinate, a heme precursor, may be biosynthesized by one of two pathways. The C5 (or Glutamate) pathway is more common [GenProp0217], while alphaproteobacteria utilize the enzyme 5-aminolevulinate synthase to make the molecule from succinyl-CoA and glycine [GenProp0223].

children.name: 5-aminolevulinate biosynthesis (glutamate pathway)

children.description: This pathway for the biosynthesis of 5-aminolevulinate, a porphyrin precursor, is known as the glutamate or C5 pathway and is found in most bacteria. A distinctive feature of this pathway is the utilization of an amino acid-charged tRNA as an enzymatic substrate.An alternative pathway from succinyl-CoA and glycine utilizing 5-aminolevulinate synthase is found in the alphaproteobacteria and eukaryotic mitochondria[1,2,3].

children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12376536, Title: Comparative genomics of thiamin biosynthesis in procaryotes. New genes and regulatory mechanisms., Authors: Rodionov DA, Vitreschak AG, Mironov AA, Gelfand MS;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2002;277:48949-48959.]
children.description: This property describes de novo synthesis of teh essential cofactor thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) [1]. children.name: Hydroxymethylpyrimidine pyrophosphate (HMP-P) biosynthesis from aminoimidazole ribotide
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12376536, Title: Comparative genomics of thiamin biosynthesis in procaryotes. New genes and regulatory mechanisms., Authors: Rodionov DA, Vitreschak AG, Mironov AA, Gelfand MS;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2002;277:48949-48959.]
children.description: Hydroxymethylpyrimidine pyrophosphate (HMP-PP) and hydroxyethylthiazole phosphate (HET-P) are the two components attached by ThiE to yield thiamine phosphate, which is subsequently converted to the active form thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP). HMP and HET may be imported and converted to HMP-PP and HET-P, respectively, as an alternative to de novo biosynthesis. This property reflects known steps of HMP-P de novo biosynthesis from the purine biosynthesis metabolite aminoimidazole ribotide (AIR), starting with the ThiC enzyme [1].

children.name: Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) biosynthesis from HMP-PP and HET-P
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12376536, Title: Comparative genomics of thiamin biosynthesis in procaryotes. New genes and regulatory mechanisms., Authors: Rodionov DA, Vitreschak AG, Mironov AA, Gelfand MS;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2002;277:48949-48959.]
children.description: Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is an essential cofactor for several carbohydrate metabolism enzymes. Hydroxymethylpyrimidine pyrophosphate (HMP-PP) may be obtained by de novo synthesis, or by import or salvage of hydroxymethylpyrimidine followed by phosphorylation. Likewise, hydroxyethylthiazole phosphate (HET-P) may come from synthesis, import, or salvage. The two heterocylic compounds are ligated by ThiE to thiamine phosphate. Thiamine phosphate then undegoes either dephosphorylation followed by pyrophosphorylation or direct phosphorylation [1].

children.name: Photosynthetic cofactor biosynthesis
children.description: The biosynthesis of compounds which assist in the harvesting of light energy, such as chlorophyll and bacteriochlorophyll.

children.name: Chlorophyllide a biosynthesis from protoporphyrin IX
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 17370354, Title: Recent advances in chlorophyll biosynthesis., Authors: Bollivar DW;, Citation: Photosynth Res. 2006;90(2):173-194.]
children.description: Chlorophyllide a is synthesised from protoporphyrin IX as part of the chlorophyll biosynthesis pathway. There is an aerobic and an anaerobic branch, this property represnts the aerobic branch. The first step (Mg-chelatase) has been shown to require three subunits encoded by three different genes. The final two steps in this pathway (vinyl reductase and protochlorophyllide reductase) can occur in the alternate order from that shown. There are two different enzymes that can catalyse the final (protochlorophyllide reductase) step; light-dependent protochlorophyllide reductase, and light-independent protochlorophyllide reductase. Despite catalyzing the same reaction, the two enzymes are very different [1].

children.name: Bacteriochlorophyll biosynthesis from chlorophyllide a
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 17370354, Title: Recent advances in chlorophyll biosynthesis., Authors: Bollivar DW;, Citation: Photosynth Res. 2006;90(2):173-194.]
children.description: Chlorophyllide a is the common branchpoint of the chlorophyll and bacteriochlorophyll biosynthetic pathways. This Genome Property describes the pathway beyond this branchpoint, which ultimately produces bacteriochlorophyll a. Three of the steps in the pathway (chlorophyllide reductase, bacteriochlorophyllide a dehydrogenase and bacteriochlorophyllide hydratase) can act in multiple orders producing different intermediates [1].

children.name: Menaquinone biosynthesis
children.description: Menaquinone may be synthesized by one of two independent pathways. The better known pathway, which includes MenA, MenB, etc., as found in Escherichia coli, passes through the intermediate SEPHCHC (see GenProp0058). An alternate pathway, found in both Helicobacter pylori and Streptomyces coelicolor, involves the intermediate futalosine (see GenProp0829).

children.name: Menaquinone biosynthesis via SEPHCHC
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 18284213, Title: Identification and characterization of (1R,6R)-2-succinyl-6-hydroxy-2,4-cyclohexadiene-1-carboxylate synthase in the menaquinone biosynthesis of Escherichia coli., Authors: Jiang M, Chen X, Guo ZF, Cao Y, Chen M, Guo Z;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2008;47:3426-3434., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 17760421, Title: Menaquinone biosynthesis in Escherichia coli: identification of 2-succinyl-5-enolpyruvyl-6-hydroxy-3-cyclohexene-1-carboxylate as a novel intermediate and re-evaluation of MenD activity., Authors: Jiang M, Cao Y, Guo ZF, Chen M, Chen X, Guo Z;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2007;46:10979-10989., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 18801996, Title: An alternative menaquinone biosynthetic pathway operating in microorganisms., Authors: Hiratsuka T, Furihata K, Ishikawa J, Yamashita H, Itoh N, Seto H, Dairi T;, Citation: Science. 2008;321(5896):1670-1673.]
children.description: Menaquinone (also known as Vitamin K2) is one of the quinone cofactors which play an essential role in hydrogen transfer reactions, particularly during anaerobic respiration. Menaquinone in E. coli and various other bacteria is synthesized from chorismate, 2-oxoglutarate, polyprenyl-pyrophosphate and S-adenosylmethionine via SEPHCHC and SHCHC intermediates [1,2]. A very similar molecule (phylloquinone, vitamin K1) is found in cyanobacteria and plants which contains a shorter isoprenoid (phytyl) chain in which three of the four double bonds are reduced. In animals, both vitamins K1 and K2 act as cofactors for gamma-carboxylation of glutamate (Glu -> Gla) which is critical for coagulation factors. Note that an alternative pathway for menaquinone biosynthesis (not described by this property) operates in Helicobacter pylori, Campylobacter jejuni, Streptomyces, and other species [3].

children.name: Molybdopterin biosynthesis
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15632135, Title: In vitro molybdenum ligation to molybdopterin using purified components., Authors: Nichols JD, Rajagopalan KV;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2005;280:7817-7822.]
children.description: Molybdenum, in every enzyme containing it except nitrogenase, is a single atom coordinated by the two sulfur atoms of molybdopterin (MPT). MoaA and MoaC synthesize precursor Z from guanine. MoaD (supported by MoeB) and MoaE synthesize MPT from precursor Z. MoeA and MogA add molybdenum to the dithiolene of MPT. A molybdenum transport system (see GenProp0192) must also be present. In bacteria, MPT most often occurs as the derivative molybdopterin guanine dinucleotide (MGG); MobA catalyzes the addition of GMP to MPT. In hyperthermophiles, tungsten may substitute for molybdenum. In species with a member of family TIGR03309 (YqeB family), selenium can substitute for sulfur.

children.name: Coenzyme F420 biosynthesis
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 18260642, Title: Identification and characterization of the 2-phospho-L-lactate guanylyltransferase involved in coenzyme F420 biosynthesis., Authors: Grochowski LL, Xu H, White RH;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2008;47:3033-3037., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12911320, Title: CofE catalyzes the addition of two glutamates to F420-0 in F420 coenzyme biosynthesis in Methanococcus jannaschii., Authors: Li H, Graupner M, Xu H, White RH;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2003;42:9771-9778., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 11717263, Title: Use of transposon Tn5367 mutagenesis and a nitroimidazopyran-based selection system to demonstrate a requirement for fbiA and fbiB in coenzyme F(420) biosynthesis by Mycobacterium bovis BCG., Authors: Choi KP, Bair TB, Bae YM, Daniels L;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2001;183:7058-7066., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 11888293, Title: Characterization of the 2-phospho-L-lactate transferase enzyme involved in coenzyme F(420) biosynthesis in Methanococcus jannaschii., Authors: Graupner M, Xu H, White RH;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2002;41:3754-3761.]
children.description: Coenzyme F420 is a hydride carrier cofactor functioning in methanogenesis [1]. The chromophore of coenzyme F420 is 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy-5-deazaflavin (otherwise known as FO), which is also used in a cyanobacterial DNA photoreactivating enzyme. Modification of FO to create coenzyme F420 includes the GTP-dependent addition of two glutamate residues in Methanococcus jannaschii [2] and five or six in Mycobacterium bovis [3]. CofF, which caps the gamma-glutamyl tail after two glutamates, occurs only the archaea.

children.name: 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy-5-deazariboflavin (FO) biosynthesis
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 2110564, Title: DNA photoreactivating enzyme from the cyanobacterium Anacystis nidulans., Authors: Eker AP, Kooiman P, Hessels JK, Yasui A;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1990;265:8009-8015., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 14593448, Title: Identification of the 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy-5-deazariboflavin synthase required for coenzyme F(420) biosynthesis., Authors: Graham DE, Xu H, White RH;, Citation: Arch Microbiol. 2003;180:455-464., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 11948155, Title: Demonstration that fbiC is required by Mycobacterium bovis BCG for coenzyme F(420) and FO biosynthesis., Authors: Choi KP, Kendrick N, Daniels L;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2002;184:2420-2428.]
children.description: 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy-5-deazariboflavin, or FO, is the chromophore of coenzyme F420. Several enzymatic steps convert FO to F420 (see GenProp0791). FO is also the chromophore of a cyanobacterial DNA photoreactivating enzyme [1]. The two key enzymes of this pathway, encoded by CofG and CofH in Methanocaldococcus jannaschii, are encoded by fusion proteins in certain lineages. The fusion protein in Mycobacterium smegmatis is designated FbiC (F420 BIosynthesis C). The precursors are a pyrimidine intermediate from riboflavin biosynthesis and the 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate precursor of tyrosine, so expressing FbiC in Escherichia coli is sufficient for FO biosynthesis [2].

children.name: 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy-5-deazariboflavin (FO) biosynthesis
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 2110564, Title: DNA photoreactivating enzyme from the cyanobacterium Anacystis nidulans., Authors: Eker AP, Kooiman P, Hessels JK, Yasui A;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1990;265:8009-8015., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 14593448, Title: Identification of the 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy-5-deazariboflavin synthase required for coenzyme F(420) biosynthesis., Authors: Graham DE, Xu H, White RH;, Citation: Arch Microbiol. 2003;180:455-464., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 11948155, Title: Demonstration that fbiC is required by Mycobacterium bovis BCG for coenzyme F(420) and FO biosynthesis., Authors: Choi KP, Kendrick N, Daniels L;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2002;184:2420-2428.]
children.description: 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy-5-deazariboflavin, or FO, is the chromophore of coenzyme F420. Several enzymatic steps convert FO to F420 (see GenProp0791). FO is also the chromophore of a cyanobacterial DNA photoreactivating enzyme [1]. The two key enzymes of this pathway, encoded by CofG and CofH in Methanocaldococcus jannaschii, are encoded by fusion proteins in certain lineages. The fusion protein in Mycobacterium smegmatis is designated FbiC (F420 BIosynthesis C). The precursors are a pyrimidine intermediate from riboflavin biosynthesis and the 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate precursor of tyrosine, so expressing FbiC in Escherichia coli is sufficient for FO biosynthesis [2].

children.name: Ergothioneine biosynthesis
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 20420449, Title: In vitro reconstitution of Mycobacterial ergothioneine biosynthesis., Authors: Seebeck FP;, Citation: J Am Chem Soc. 2010;132:6632-6633.]
children.description: In actinobacteria, ergothioneine biosynthesis begins with EgtD, a SAM-dependent enzyme that trimethylates the histidine alpha-amino group to produce hercynine, the histidine-betaine. EgtA gamma-ligates Cys to Glu, as occurs in glutathione biosynthesis. Next, EgtB attaches hercynine to gammaglutamyl cysteine, with sulfur attachment to the histidine-derived ring. EgtC then releases glutamate. Finally EgtE, a pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzyme related to selenocysteine lyase, cleaves the hercynylcysteine sulfoxide to leave ergothioneine. Ergothioneine production is known also in cyanobacteria and mushrooms, and is predicted to be more widely distributed.
