children.name: Rhamnose catabolism
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 9893952, Title: The metabolism of 6-deoxyhexoses in bacterial and animal cells., Authors: Tonetti M, Sturla L, Bisso A, Zanardi D, Benatti U, De Flora A;, Citation: Biochimie. 1998;80:923-931., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 15576793, Title: A genetic locus necessary for rhamnose uptake and catabolism in Rhizobium leguminosarum bv. trifolii., Authors: Richardson JS, Hynes MF, Oresnik IJ;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2004;186:8433-8442., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 8384447, Title: Proton-linked L-rhamnose transport, and its comparison with L-fucose transport in Enterobacteriaceae., Authors: Muiry JA, Gunn TC, McDonald TP, Bradley SA, Tate CG, Henderson PJ;, Citation: Biochem J. 1993;290 ( Pt 3):833-842., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 3316663, Title: Positive regulation of the Escherichia coli L-rhamnose operon is mediated by the products of tandemly repeated regulatory genes., Authors: Tobin JF, Schleif RF;, Citation: J Mol Biol. 1987;196:789-799., Ref 5, Pubmed ID: 3275622, Title: Metabolism of L-fucose and L-rhamnose in Escherichia coli: aerobic-anaerobic regulation of L-lactaldehyde dissimilation., Authors: Baldomà L, Aguilar J;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1988;170:416-421., Ref 6, Pubmed ID: 15876375, Title: Structural insights into the monosaccharide specificity of Escherichia coli rhamnose mutarotase., Authors: Ryu KS, Kim JI, Cho SJ, Park D, Park C, Cheong HK, Lee JO, Choi BS;, Citation: J Mol Biol. 2005;349:153-162.]
children.description: L-rhamnose, (aka 6-deoxy-L-mannose) is a common sugar synthesized and utilized in oligosaccharides and glcyolipids by many bacteria [1]. The monosaccharide is available in various environments and thus regulatory, transport and enzymatic systems have also evolved for its breakdown and use as a carbon source. The system modeled here includes specific transporters, ketose-aldose isomerases, kinases, and aldolases which result in the production of lactaldehyde and glycerone-phosphate. As these genes are generally organized into operons, assignments can be made for regulatory components as well as transport and enzymatic components which, by homology alone, cannot be assigned a specific substrate. Certain of the enzymes in this system are similar enough to cognate enzymes in the fucose catabolism system (GenProp0458) as to have caused gene naming errors in the past (i.e. fuculokinase/rhamnokinase). The system in certain rhizobial species [2] has been reported to vary from the canonical pathway in that the sugar may be phosphorylated prior to isomerization (i.e. the rhamnulokinase may in fact be a rhamnokinase and the rhamnose isomerase may be a rhamnose-1-phosphate isomerase), although this has not yet been independantly verified. In addition to the characterized rhamnose:proton symporter [3], rhamnose catabolism operons contain transporters from the ABC, and major facilitator families. Regulators are generally members of the DeoR and AraC [4] families. The product of both rhamnose and fucose catabolism is lactaldehyde, and subsequently alcohol and aldehyde dehydrogenases are often present in those operons to convert it to either 1,2-propane diol or lactate depending on oxidation conditions [5]. Rhamnose operons also often contain an epimerase (mutarotase) enzyme which has been proposed to be essential only under limiting L-rhamnose conditions [6]. Partial rhamnose catabolism operons have been detected in Thermotoga species which appear to handle the import and cleavage of rhamnose-containing oligosaccharides.

children.name: Fucose catabolism
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 3325779, Title: The organization of the fuc regulon specifying L-fucose dissimilation in Escherichia coli K12 as determined by gene cloning., Authors: Chen YM, Zhu Y, Lin EC;, Citation: Mol Gen Genet. 1987;210:331-337.]
children.description: This property describes the catabolism of fucose by the following route. L-fucose to fuculose by L-fucose ketol-isomerase, then to L-fuculose 1P by L-fuculokinase, then to L-lactaldehyde and glycerone phosphate by L-fuculose-phosphate aldolase. The property also includes a transporter to import fucose and transcription factors.

children.name: Malonate decarboxylase
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11902724, Title: Enzymic and genetic basis for bacterial growth on malonate., Authors: Dimroth P, Hilbi H;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 1997;25:3-10., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12619701, Title: Functions of malonate decarboxylase subunits from Pseudomonas putida., Authors: Chohnan S, Akagi K, Takamura Y;, Citation: Biosci Biotechnol Biochem. 2003;67:214-217.]
children.description: Malonate decarboxylase as found in Klebsiella pneumoniae is a multi-subunit water-soluble enzyme. In some species, such as Malonomonas rubra, soluble components are linked to membrane-bound enzymes and the system on the whole acts as a sodium pump. This property contains (as required steps) the subunits of the water-soluble enzyme and accessory proteins for biosynthesis and attachment of the 2'-(5''-phosphoribosyl)-3'-dephospho-CoA prosthetic group. The sodium pumping form can be recognized by the presence of a carboxybiotin decarboxylase subunit (step 1) in the operon.

children.name: Allantoin catabolism to glyoxalate and urea
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10601204, Title: Genetic analysis of a chromosomal region containing genes required for assimilation of allantoin nitrogen and linked glyoxylate metabolism in Escherichia coli., Authors: Cusa E, Obradors N, Baldomà L, Badía J, Aguilar J;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1999;181:7479-7484.]
children.description: (S)-allantoin ([(4S)-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-4-yl]urea) is a breakdown product of urate that may be obtained by an endogenous urate catabolism pathway or by transport from the environment. Catabolism of allantoate consists of a three-step pathway resulting in glyoxalate. This is further processed to tartronate semi-aldehyde (2-hydroxy-3-oxopropanoate) and subsequently to either phyosphoglycerate or glycoaldehyde (in the pathway to the pyridoxine component of vitamin B6). Since many pathways result in glyoxalate, this genome property terminates at that compound although the downsream enzymes may be grouped into apparent operons in many organisms (i.e. E. coli).Degradation of allantoin results in the production of two molecules of urea which may be excreted or used as a source of ammonia in urease-containing organisms.

children.name: Urate catabolism to allantoin
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16787778, Title: The crystal structure of the transthyretin-like protein from Salmonella dublin, a prokaryote 5-hydroxyisourate hydrolase., Authors: Hennebry SC, Law RH, Richardson SJ, Buckle AM, Whisstock JC;, Citation: J Mol Biol. 2006;359:1389-1399., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 15790071, Title: Identification, cloning and expression of Pseudomonas aeruginosa Ps-x putative urate oxidase gene in Escherichia coli., Authors: Saeed HM, Abdel-Fattah YR, Berekaa MM, Gohar YM, Elbaz MA;, Citation: Pol J Microbiol. 2004;53:227-236., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 16462750, Title: Completing the uric acid degradation pathway through phylogenetic comparison of whole genomes., Authors: Ramazzina I, Folli C, Secchi A, Berni R, Percudani R;, Citation: Nat Chem Biol. 2006;2:144-148.]
children.description: Urate is the product of xanthine catabolism by either the xanthine dehydrogenase complex or xanthine oxidase. The purine ring system of urate is oxidized by uricase (urate oxidase) and the 6-membered ring is opened by hydroxyisourate hydrolase. The hydrolase may be unnecessary in some organisms as the hydroxyisourate will hydrolyze spontaneously, albeit an a slow rate. The resulting product (OHCU) then spontaneously decarboxylates, resulting in a mixture of (S)- and (R)-allantoin. For further catabolism, generally only (S)-allantoin is processed, so allantoin racemace is also typically found. An OHCU carboxylase has been discovered in Mus musculus which does have homologs in prokaryotes.

children.name: Allantoin catabolism to oxamate and carbamoyl-phosphate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10601204, Title: Genetic analysis of a chromosomal region containing genes required for assimilation of allantoin nitrogen and linked glyoxylate metabolism in Escherichia coli., Authors: Cusa E, Obradors N, Baldomà L, Badía J, Aguilar J;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1999;181:7479-7484.]
children.description: Allantoin ([(4S)-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-4-yl]urea) is a breakdown product of urate and may be obtained by an endogenous urate catabolism pathway or by transport from the environment. This catabolism pathway avoids the production of urea (as in the pathway to glyoxalate -- GenProp0686) and instead produces ammonia by the action of allantoate amidohydrolase and the breakdown of carbamoyl-phosphate by carbamate kinase. A by-product of this pathway is oxamate (oxalic monoamide) which is presumably excreted.

children.name: Fructose utilization as fructose-1,6-bisphosphate

children.name: PTS transport system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 28168775, Title: Structural characterization of the PTS IIA and IIB proteins associated with pneumococcal fucose utilization., Authors: Higgins MA, Hamilton AM, Boraston AB;, Citation: Proteins. 2017;]
children.description: Phosphotransferase system (PTS) is a phosphorylation cascade that allows various carbohydrates to be transported accross a membrane at the expense of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP). First, a phosphoryl group is donated from PEP to a general (non sugar-specific) enzyme I (phosphotransferase system, enzyme I), and then on to a phosphocarrier protein (HPr). HPr then dontaes the phosphoryl group to the sugar-specific EIIA (enzyme IIA), and then on to EIIB (enzyme IIB), before being transferred to the incoming carbohydrate. The carbohydrate is transported by EIIC (enzyme IIC), and occasionally EIID (enzyme IID), which are sugar-specific transmembrane components [1].

children.name: Purine catabolism via urate, xanthine and allantoin
children.description: This property is an overview of the complete catabolic pathways leading from intracellular guanine, adenine or extracellular xanthine, through to the breakdown products of allantoin, oxamate or glyoxalate.

children.name: Xanthine catabolism to urate
children.description: The committed step in the catabolism of purines is the oxidation of the purine ring of xanthine (via hypoxanthine) to urate (uric acid). The xanthine may result from the deamination of guanine (or hypoxanthine from adenine), or may be imported via a permease. Several systems exist for the conversion of xanthine to urate including the XdhABC xanthine dehydrogenase complex, xanthine oxidase and other less well-described oxidoreductases.

children.name: Xanthine dehydrogenase
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16597619, Title: Rhodobacter capsulatus XdhC is involved in molybdenum cofactor binding and insertion into xanthine dehydrogenase., Authors: Neumann M, Schulte M, Jünemann N, Stöcklein W, Leimkühler S;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2006;281:15701-15708.]
children.description: Xanthine dehydrogenase is a molydbopterin-containing enzyme. It converts xanthine, from the purine pool, to urate, which is subsequently degraded. In bacteria, the enzyme usually is encoded as a small subunit, XdhA, that contains FAD and 2Fe2S cofactors and a large subunit, XdhB, that contains the molybdopterin cofactor. The accessory protein XdhC is usually but not always encoded next to the XdhAB gene pair.

children.name: Urate catabolism to allantoin
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16787778, Title: The crystal structure of the transthyretin-like protein from Salmonella dublin, a prokaryote 5-hydroxyisourate hydrolase., Authors: Hennebry SC, Law RH, Richardson SJ, Buckle AM, Whisstock JC;, Citation: J Mol Biol. 2006;359:1389-1399., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 15790071, Title: Identification, cloning and expression of Pseudomonas aeruginosa Ps-x putative urate oxidase gene in Escherichia coli., Authors: Saeed HM, Abdel-Fattah YR, Berekaa MM, Gohar YM, Elbaz MA;, Citation: Pol J Microbiol. 2004;53:227-236., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 16462750, Title: Completing the uric acid degradation pathway through phylogenetic comparison of whole genomes., Authors: Ramazzina I, Folli C, Secchi A, Berni R, Percudani R;, Citation: Nat Chem Biol. 2006;2:144-148.]
children.description: Urate is the product of xanthine catabolism by either the xanthine dehydrogenase complex or xanthine oxidase. The purine ring system of urate is oxidized by uricase (urate oxidase) and the 6-membered ring is opened by hydroxyisourate hydrolase. The hydrolase may be unnecessary in some organisms as the hydroxyisourate will hydrolyze spontaneously, albeit an a slow rate. The resulting product (OHCU) then spontaneously decarboxylates, resulting in a mixture of (S)- and (R)-allantoin. For further catabolism, generally only (S)-allantoin is processed, so allantoin racemace is also typically found. An OHCU carboxylase has been discovered in Mus musculus which does have homologs in prokaryotes.

children.name: Allantoin catabolism to oxamate and carbamoyl-phosphate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10601204, Title: Genetic analysis of a chromosomal region containing genes required for assimilation of allantoin nitrogen and linked glyoxylate metabolism in Escherichia coli., Authors: Cusa E, Obradors N, Baldomà L, Badía J, Aguilar J;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1999;181:7479-7484.]
children.description: Allantoin ([(4S)-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-4-yl]urea) is a breakdown product of urate and may be obtained by an endogenous urate catabolism pathway or by transport from the environment. This catabolism pathway avoids the production of urea (as in the pathway to glyoxalate -- GenProp0686) and instead produces ammonia by the action of allantoate amidohydrolase and the breakdown of carbamoyl-phosphate by carbamate kinase. A by-product of this pathway is oxamate (oxalic monoamide) which is presumably excreted.

children.name: Urate catabolism to allantoin
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16787778, Title: The crystal structure of the transthyretin-like protein from Salmonella dublin, a prokaryote 5-hydroxyisourate hydrolase., Authors: Hennebry SC, Law RH, Richardson SJ, Buckle AM, Whisstock JC;, Citation: J Mol Biol. 2006;359:1389-1399., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 15790071, Title: Identification, cloning and expression of Pseudomonas aeruginosa Ps-x putative urate oxidase gene in Escherichia coli., Authors: Saeed HM, Abdel-Fattah YR, Berekaa MM, Gohar YM, Elbaz MA;, Citation: Pol J Microbiol. 2004;53:227-236., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 16462750, Title: Completing the uric acid degradation pathway through phylogenetic comparison of whole genomes., Authors: Ramazzina I, Folli C, Secchi A, Berni R, Percudani R;, Citation: Nat Chem Biol. 2006;2:144-148.]
children.description: Urate is the product of xanthine catabolism by either the xanthine dehydrogenase complex or xanthine oxidase. The purine ring system of urate is oxidized by uricase (urate oxidase) and the 6-membered ring is opened by hydroxyisourate hydrolase. The hydrolase may be unnecessary in some organisms as the hydroxyisourate will hydrolyze spontaneously, albeit an a slow rate. The resulting product (OHCU) then spontaneously decarboxylates, resulting in a mixture of (S)- and (R)-allantoin. For further catabolism, generally only (S)-allantoin is processed, so allantoin racemace is also typically found. An OHCU carboxylase has been discovered in Mus musculus which does have homologs in prokaryotes.

children.name: Allantoin catabolism to glyoxalate and urea
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10601204, Title: Genetic analysis of a chromosomal region containing genes required for assimilation of allantoin nitrogen and linked glyoxylate metabolism in Escherichia coli., Authors: Cusa E, Obradors N, Baldomà L, Badía J, Aguilar J;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1999;181:7479-7484.]
children.description: (S)-allantoin ([(4S)-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-4-yl]urea) is a breakdown product of urate that may be obtained by an endogenous urate catabolism pathway or by transport from the environment. Catabolism of allantoate consists of a three-step pathway resulting in glyoxalate. This is further processed to tartronate semi-aldehyde (2-hydroxy-3-oxopropanoate) and subsequently to either phyosphoglycerate or glycoaldehyde (in the pathway to the pyridoxine component of vitamin B6). Since many pathways result in glyoxalate, this genome property terminates at that compound although the downsream enzymes may be grouped into apparent operons in many organisms (i.e. E. coli).Degradation of allantoin results in the production of two molecules of urea which may be excreted or used as a source of ammonia in urease-containing organisms.

children.name: Catechol meta-cleavage pathway
children.description: The metabolism of many aromatic compounds proceeds by way of catechol, a compound chemically similar to benzene except that a pair of adjacent H atoms of benzene are replaced by OH groups of catechol. This property describes the meta-cleavage pathway, in which catechol 2,3-dioxygenase cleaves the ring at the meta position. Degradation continues to pyruvate and acetyl-CoA. Some compounds degraded by way of catechol and this pathway, include benzoate, toluene, salicylate, phenol, napthalene, and 3,4-dimethylphenol (dmp).

children.name: Oxalate degradation
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16517636, Title: Transcriptional and functional analysis of oxalyl-coenzyme A (CoA) decarboxylase and formyl-CoA transferase genes from Lactobacillus acidophilus., Authors: Azcarate-Peril MA, Bruno-Bárcena JM, Hassan HM, Klaenhammer TR;, Citation: Appl Environ Microbiol. 2006;72:1891-1899., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12844490, Title: The crystal structure of the Escherichia coli YfdW gene product reveals a new fold of two interlaced rings identifying a wide family of CoA transferases., Authors: Gruez A, Roig-Zamboni V, Valencia C, Campanacci V, Cambillau C;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2003;278:34582-34586.]
children.description: A two-enzyme pathway degrades oxalate, a toxic metabolite. Formyl-CoA transferase transfers coenzyme A from formyl-CoA to oxalate, leaving formate. Oxalyl-CoA decarboxylase, a TPP-containing enzyme, removes C02 to regenerate formyl-CoA. The net result is conversion of oxalate to formate and CO2. This system was originally described in Oxalobacter formigenes from the human gut, and is found in a number of other gut bacteria.

children.name: Choline sulfate utilization
children.description: This property describes a gene pair for choline sulfate utilization. Choline is a precursor to the osmoprotectant glycine-betaine and to acetylcholine, and can be used as an energy source. One member of the gene pair is a choline-sulfatase, as in Sinorhizobium meliloti and Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1. The other gene is a periplasmic binding protein for the ABC transporters responsible for choline uptake. It appears that several different periplasmic binding proteins interact with the same permease and ATP-binding subunit.

children.name: Encapsulin proteinaceous organelle
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 22046962, Title: Self-assembling, protein-based intracellular bacterial organelles: emerging vehicles for encapsulating, targeting and delivering therapeutical cargoes., Authors: Corchero JL, Cedano J;, Citation: Microb Cell Fact. 2011;10:92.]
children.description: The protein previously called linocin M18 is now recognized as encapsulin, a self-assembling protein that associates with an enzyme (typically a peroxidase) and forms a proteinaceous organelle. Two quite different families, one a peroxidase, the other resembling ferritins, can be packaged by encapsulin and have a similar C-terminal motif, resembling DGSL[SGN]IGSL[KR], separated by a disordered region from their respective core homology regions.

children.name: Pyrimidine utilization
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16540542, Title: A previously undescribed pathway for pyrimidine catabolism., Authors: Loh KD, Gyaneshwar P, Markenscoff Papadimitriou E, Fong R, Kim KS, Parales R, Zhou Z, Inwood W, Kustu S;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2006;103:5114-5119.]
children.description: This seven-gene operon described in E. coli K-12 [1] is responsible for the degradation of uracil, and to a lesser extent, thymine. This has been determined by growth and mutation experiments. The operon contains a luciferase family member (RutA) which likely catalyzes the FMN-dependent critical oxidation for the ring opening as well as RutF which may be involved in recycling the FMN cofactor. Other seemingly essential components are an isochorismate mutase family protein (RutB), a hydrolase (RutD) and a member of the L-PSP endoribonuclease family (RutC) and a regulatory protein (RutR). The transporter RutG found in E. coli is not found in all genomes harboring the rest of the operon and may be replaced by other non-homologous transporters located elsewhere in the genomes. This property appears to be limited to the alpha and gamma proteobacteria.

children.name: Ethanolamine degradation organelle
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 1550360, Title: Overexpression, purification, and some properties of the AdoCbl-dependent ethanolamine ammonia-lyase from Salmonella typhimurium., Authors: Faust LP, Babior BM;, Citation: Arch Biochem Biophys. 1992;294:50-54., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 15466038, Title: Identification of a reactivating factor for adenosylcobalamin-dependent ethanolamine ammonia lyase., Authors: Mori K, Bando R, Hieda N, Toraya T;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2004;186:6845-6854., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 15516577, Title: Evidence that a B12-adenosyl transferase is encoded within the ethanolamine operon of Salmonella enterica., Authors: Sheppard DE, Penrod JT, Bobik T, Kofoid E, Roth JR;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2004;186:7635-7644., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 15466042, Title: A pH-sensitive function and phenotype: evidence that EutH facilitates diffusion of uncharged ethanolamine in Salmonella enterica., Authors: Penrod JT, Mace CC, Roth JR;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2004;186:6885-6890., Ref 5, Pubmed ID: 23585538, Title: Evidence that a metabolic microcompartment contains and recycles private cofactor pools., Authors: Huseby DL, Roth JR;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2013;195:2864-2879.]
children.description: Ethanolamine can be broken down to acetaldehyde by the action of ethanolamine ammonia lyase, an adenosyl cobalamin (vitamin B12) dependent enzyme. In its simplest form this system consists only of the two subunits of the enzyme, but ususally also includes a transporter for ethanolamine and may include a coexpressed acetaldehyde dehydrogenase to ensure that the toxic aldehyde is efficiently converted to acetyl-CoA. This property encompasses the more complex version of this system which includes additional genes coding for the proteinaceous coat of a specialized organelle as well as other genes for the efficienct maintenance and regulation of the lyase, handling of the product and import of the substrate. Presumably, this organellar system in organisms which may rely on ethanolamine as a primary carbon source.

children.name: Catechol ortho-cleavage upper pathway
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 18836712, Title: Induction of ortho- and meta-cleavage pathways in Pseudomonas in biodegradation of high benzoate concentration: MS identification of catabolic enzymes., Authors: Cao B, Geng A, Loh KC;, Citation: Appl Microbiol Biotechnol. 2008;81:99-107.]
children.description: Catechol is an intermediate in the degradation of a number of aromatic compounds, including benzoate. Cleavage of the catechol ring can occur either by the ortho- or the meta-cleavage pathways. This property describes the initial steps in the ortho-cleavage pathway. Catechol is cleaved between two ring hydroxyls by catechol 1,2-dioxygenase (catA) to produce cis,cis-muconate.cis,cis-muconate is then metabolised (via the three steps catB, catC and catD) to form 3-oxoadipate (the end-point of this upper part of the pathway)[1].

children.name: Proposed phosphonate catabolism pathway HpnWXZ
children.description: Phosphonatase (PhnX) is an enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of phosphonoacetaldehyde via a bicatalytic mechanism involving a specific enzyme lysine which forms a Shiff base with the aldehyde, and a magnesium-aspartate (HAD-type) nucleophile to cleave the phosphonate carbon-phosphorous bond. The PhnW enzyme provides the substrate for this reaction. HpnX (closely related to PhnX) shares a significant degree of similarity at critical catalytic sites suggesting that it also acts as a phosphonatase on a beta-phosphonoaldehyde. HpnX genes are often found in the vicinity of a family of FAD-dependent oxidoreductases (HpnW). These genes may act in an analagous fashion to PhnW by converting an aminophosphonate into an aldehyde, here by oxidative deamination. HpnW genes are members of a larger family of genes including enzymes with amino acid deaminating oxidase activities. These genes (HpnX and HpnW) are often associated with a family of Zn++ dependent alcohol dehydrogenases. Other genes in the vicinity indicate a phosphonate-related context and are typically observed near other phosphonate catabolic pathways such as genes of the HDIG domain family, certain GntR-type transcriptional regulators and phosphonate-related transporters.

children.name: Storage polymer systems
children.description: These polymers of various monomer units are used as storage for energy, carbon and/or nitrogen. Sometimes these polymers are observed as granular inclusions within the cell. These systems may include enzymes for the biosynthesis and degradation of the polymer, regulatory components as well as proteins associated with the granule surface.

children.name: Polyhydroxyalkanoic acids
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 23702844, Title: The role of short-chain conjugated poly-(R)-3-hydroxybutyrate (cPHB) in protein folding., Authors: Reusch RN;, Citation: Int J Mol Sci. 2013;14(6):10727-10748.]
children.description: Polyhydroxyalkanoic acids (PHAs) are high molecular weight carbon and energy storage molecules. They exist as linear polymers in which the monomeric units have the form -[O-CHR(CH2)xCO]-. The aliphatic polyesters occur in inclusion bodies in various bacteria and archaea. The most common form is polyhydroxybutyric acid, -[0-CHCH3-CH2-CO]-. Typical biosynthetic enzymes include ketothiolases, reductases, and PHA synthases. Additional proteins may include small PHA inclusion body-associated proteins. Typical gene symbols include pha (phb for polyhydroxybutyrate) A (ketothiolase), B (reductase), C (synthase), Z (depolymerase), E (second subunit of heterodimeric-type PHA synthase), R, and Q. It has been reported that all prokaryotes and eukaryotes synthesize PHB of medium-chain length (~100–200 residues) thats is found in lipid bilayers and vesicles, and PHB of short-chain length (<12 residues) which is conjugated to proteins in membranes and organelles [1]. However, this property refers to very high molecular weight (10,000 to >1,000,000 residues) PHAs in granular deposits.

children.name: Cyanophycin-like storage polymers
children.description: Cyanophycin is a characteristically Cyanobacterial storage polymer for nitrogen, carbon, and energy. It is made by cyanophycin synthetase and degraded by cyanophycinase. Cyanophycinase is also found in an extracellular form by some species that can utilize exogenous cyanophycin. The polymer has a backbone of L-aspartic acid residues (Asp), with the side chain COOH linked to the NH2 of arginine (Arg) residues. The native cyanobacterial form is insoluble, while heterogenously expressed cyanophycin synthetases in E. coli may produce a soluble form with some level of Lys substituting for Arg.This polymer is analogous to polyhydroxyalkanoic acid biosynthesis systems with which it sometimes co-occurs.

children.name: Glycogen system
children.description: Glycogen and starch are related glucose storage polysaccharides. Alpha 1,4 glucan linkages predominate, with some branching using alpha 1,6 linkages. The relative level of branching determines whether the substance is called glycogen or starch. In bacteria and plants, the precursor is ADP-glucose. In animals, the precursor isUDP-glucose. Different forms of glycogen synthase are used for the two. This property includes the enzyme phosphorylase (glycogen phosphorylase or starch phosphorylase, depending on context) necessary to release glucose-1-phosphate from the polysaccharide.

children.name: Polyphosphate kinase/exopolyphosphatase system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15520374, Title: Inorganic polyphosphate in the origin and survival of species., Authors: Brown MR, Kornberg A;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2004;101:16085-16087.]
children.description: This property describes systems for polyphosphate metabolism, featuring a polyphosphate kinase (PPK1) and an exopolyphosphatase that often are encoded by adjacent genes. Polyphosphate can provide functions of phosphate and energy storage, and may form granules. Genes from this system are often found next to genes of the inorganic phosphate transport system. Performing comparative genomics for this system is tricky in part because of numbers of numerous apparent bifunctional proteins, exopolyphosphatase/guanosine pentaphosphate phosphohydrolase. Proteins of the polyphosphate kinase 2 (PPK2) family are largely restricted to species with PPK1 and help produce GTP from GDP and polyphosphate.

children.name: Coenzyme F420 utilization
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11726492, Title: Structures of F420H2:NADP+ oxidoreductase with and without its substrates bound., Authors: Warkentin E, Mamat B, Sordel-Klippert M, Wicke M, Thauer RK, Iwata M, Iwata S, Ermler U, Shima S;, Citation: EMBO J. 2001;20:6561-6569.]
children.description: Coenzyme F420 (a 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy 5-deazaflavin) is found in methanogenic archaea, the Mycobacteria, and some other species[1]. Forms differ in the number of glutamyl residues attached. The chromophore by itself, FO, often can replace intact F420, so the literature will occasionally describe an enzyme dependent on FO. This does not necessarily mean the FO is not typically part of coenzyme F420 in vivo. However, it appears that only FO, and not F420, occurs in the Cyanobacteria. This property describes the presence of enzymes that use F420 as an electron donor or receptor, as opposed to enzymes of its biosynthesis.

children.name: Coenzyme F420 biosynthesis
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 18260642, Title: Identification and characterization of the 2-phospho-L-lactate guanylyltransferase involved in coenzyme F420 biosynthesis., Authors: Grochowski LL, Xu H, White RH;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2008;47:3033-3037., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12911320, Title: CofE catalyzes the addition of two glutamates to F420-0 in F420 coenzyme biosynthesis in Methanococcus jannaschii., Authors: Li H, Graupner M, Xu H, White RH;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2003;42:9771-9778., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 11717263, Title: Use of transposon Tn5367 mutagenesis and a nitroimidazopyran-based selection system to demonstrate a requirement for fbiA and fbiB in coenzyme F(420) biosynthesis by Mycobacterium bovis BCG., Authors: Choi KP, Bair TB, Bae YM, Daniels L;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2001;183:7058-7066., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 11888293, Title: Characterization of the 2-phospho-L-lactate transferase enzyme involved in coenzyme F(420) biosynthesis in Methanococcus jannaschii., Authors: Graupner M, Xu H, White RH;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2002;41:3754-3761.]
children.description: Coenzyme F420 is a hydride carrier cofactor functioning in methanogenesis [1]. The chromophore of coenzyme F420 is 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy-5-deazaflavin (otherwise known as FO), which is also used in a cyanobacterial DNA photoreactivating enzyme. Modification of FO to create coenzyme F420 includes the GTP-dependent addition of two glutamate residues in Methanococcus jannaschii [2] and five or six in Mycobacterium bovis [3]. CofF, which caps the gamma-glutamyl tail after two glutamates, occurs only the archaea.

children.name: 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy-5-deazariboflavin (FO) biosynthesis
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 2110564, Title: DNA photoreactivating enzyme from the cyanobacterium Anacystis nidulans., Authors: Eker AP, Kooiman P, Hessels JK, Yasui A;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1990;265:8009-8015., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 14593448, Title: Identification of the 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy-5-deazariboflavin synthase required for coenzyme F(420) biosynthesis., Authors: Graham DE, Xu H, White RH;, Citation: Arch Microbiol. 2003;180:455-464., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 11948155, Title: Demonstration that fbiC is required by Mycobacterium bovis BCG for coenzyme F(420) and FO biosynthesis., Authors: Choi KP, Kendrick N, Daniels L;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2002;184:2420-2428.]
children.description: 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy-5-deazariboflavin, or FO, is the chromophore of coenzyme F420. Several enzymatic steps convert FO to F420 (see GenProp0791). FO is also the chromophore of a cyanobacterial DNA photoreactivating enzyme [1]. The two key enzymes of this pathway, encoded by CofG and CofH in Methanocaldococcus jannaschii, are encoded by fusion proteins in certain lineages. The fusion protein in Mycobacterium smegmatis is designated FbiC (F420 BIosynthesis C). The precursors are a pyrimidine intermediate from riboflavin biosynthesis and the 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate precursor of tyrosine, so expressing FbiC in Escherichia coli is sufficient for FO biosynthesis [2].

children.name: Hydrogenase, nickel and F420-dependent
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 2207102, Title: Cloning, sequence determination, and expression of the genes encoding the subunits of the nickel-containing 8-hydroxy-5-deazaflavin reducing hydrogenase from Methanobacterium thermoautotrophicum delta H., Authors: Alex LA, Reeve JN, Orme-Johnson WH, Walsh CT;, Citation: Biochemistry. 1990;29:7237-7244.]
children.description: This nickel hydrogenase reduces coenzyme F420 (8-hydroxy-5-deazaflavin) and is found exclusively, but not universally, in methanogenic archaea. It is lacking in at least four Methanosarcinales. F420 reducing hydrogenase (FRH) is composed of three subuints, aplpha, beta and gamma, which are encoded by the genes frhA, frhB, and frhG respectively. A forth gene in the same cluster, frhD, encodes a delta subunit, which is not part of the active FRH heterotrimer, but may be required for maturation [1].

children.name: Lipoprotein system lgt/lsp/lnt
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 8051048, Title: Lipid modification of bacterial prolipoprotein. Transfer of diacylglyceryl moiety from phosphatidylglycerol., Authors: Sankaran K, Wu HC;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1994;269(31):19701-6.]
children.description: Some membrane proteins are anchored to the membrane by a lipid moiety attached to a modified N-terminus rather than by a transmembrane helix. This property describes such a system. The system starts with the modification of the Cys sulfhydryl of the conserved lipobox motif L-X-G/A-C by prolipoprotein diacylglyceryl transferase (Lgt). Prolipoprotein signal peptidase (Lsp) then cleaves the lipoprotein signal sequence leaving Cys as the new N-terminal residue. Finally the Cys NH2 is acylated by apolipoprotein N-acyltransferase (Lnt) [1].

children.description: The twin-arginine dependent translocation (Tat) system of protein transport differs from Sec-dependent translocation in that the Tat system transports folded proteins while Sec feeds through unfolded, nascent proteins that fold after they cross the membrane. The significance is that Tat lets cofactors such as flavins or iron-sulfur clusters be retained during transit across the membrane. Targets for the system can often be recognized by a characteristic signal sequence with an Arg-Arg motif. The target proteins usually are predicted to perform redox functions [1]. This property reflects detection of the whole system: components of the translocase and at least one example of a predicted Tat signal sequence. Every system must have at least one TatA homolog (other than TatB) and at least one TatC homolog. TatB occurs only in Proteobacteria and is required at least in E. coli. Recently, several proteins (TorD, NapD) have been shown to act as chaperones that bind the TAT signal peptide of a specific protein and delay translocation until the cofactor has bound [2].

children.name: Gamma secretase
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 28320827, Title: Structural and Chemical Biology of Presenilin Complexes., Authors: Johnson DS, Li YM, Pettersson M, St George-Hyslop PH;, Citation: Cold Spring Harb Perspect Med. 2017; [Epub ahead of print]]
children.description: Gamma secretase is a complex found in cell membranes and initially identified as the peptidase responsible for the gamma, varepsilon and zeta cleavages of the transmembrane domains of Type I membrane proteins including amyloid precursor protein (APP) and Notch.Release of the amyloid beta (A-beta) peptide from APP is an important step in the development of Alzheimer's disease and forms the plaques that are characteristic of the pathology.Release of the A-beta peptide requires two proteolytic cleavages, cleavage by beta-secretase in the extracellular domain, and then cleavage at the gamma and epsilon sites by gamma secretase.The proteolytic component of gamma secretase is presenilin which is an aspartic endopeptidase [1].

children.name: Apoptosome
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 14499155, Title: Apoptosis: the complex scenario for a silent cell death., Authors: Bohm I, Schild H;, Citation: Mol Imaging Biol. 2003;5:2-14., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 21456965, Title: Caspase substrates and cellular remodeling., Authors: Crawford ED; Wells JA;, Citation: Annu Rev Biochem. 2001;80:1055-1087., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 26543158, Title: Atomic structure of the apoptosome: mechanism of cytochrome c- and dATP-mediated activation of Apaf-1., Authors: Zhou M; Li Y; Hu Q; Bai XC; Huang W; Yan C; Scheres SH; Shi Y;, Citation: Genes Dev. 2015;29:2349-2361.]
children.description: Apoptosis or programmed cell death is the mechanism by which cells in eukaryotes are killed. Cysteine endopeptidases known as caspases are activated and these deactivate cellular proteins, often by cleaving within interdomain regions, thereby separating binding domains of signal reception and transduction domains [1]. Caspases have a specificity for aspartyl bonds, which occur frequently in surface loops and interdomain regions of proteins [2]. Caspases involved in apoptosis are of two kinds: initiators and executors. Initiator caspases activate the executor caspases which cleave other proteins in the cell. There are at least four routes by which the initiator caspase precursors are activated. This Genome Property includes the apoptosome, which includes the precursor of initiator caspase 9 from the intrinsic (or mitochondrial) pathway [3]. When it binds cytochrome c and dATP, Apaf1 oligomerizes into a heptameric ring.

children.name: Selenium-dependent molybdenum hydroxylase system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10860985, Title: Selenium-dependent metabolism of purines: A selenium-dependent purine hydroxylase and xanthine dehydrogenase were purified from Clostridium purinolyticum and characterized., Authors: Self WT, Stadtman TC;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2000;97:7208-7213., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 14503889, Title: Cofactor determination and spectroscopic characterization of the selenium-dependent purine hydroxylase from Clostridium purinolyticum., Authors: Self WT, Wolfe MD, Stadtman TC;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2003;42:11382-11390., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 10430865, Title: Crystal structure and mechanism of CO dehydrogenase, a molybdo iron-sulfur flavoprotein containing S-selanylcysteine., Authors: Dobbek H, Gremer L, Meyer O, Huber R;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 1999;96:8884-8889., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 21257770, Title: A selenium-dependent xanthine dehydrogenase triggers biofilm proliferation in Enterococcus faecalis through oxidant production., Authors: Srivastava M, Mallard C, Barke T, Hancock LE, Self WT;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2011;193:1643-1652.]
children.description: The enzyme selenide, water dikinase (SelD) activates selenium for use in bacteria as selenocysteine to be incorporated during protein translation, or as the modified base selenouridine in certain tRNAs. However, SelD occurs in some genomes with neither of those traits, and instead acts in the post-translational addition of a labile selenium to a molybdenum-containing cofactor. A bioinformatic analysis showed that the family of TIGRFAMs model TIGR03309 represents a third selenium-dependent bacterial trait, and that it is quite widespread. The current version of this Genome Property includes both selenium cofactor maturation proteins and subunits of predicted labile selenium cofactor enzymes.

children.name: Tryptophan tryptophylquinone modification of methylamine dehydrogenase
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 19196017, Title: Kinetic mechanism for the initial steps in MauG-dependent tryptophan tryptophylquinone biosynthesis., Authors: Lee S, Shin S, Li X, Davidson VL;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2009;48:2442-2447., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 22314272, Title: Tryptophan tryptophylquinone biosynthesis: a radical approach to posttranslational modification., Authors: Davidson VL, Liu A;, Citation: Biochim Biophys Acta. 2012;1824:1299-1305.]
children.description: The maturation enzyme MauG completes the modification and cross-linking of a pair of Trp residues into the novel cofactor tryptophan tryptophylquinone (TTQ) in the light chain (MauA) of methylamine dehydrogenase. While some analogous enzyme cofactors are produced autocatalytically from amino acids in the precursor polypeptide, TTQ is produced with aid of the maturation enzyme MauG. MauG is a di-heme enzyme with peroxidase activity, similar to di-heme cytochrome c peroxidases of other biological systems. Interestingly, the pair of modified Trp residues are conserved in MauA homologs in species that have no MauG homolog in the vicinity, suggesting no modification, autocatalytic modification, or a different modification enzyme.

children.description: Mycothiol is a glutathione analog common in the Actinobacteria, but not found elsewhere. This Genome Property provides a higher-level view of mycothiol metabolism that includes its synthesis, the regeneration of mycothiol from mycothione (its disulfide-bonded dimer) by NADPH-dependent reduction, and a guild of mycothiol-dependent enzymes, the discovery of which is incomplete.

children.name: Mycothiol biosynthesis

children.description: Mycothiol is a thiol, a glutathione analog, found in Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Corynebacterium glutamicum, Streptomyces coelicolor, and related species. Four genes associated with its biosynthesis, designated mshA, mshB, mshC, and mshD, are scattered in the M. tuberculosis genome rather than arranged as an operon. A fifth reaction associated with this biosynthesis, a phosphatase designated MsaA2, has been described but not yet assigned to a specific protein. Genomes with this biosynthesis system will have other proteins that make use of mycothiol.

children.name: Mitochondrial protein processing
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11470436, Title: Crystal structures of mitochondrial processing peptidase reveal the mode for specific cleavage of import signal sequences., Authors: Taylor AB; Smith BS; Kitada S; Kojima K; Miyaura H; Otwinowski Z; Ito A; Deisenhofer J;, Citation: Structure 2001;9:615-625., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 8035833, Title: MIP1, a new yeast gene homologous to the rat mitochondrial intermediate peptidase gene, is required for oxidative metabolism in Saccharomyces cerevisiae., Authors: Isaya G; Miklos D; Rollins RA;, Citation: Mol Cell Biol. 1994;14:5603-5616.]
children.description: Mitocondrial processing peptidase (MPP) removes the first, N-terminal targeting sequence from nuclear-encoded proteins that are destined for import into the mitochondrion. MPP is a heterodimer of two homologous subunits, MMPalpha and MPPbeta. Only the beta subunit has peptidase activity [1]. The initial targeting signal may be followed by a second signal that targets a protein to the mitochondrial matrix or inner membrane. This second signal is removed by mitochondrial intermediate peptidase [2].

children.name: Mitochondrial-processing peptidase subunit beta

children.name: Mitochondrial inner membrane peptidase complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 8132591, Title: Purified inner membrane protease I of yeast mitochondria is a heterodimer., Authors: Schneider A; Oppliger W; Jenö P;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1994 Mar 25;269(12):8635-8638., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 8879245, Title: SOM 1, a small new gene required for mitochondrial inner membrane peptidase function in Saccharomyces cerevisiae., Authors: Esser K; Pratje E; Michaelis G;, Citation: Mol Gen Genet. 1996;252:437-445.]
children.description: The mitochondrial inner membrane peptidase (MIP) complex removes the N-terminal signal peptide from proteins that are synthesized in the mitochondrial matrix but destined for the inter-membrane space. There are two subunits that have proteolytic activity, IMP1 and IMP2 [1]. SOM1 is required for correct processing of cytochrome oxidase subunit 2 and cytochrome b2 [2].

children.name: COP9 Signalosome, eukaryote
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 26456823, Title: CSNAP Is a Stoichiometric Subunit of the COP9 Signalosome., Authors: Rozen S; Füzesi-Levi MG; Ben-Nissan G; Mizrachi L; Gabashvili A; Levin Y; Ben-Dor S; Eisenstein M; Sharon M;, Citation: Cell Rep. 2015;13:585-598., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12183637, Title: Role of predicted metalloprotease motif of Jab1/Csn5 in cleavage of Nedd8 from Cul1., Authors: Cope GA; Suh GS; Aravind L; Schwarz SE; Zipursky SL; Koonin EV; Deshaies RJ;, Citation: Science 2002;298:608-611.]
children.description: The COP9 signalosome (CSN) consists of COPS1/GPS1, COPS2, COPS3, COPS4, COPS5, COPS6, COPS7 (COPS7A or COPS7B), COPS8 and COPS9 isoform 1 [1]. CSN subunit 5 is a metallo-isopeptidase that releases the ubiquitin-like protein Nedd8 from the Cul1 subunit of SCF ubiquitin ligases [2].

children.name: Type III secretion
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11018143, Title: Assembly and function of type III secretory systems., Authors: Cornelis GR, Van Gijsegem F;, Citation: Annu Rev Microbiol. 2000;54:735-774., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 15629935, Title: The Erwinia chrysanthemi type III secretion system is required for multicellular behavior., Authors: Yap MN, Yang CH, Barak JD, Jahn CE, Charkowski AO;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2005;187:639-648., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 15808742, Title: Bioinformatics, genomics and evolution of non-flagellar type-III secretion systems: a Darwinian perspective., Authors: Pallen MJ, Beatson SA, Bailey CM;, Citation: FEMS Microbiol Rev. 2005;29:201-229.]
children.description: Type III secretion systems are found in a number of pathogenenic gram-negative bacteria. These systems consist of approximately twenty-five translocation proteins, as well as those proteins that are transported either across the bacterial inner and outer membrane, into the medium, or further across a eukaryotic target cell membrane. Substrates for type III secretion are not cleaved during transport, although the signal for transport appears to lie near the N-terminus (or in the RNA); chaperones act as well for some substrates and may be a second signal. Proteins delivered to the target cell cytosol and active in pathogenesis are termed effectors. Type III secretion systems resemble some of the flagellar export apparatus. In some cases, a type III pilus is observed and required for effector delivery. Gene nomeclature transposes across genomes: ysc in Yersinia, bsc in Bordetella, esc in enteropathogenic E. coli, hrc in plant pathogens, etc., so that YscD, EscD, HrcD, etc. are homologous and functionally analogous [1,2,3].

children.name: Type II secretion
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11309111, Title: Biology of type II secretion., Authors: Sandkvist M;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2001;40:271-283., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 11726509, Title: Involvement of the twin-arginine translocation system in protein secretion via the type II pathway., Authors: Voulhoux R, Ball G, Ize B, Vasil ML, Lazdunski A, Wu LF, Filloux A;, Citation: EMBO J. 2001;20(23):6735-6741.]
children.description: Type II secretion is also known as the main terminal branch of the general secretion pathway. Type II secretion systems transport folded proteins across the outer membrane. These proteins have previously come unfolded across the inner membrane by the general secretory pathway (Sec) and are then fully folded in the periplasm [1]. It has been reported that some proteins may cross the inner membrane by Tat (Sec-independent) protein export rather than by Sec prior to type II secretion [2].

children.name: Type I secretion
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11157948, Title: Subset of hybrid eukaryotic proteins is exported by the type I secretion system of Erwinia chrysanthemi., Authors: Palacios JL, Zaror I, Martínez P, Uribe F, Opazo P, Socías T, Gidekel M, Venegas A., Citation: J Bacteriol. 2001;183(4):1346-1358.]
children.description: A type I protein secretion system is an ABC (ATP-binding cassette) transporter. The system is Sec-independent. ATP drives the transport of target proteins across both inner and outer membranes and into the extracellular medium. There is no cleaved N-terminal signal sequence. Instead, the type I system recognizes C-terminal information, localized to the last 50 amino acids or less. Characteristic sequence found nearby, such as repeats of the motif GGXGXDXXX in Erwinia, may play a supporting role, possibly for chaperoning the rest of the protein rather than for recognition of the export signal [1].This property does NOT cover ABC transporter-mediated processing and secretion of class II bacteriocins of certain Gram-positive bacteria.

children.name: Tat (Sec-independent) protein export
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12562823, Title: Prokaryotic utilization of the twin-arginine translocation pathway: a genomic survey., Authors: Dilks K, Rose RW, Hartmann E, Pohlschröder M;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2003;185:1478-1483., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 17901208, Title: Structural diversity in twin-arginine signal peptide-binding proteins., Authors: Maillard J, Spronk CA, Buchanan G, Lyall V, Richardson DJ, Palmer T, Vuister GW, Sargent F;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2007;104:15641-15646.]
children.description: The twin-arginine dependent translocation (Tat) system of protein transport differs from Sec-dependent translocation in that the Tat system transports folded proteins while Sec feeds through unfolded, nascent proteins that fold after they cross the membrane. The significance is that Tat lets cofactors such as flavins or iron-sulfur clusters be retained during transit across the membrane. Targets for the system can often be recognized by a characteristic signal sequence with an Arg-Arg motif. The target proteins usually are predicted to perform redox functions [1]. This property reflects detection of the whole system: components of the translocase and at least one example of a predicted Tat signal sequence. Every system must have at least one TatA homolog (other than TatB) and at least one TatC homolog. TatB occurs only in Proteobacteria and is required at least in E. coli. Recently, several proteins (TorD, NapD) have been shown to act as chaperones that bind the TAT signal peptide of a specific protein and delay translocation until the cofactor has bound [2].

children.name: Lipoprotein localization system lolABCDE
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10783239, Title: A new ABC transporter mediating the detachment of lipid-modified proteins from membranes., Authors: Yakushi T, Masuda K, Narita S, Matsuyama S, Tokuda H;, Citation: Nat Cell Biol. 2000;2:212-218., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12823819, Title: A mutation in the membrane subunit of an ABC transporter LolCDE complex causing outer membrane localization of lipoproteins against their inner membrane-specific signals., Authors: Narita S, Kanamaru K, Matsuyama S, Tokuda H;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2003;49:167-177., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 11673422, Title: Deletion of lolB, encoding an outer membrane lipoprotein, is lethal for Escherichia coli and causes accumulation of lipoprotein localization intermediates in the periplasm., Authors: Tanaka K, Matsuyama SI, Tokuda H;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2001;183:6538-6542.]
children.description: Bacterial lipoproteins have a modified amino terminal Cys residue with a covalently attached lipid moiety that serves as a membrane anchor. The lol system is responsible for moving lipoproteins from the periplasmic side of the inner membrane to the periplasmic side of the outer membrane. LolD is homologous to the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transport family [1,2]. LolC and LolE are homologous to each other (in species that have both rather than just one) and have several membrane-spanning segments, much like ABC transport permeases[3]. However, the LolCDE complex differs from other ABC transporters in that is does not move a substrate across a membrane. Instead, it detaches lipoproteins from the inner membrane. LolA and LolB act to chaperone lipoproteins, including LolB itself, to the outer membrane. This system is less broadly distributed than the lgt/lsp/lnt system for lipoprotein N-terminal modification.

children.name: Sec system preprotein translocase
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 22411975, Title: The bacterial Sec-translocase: structure and mechanism., Authors: Lycklama A Nijeholt JA, Driessen AJ;, Citation: Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci. 2012;367:1016-1028.]
children.description: This property describes the bacterial preprotein translocase Sec[1]. The analogous process occurs in eukaryotes and archaea (little studied in the archaea), but the component proteins are different enough not to be described by the same set of hidden Markov models. SecB is a cytosolic export-specific chaperone in E. coli and some related species, but is not broadly distributed. SecA, the ATPase that powers the translocase, is a peripheral membrane protein. SecY, SecE, and SecG form the heterotrimeric translocase, although SecG is not essential at some temperatures. SecD, SecG, and YajC form an accessory complex that may prevent backsliding of proteins being translocated, and may not be essential proteins.

children.name: Protein sorting system, PEP-CTERM/exosortase (generic)
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16930487, Title: Exopolysaccharide-associated protein sorting in environmental organisms: the PEP-CTERM/EpsH system. Application of a novel phylogenetic profiling heuristic., Authors: Haft DH, Paulsen IT, Ward N, Selengut JD;, Citation: BMC Biol. 2006;4:29.]
children.description: This Genome Property describes a proposed protein sorting system associated with exopolysaccharide loci in many Gram-negative bacteria. One hallmark is the presence of a paralogous domain at the C-termini of a substantial number of proteins in a single genome, usually from four to sixty-five. Features of this domain, described by TIGRFAMs model TIGR02595, are a conserved motif PEP, a transmembrane domain, and a cluster of basic residues for a total length of about 24 amino acids. Wecall this domain PEP-CTERM, and note that is shares a number of properties with the the LPXTG-type Gram-positive cell-wall targeting sequence. Another hallmark of this system is the presence of one or more homologs of EpsH (TIGR02602), a highly hydrophobic protein that spans the membrane eight or more times. Its surrounding genes nearly always pertain to exopolysaccharide biosynthesis. We have proposed that TIGR02602 models a transpeptidase that cleaves PEP-CTERM proteins, attaches them transiently to an active site Cys, then attaches them covalently to an unknown substrate for sorting to the outer surface of the cell, closely analogous to the action of sortase in Gram-positive bacteria. We suggest the name exosortase for EpsH homologs involved in this process. In Proteobacterial species with a the PEP-CTERM/exsortase system, a sensor histidine kinase (TIGR02916) and a sigma-54-dependent DNA-binding response regulator (TIGR02915) are present and appear to bind a conserved regulatory site found upstream of most PEP-CTERM genes.

children.name: Protein sorting system, sortase type, LPXTG/SrtA class
children.description: This property describes the common subtype of the sortase system for targeting cell wall proteins in the Firmicutes by recognition of the LPXTG C-terminal motif. The presence of one or more sortases and their target sequences should be universal in Gram-positive organisms with cell walls. Sortase is a transpeptidase; sortases belonging to this Genome Property resemble SrtA, and the sorting signal generally resembles LPXTG. Several SrtA paralogs can be found in some genomes, as well as the substantially different SrtB and other families of sortase and their cognate sequences.

children.description: This is a family of sortases and their substrates, less abundant than the housekeeping sortase, SrtA, and the LPXTG-like target sequences [1]. SrtB in Listeria monocytogenes appears to process two classes of signal, NXZTN and NPKXZ [2]. Note that the protein called SrtB in Streptococcus pyogenes [3] is a member of the SrtA family, not the family described here, while the protein called SrtC2 is a member of the SrtB family [4].

children.name: Protein sorting system, putative, exosortase G class
children.description: For several non-pathogenic Gram-positive bacteria, a protein family showing considerable sequence similarity to the proposed exosortases of Gram-negative bacteria occurs in a conserved gene neighborhood. This property describes that neighborhood, which also includes a glycosyltransferase and a domain related to 6-pyruvoyl tetrahydropterin synthases. These regions also include a family of proteins in the which the well-conserved C-terminal region (TIGR04145) resembles PEP-CTERM and LPXTG protein C-terminal regions. This last family may be the protein-sorting target.

children.description: The protein secretion system now called type VI (T6SS) has been described by Pukatzki, et al. [1], Mougous. et al. [2] and others. Two components of the system resemble components of type IV secretion systems (T4SS). Many species that carry this system have known pathogenic activity, but T6SS may be directed against other bacteria rather than eukaryotic cells. In addition to protein families for this system identified in various publications, several were identified by the partial phylogenetic programming algorithm [3], supported by proximity to other type VI secretion genes.

children.name: OMP chaperone system: SurA-Skp-DegP
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 17908933, Title: Defining the roles of the periplasmic chaperones SurA, Skp, and DegP in Escherichia coli., Authors: Sklar JG, Wu T, Kahne D, Silhavy TJ;, Citation: Genes Dev. 2007;21:2473-2484.]
children.description: Outer membrane beta-barrel proteins are translocated into the periplasm by the Sec system and subsequently properly folded and inserted into the outer membrane by the beta-barrel assembly machine (Bam). In the periplasm, chaperones prevent misfolding and aggregation, and facilitate the transit across the periplasmic space. The SurA protein appears to be the primary chaperone, at least in E. coli [1], while Skp and DegP may act to rescue any OMPs which fall off of the SurA complex.

children.name: Protein sorting system, GlyGly-CTERM/rhombosortase
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 22194940, Title: GlyGly-CTERM and rhombosortase: a C-terminal protein processing signal in a many-to-one pairing with a rhomboid family intramembrane serine protease., Authors: Haft DH, Varghese N;, Citation: PLoS One. 2011;6:e28886., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 21385872, Title: Proteomic analysis of the Vibrio cholerae type II secretome reveals new proteins, including three related serine proteases., Authors: Sikora AE, Zielke RA, Lawrence DA, Andrews PC, Sandkvist M;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2011;286:16555-16566.]
children.description: The GlyGly-CTERM domain, previously called the gammaproteobacterial enzyme C-terminal transmembrane domain or rhombotail, appears to be a protein sorting signal analogous to LPXTG and PEP-CTERM. Every genome that encodes a set of GlyGly-CTERM proteins also encodes a rhomboid family enzyme, designated rhombosortase, in a many-to-one relationship. Rhomboid proteases are serine proteases with the active site Ser within the membrane, and they are capable of cleaving hydrophobic transmembrane segments. In general, genomes that encode GlyGly-CTERM proteins and rhombosortase also encode a type 2 secretion system (T2SS). Several GlyGly-CTERM proteins have been shown to undergo T2SS-mediated secretion.

children.name: Protein sorting system, KxYKxGKxW class
children.description: Analogous to YSIRK, this property describes a subclass of N-terminal signal sequence in Firmicutes (low-GC Gram-positive bacteria). As with YSIRK, many proteins with this N-terminal domain have an LPXTG C-terminal anchor. However, most of these proteins have extended regions of low-complexity sequence, usually serine-rich. We propose that this signal domain is recognized by cellular machinery that delays protein translocation until glycosylation or other post-translational modifications are complete.

children.name: Protein sorting system, proteobacterial dedicated sortase type
children.description: This property represents a specialization of SrtA-like sortase systems in the Proteobacteria, including many marine species. In contrast to sortase A systems in the Firmicutes, where a single transpeptidase serves multiple target proteins, this system is characterized by a single sorting target protein, conserved across species, adjacent to the sorting enzyme itself. In a majority of species with this system, the sortase and target pair are accompanied by a histidine kinase and response regulator pair.

children.name: Type VII secretion, Actinobacteria form

children.description: Type VII secretion (T7S) (also called ESAT-6-, SNM-, or ESX-secretion) occurs in Mycobacterium. Mycobacterium has an impermeable cell envelope that contains long-chain mycolic acids in an outer membrane; T7S provides a means to transport proteins through this barrier. Multiple T7S loci can occur in one species, with different secretion targets for different systems. The system includes a subtilisin-like protease called mycosin and membrane proteins with a new nomenclature starting with ecc (esx conserved component).

children.description: This system occurs in the lineage Bacteriodetes, and contains a homolog to exosortase (EpsH). Like archaeal homologs, it is shorter by about 70 amino acids towards the N terminus, and it lacks an EpsI-like domain. Species with this system lack a classical PEP-CTERM, PEF-CTERM, or PGF-CTERM-like protein sorting C-terminal domain.

Target proteins tend to be repetitive and most show extensive mutual sequence homology. The first identified species with this system are Methanohalophilus mahii DSM 5219 and Methanohalobium evestigatum Z-7303.

children.description: This Genome Property describes a uniquely cyanobacterial subclass of the PEP-CTERM/exosortase system, restricted to but found in nearly every cyanobacterium outside of Prochlorococcus. The PEP-CTERM variant is somewhat longer at its C terminus, with much stronger conservation throughout the transmembrane region. At least one of two forms of cyanobacterial-restricted exosortase (cyanosortase) always occurs as well, occasionally adjacent to a PEP-CTERM protein.

children.description: This protein-sorting system occurs so far only in the alpha Proteobacteria. The system is largely dedicated, in the sense that the presumed substrate is usually one-per-genome and usually adjacent. Substrates contain the motif (V)PEID and are among the smallest of any proposed exosortase targets. The processing enzyme is an unusual fusion of an N-terminal exosortase region and a C-terminal region related to eukaryotic CAAX prenyl proteases and bacterial bacteriocin self-immunity proteins.

children.name: Protein sorting system, PEFG-CTERM/thaumarchaeosortase
children.description: Thaumarchaeosortase (archaeosortase G, ArtG) is a member of the exosortase/archaeosortase family of putative protein-processing enzymes. It is restricted to the Thaumarchaeota, a branch of the Archaea. Species with ArtG each have roughly ten sequences with a C-terminal putative protein-sorting domain, PEFG-CTERM. This system is unusual in that the Cys conserved in all other subfamilies described in the exosortase/archaeosortase family, and thought to be part of the active site, is replaced by Ser in ArtG.

children.name: Type V secretion
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 22411980, Title: Type V secretion: mechanism(s) of autotransport through the bacterial outer membrane., Authors: Leo JC, Grin I, Linke D;, Citation: Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci. 2012;367:1088-1101.]
children.description: Type V secretion systems (T5SS) are most commonly the classical monomeric autotransporters (type Va), in which a C-terminal outer membrane (OM) beta barrel domain functions as a translocator through the OM for an N-terminal passenger domain of the same polypeptide chain. Many type Va autotransporters cleave autocatalytically to release the passenger domain. In type Vb systems, called two-partner secretion systems, the passenger and translocator domains are in separate polypeptides. Additional variant forms Vc, Vd, and Ve have also been described. A special type of signal peptide (PF13018) tethers the nascent polypeptide chain to the Sec apparatus in some autotransporters to allow proper completion of C-terminal domain folding in the OM.

children.name: Protein sorting system, CGP-CTERM/unknown of Thermococcaceae
children.description: This C-terminal protein sorting signal domain CGP-CTERM (TIGR04288) is restricted to the the family Thermococcaceae (including Thermococcus, Pyrococcus, and Palaeococcus) within the Euryarchaeota. It may be universal in that family. The sorting family is unknown. By analogy to the sortase, exosortase/archaeosortase, and rhombosortase systems, it is predicted that some protein sorting and processing enzyme recognizes and cleaves the C-terminal region. The unknown putative sorting enzyme may act as a transpeptidase.

children.name: Protein sorting system, Synergist-CTERM/unknown of Synergistetes
children.description: This property describes a putative bacterial C-terminal protein-sorting system restricted to the Synergistetes, but not universal in that lineage. Model genomes from at least seven genera average ten proteins apiece with the Synergist-CTERM signal. Some protein-sorting signals have the signature motif separated from the transmembrane helix (TM) by a spacer region (e.g. LPXTG and MYXO-CTERM) while others are have it flush against the TM (PGF-CTERM, GlyGly-CTERM, and this one). The lack of spacer suggests that the unknown sorting enzyme is a multiple membrane-spanning protein, like archaeosortase and rhombosortase, rather than a predominantly hydrophilic enzyme like sortase, whose targets have a spacer.

children.description: The formation of proteins from amino acid building blocks.

children.name: Transcription termination/antitermination Nus factors
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16946247, Title: Rho-dependent terminators and transcription termination., Authors: Ciampi MS;, Citation: Microbiology. 2006;152:2515-2528.]
children.description: This Genome Property describes the set of Nus factors NusA, NusB, and NusG, as well as ribosomal protein S10 which is known as NusE. The name Nus, for N-utilization substance, reflects the phenomenology of exploitation of N factors for phage lambda in Escherichia coli. Much of the literature of these transcription termination/anti-termination factors revolves around the interaction with the transcription termination factor Rho, but factor Rho and cis-acting Rho-utilization sites are less well distributed than the N-factors, which are essentially universal in bacteria. In species with Rho, Nus factors improve transcriptase turnover speeds. Nus factors can block Rho action, a process called anti-termination [1]. See GenProp0812 for Rho-dependent transcription termination.

children.name: GatABC aspartyl/glutamyl-tRNA(Asn/Gln) amidotransferase complex
children.description: The GatABC heterotrimer acts as an alternative to direct aminoacylation of tRNA(Gln), tRNA(Asn), or both with its respective amino acid. Rather, the tRNA may be misacylated with Glu in the place of Gln, or Asp in the place of Asn. The phylogenetic ranges over which GatABC orthologs act on Glu-tRNA(Gln), Asp-tRNA(Asn), or both are not fully worked out. It is both in Chlamydia, the Thermus-Deinococcus lineage, and Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans. In the Archaea, GatDE act on Glu-tRNA(Gln) while GatABC act on Asp-tRNA(Asn). In Lactobacillus and possibly all Firmicutes, GatABC acts on Glu-tRNA(Gln) only. Note that the amidotransferase reaction is a mechanism not only to charge a tRNA with Asn or Gln, but to complete the synthesis of that amino acid.

children.name: tRNA-Gln direct aminoacylation
children.description: The tRNA for Gln is produced, in different species, in two different ways. In some bacteria (including E. coli) and in the eukaryotic cytosol, the tRNA for glutamine is charged with glutamine. In the majority of sequenced prokaryotes however, tRNA(gln) initially is mischarged with glutamate (Glu). Glu is subsequently amidated to Gln while on the tRNA(gln), as by GatABC in Bacillus subtilis, resulting in Gln biosynthesis from Glu as well as tRNA aminoacylation. This property describes the pathway of direct Gln--tRNA ligase activity, performed by a single protein, glutaminyl-tRNA synthetase.

children.name: tRNA-Asn direct aminoacylation
children.description: The tRNA for Asn can be produced in either of two ways: direct aminoacylation with Asn, and misacylation with Asp that is subsequently amidated to Asn. This is analogous to the system for charging tRNA with Gln, and may share some of the same machinery. This property describes a single polypeptide chain tRNA ligase responsible for direct aminoacylation with Asn.

children.name: Cysteine biosynthesis, tRNA-dependent
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15790858, Title: RNA-dependent cysteine biosynthesis in archaea., Authors: Sauerwald A, Zhu W, Major TA, Roy H, Palioura S, Jahn D, Whitman WB, Yates JR, Ibba M, Söll D;, Citation: Science. 2005;307:1969-1972.]
children.description: Methanocaldococcus jannaschii is a model archaeal species that lacks a direct cys--tRNA ligase. In a system analogous to pyrrolysine and (in many species) asparagine tRNA aminoacylation, the tRNA is misacylated and then the attached amino acid is modified. This two-step pathway is conducted by proteins in the families of MJ1660 (sepS) and MJ1678 (pscS). This pathway assumes 0-phosphoserine, whose biosynthesis is proposed to require D-3-phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase (TIGR01327) and an unidentified aminotransferase.

children.name: Sigma-54 (RpoN) systems
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15231786, Title: Helicobacter pylori FlgR is an enhancer-independent activator of sigma54-RNA polymerase holoenzyme., Authors: Brahmachary P, Dashti MG, Olson JW, Hoover TR;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2004;186:4535-4542., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 7934866, Title: In a class of its own--the RNA polymerase sigma factor sigma 54 (sigma N)., Authors: Merrick MJ;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 1993;10:903-909., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 10894718, Title: The bacterial enhancer-dependent sigma(54) (sigma(N)) transcription factor., Authors: Buck M, Gallegos MT, Studholme DJ, Guo Y, Gralla JD;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2000;182:4129-4136., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 11528004, Title: Metabolic context and possible physiological themes of sigma(54)-dependent genes in Escherichia coli., Authors: Reitzer L, Schneider BL;, Citation: Microbiol Mol Biol Rev. 2001;65:422-44, table of contents.]
children.description: A sigma factor is a DNA-binding protein that binds to the DNA-directed RNA polymerase core, to produce the holoenzyme capable of initiating transcription at specific sites. Different sigma factors act in vegetative growth, heat shock, extracytoplasmic functions (ECF), etc. This model represents the clade of sigma factors called sigma-54, or RpoN (unrelated to sigma 70-type factors such as RpoD/SigA). RpoN is responsible for enhancer-dependent transcription, and its presence characteristically is associated with varied panels of activators, most of which are enhancer-binding proteins [1]. RpoN may be responsible for transcription of nitrogen fixation genes, flagellins, pilins, etc., and synonyms for the gene symbol rpoN, such as ntrA, reflect these observations.

children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 14594807, Title: Functional diversity of the rhodanese homology domain: the Escherichia coli ybbB gene encodes a selenophosphate-dependent tRNA 2-selenouridine synthase., Authors: Wolfe MD, Ahmed F, Lacourciere GM, Lauhon CT, Stadtman TC, Larson TJ;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2004;279:1801-1809., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 16086848, Title: Evolution of selenium utilization traits., Authors: Romero H, Zhang Y, Gladyshev VN, Salinas G;, Citation: Genome Biol. 2005;6:r66., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 22293502, Title: Selenomodification of tRNA in archaea requires a bipartite rhodanese enzyme., Authors: Su D, Ojo TT, Söll D, Hohn MJ;, Citation: FEBS Lett. 2012;586:717-721.]
children.description: Selenium may occur in cells both in proteins, in the form of selenocysteine, and in tRNA, in the form of 2-selenouridine. The two incorporation systems both rely on the selenium donor protein, selenide-water dikinase. This property describes the two-gene combination of selenide-water dikinase and tRNA 2-selenouridine synthase. Note that an initial sulfurtransferase reaction must proceed the action of 2-selenouridine synthase; the enzyme(s) responsible is not currently included in the definition of this Genome Property.

children.name: Translation termination, bacterial
children.description: This Genome Property describes the basic set of bacterial transcription termination factors. Release factor 1 (RF-1, PrfA) should be both universal among bacteria and univerally detected, as should release factor 3 (RF-3). Release factor 2 is a special case. It is truly absent in the Mycoplasmatales, including Mycoplasma genitalium. Its absence means TGA is not recognized as a stop coodon. It codes for Trp instead. However, release factor 2 in most bacteria is encoded by a gene with a programmed frameshift about 25 amino acids from the N-terminus. It may be annotated incorrectly as a truncated or disrupted gene and therefore not detected by its HMM, TIGR00020. A fourth protein included in this genome property is the ribosome recycling factor, which also partipates in processes at the conclusion of bacterial protein translation. This property does not include PrfH, part of a specialized system present only in some bacteria, as it is intended for essentially univeral bacterial termination factors.

children.name: Rho-dependent termination
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16554712, Title: Rho-dependent transcription termination: more questions than answers., Authors: Banerjee S, Chalissery J, Bandey I, Sen R;, Citation: J Microbiol. 2006;44:11-22.]
children.description: Transcriptional termination in bacteria occurs in two modes, one of them dependent on the termination factor Rho. Rho occurs in the overwhelming majority of bacteria, and is an essential protein in most but not all of those species. When Rho is present, the Nus factors (NusA, NusB, and NusG) participate in Rho-dependent termination, although those proteins have other functions as well and are more nearly universal than Rho itself.

children.name: Transcription termination/antitermination Nus factors
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16946247, Title: Rho-dependent terminators and transcription termination., Authors: Ciampi MS;, Citation: Microbiology. 2006;152:2515-2528.]
children.description: This Genome Property describes the set of Nus factors NusA, NusB, and NusG, as well as ribosomal protein S10 which is known as NusE. The name Nus, for N-utilization substance, reflects the phenomenology of exploitation of N factors for phage lambda in Escherichia coli. Much of the literature of these transcription termination/anti-termination factors revolves around the interaction with the transcription termination factor Rho, but factor Rho and cis-acting Rho-utilization sites are less well distributed than the N-factors, which are essentially universal in bacteria. In species with Rho, Nus factors improve transcriptase turnover speeds. Nus factors can block Rho action, a process called anti-termination [1]. See GenProp0812 for Rho-dependent transcription termination.

children.name: YgjD-YeaZ-YjeE complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 23242255, Title: A cyclic form of N6-threonylcarbamoyladenosine as a widely distributed tRNA hypermodification., Authors: Miyauchi K, Kimura S, Suzuki T, Citation: Nat Chem Biol. 2013;9:105-111, Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 25578970, Title: The ATP-mediated formation of the YgjD-YeaZ-YjeE complex is required for the biosynthesis of tRNA t6A in Escherichia coli., Authors: Zhang W, Collinet B, Perrochia L, Durand D, van Tilbeurgh H, Citation: Nucleic Acids Res. 2015;43:1804-1817]
children.description: Catalyses the transfer of the threonylcarbamoyl-moiety of threonylcarbamoyladenylate onto A37 of substrate tRNA in the cytoplasm, or more probably in E.coli, the formation of 'cyclic t6A' (ct6A), which is a cyclized active ester with an oxazolone ring. The N6-threonylcarbamoyladenosine (t6A) modification is present at position 37 of tRNAs that recognize ANN-codons, with N being any nucleotide, enhancing the codon-anti-codon interaction and is required for recognition of the AUG start codon. The modification is thus important for maintaining translational fidelity. A stable YgjD-YeaZ heterodimer first forms, which has an atypical ADP-binding site at the YgjD-YeaZ interface that may also be the binding site for YjeE as the ternary complex only forms in the presence of ATP. An additional YrdC protein is necessary for T6a activity.
