children.name: mTORC1 complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12150925, Title: mTOR interacts with raptor to form a nutrient-sensitive complex that signals to the cell growth machinery., Authors: Kim DH; Sarbassov DD; Ali SM; King JE; Latek RR; Erdjument-Bromage H; Tempst P; Sabatini DM;, Citation: Cell. 2002;110:163-175., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 18497260, Title: The Rag GTPases bind raptor and mediate amino acid signaling to mTORC1., Authors: Sancak Y; Peterson TR; Shaul YD; Lindquist RA; Thoreen CC; Bar-Peled L; Sabatini DM;, Citation: Science. 2008;320:1496-1501., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 12718876, Title: GbetaL, a positive regulator of the rapamycin-sensitive pathway required for the nutrient-sensitive interaction between raptor and mTOR., Authors: Kim DH; Sarbassov DD; Ali SM; Latek RR; Guntur KV; Erdjument-Bromage H; Tempst P; Sabatini DM;, Citation: Mol Cell. 2003;11:895-904., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 17386266, Title: PRAS40 is an insulin-regulated inhibitor of the mTORC1 protein kinase., Authors: Sancak Y; Thoreen CC; Peterson TR; Lindquist RA; Kang SA; Spooner E; Carr SA; Sabatini DM;, Citation: Mol Cell. 2007;25:903-915., Ref 5, Pubmed ID: 19446321, Title: DEPTOR is an mTOR inhibitor frequently overexpressed in multiple myeloma cells and required for their survival., Authors: Peterson TR; Laplante M; Thoreen CC; Sancak Y; Kang SA; Kuehl WM; Gray NS; Sabatini DM;, Citation: Cell. 2009;137:873-886.]
children.description: mTORC1 (mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1 or mechanistic target of rapamycin complex 1) is a nutrient sensor which controls protein synthesis by activating protein translation [1]. Protein synthesis requires a supply of amino acids, an energy source, oxygen abundance and the required growth factors.When these conditons are met, Rag GTPase heterodimers are activated, interact with Raptor, and mTORC1 is localized to the lysosomal membrane surface where it can interact with the G protein Rheb and ATP [2, 3].The pathway is controlled by two complexes that interact with the Rag GTPase, GATOR1 (inhibitor) and GATOR2 (activator) [4].

children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 7935836, Title: Insulin-dependent stimulation of protein synthesis by phosphorylation of a regulator of 5'-cap function., Authors: Pause A; Belsham GJ; Gingras AC; Donzé O; Lin TA; Lawrence JC Jr; Sonenberg N;, Citation: Nature. 1994;371:762-767., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 14673156, Title: mTOR controls cell cycle progression through its cell growth effectors S6K1 and 4E-BP1/eukaryotic translation initiation factor 4E., Authors: Fingar DC; Richardson CJ; Tee AR; Cheatham L; Tsou C; Blenis J;, Citation: Mol Cell Biol. 2004;24:200-216.]
children.description: The mTORC1 (mammalian target of rapamycin) complex is a sensor detecting energy levels and amino acid abundance. Once activated, the mTORC1 complex leads to protein synthesis [1]. Activation of mTORC1 occurs on the surface of the lysosome membrane. The mTORC1 complex leads to activation of eukaryote initiation factor 4F via S6K1, and removes inhibition by EIF4EBP1. EIF4EBP1 prevents assembly of the eIF4F complex [2].

children.name: mTORC1 complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12150925, Title: mTOR interacts with raptor to form a nutrient-sensitive complex that signals to the cell growth machinery., Authors: Kim DH; Sarbassov DD; Ali SM; King JE; Latek RR; Erdjument-Bromage H; Tempst P; Sabatini DM;, Citation: Cell. 2002;110:163-175., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 18497260, Title: The Rag GTPases bind raptor and mediate amino acid signaling to mTORC1., Authors: Sancak Y; Peterson TR; Shaul YD; Lindquist RA; Thoreen CC; Bar-Peled L; Sabatini DM;, Citation: Science. 2008;320:1496-1501., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 12718876, Title: GbetaL, a positive regulator of the rapamycin-sensitive pathway required for the nutrient-sensitive interaction between raptor and mTOR., Authors: Kim DH; Sarbassov DD; Ali SM; Latek RR; Guntur KV; Erdjument-Bromage H; Tempst P; Sabatini DM;, Citation: Mol Cell. 2003;11:895-904., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 17386266, Title: PRAS40 is an insulin-regulated inhibitor of the mTORC1 protein kinase., Authors: Sancak Y; Thoreen CC; Peterson TR; Lindquist RA; Kang SA; Spooner E; Carr SA; Sabatini DM;, Citation: Mol Cell. 2007;25:903-915., Ref 5, Pubmed ID: 19446321, Title: DEPTOR is an mTOR inhibitor frequently overexpressed in multiple myeloma cells and required for their survival., Authors: Peterson TR; Laplante M; Thoreen CC; Sancak Y; Kang SA; Kuehl WM; Gray NS; Sabatini DM;, Citation: Cell. 2009;137:873-886.]
children.description: mTORC1 (mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1 or mechanistic target of rapamycin complex 1) is a nutrient sensor which controls protein synthesis by activating protein translation [1]. Protein synthesis requires a supply of amino acids, an energy source, oxygen abundance and the required growth factors.When these conditons are met, Rag GTPase heterodimers are activated, interact with Raptor, and mTORC1 is localized to the lysosomal membrane surface where it can interact with the G protein Rheb and ATP [2, 3].The pathway is controlled by two complexes that interact with the Rag GTPase, GATOR1 (inhibitor) and GATOR2 (activator) [4].

children.description: Eukaryote initiation factor 4F (eI4F) is a complex involved in protein translation [1,4]. It recognizes the mRNA cap, recruits mRNA to the ribosome and unwinds 5'-terminal secondary structure in an ATP- dependent manner [3]. The composition of the complex varies with the external and internal conditions.

children.description: The transformation of polypeptide chains between the unfolded, misfolded and folded (active) states.

children.name: Chaperone system: DnaK-DnaJ-GrpE
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15102842, Title: Influence of GrpE on DnaK-substrate interactions., Authors: Brehmer D, Gässler C, Rist W, Mayer MP, Bukau B;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2004;279:27957-27964.]
children.description: DnaK, DnaJ, and GrpE form a chaperone system. DnaK has ATPase activity. DnaJ and GrpE are co-chaperones for DnaK, that is, stimulate this activity[1]. This system is also called the hsp70 heat-shock system. Excluded from this system are the heat shock cognate (Hsc) homologs, which are associated specifically with iron-sulfur cluster biosynthesis (see GenProp0138, the iron-sulfur cluster assembly iscSUA-hscBA-fdx system). The heat shock repressor HrcA is found in about half of bacterial genomes with the DnaK-DnaJ-GrpE heat shock system, usually encoded upstream in a heat shock operon; it is included here as an optional component.

children.name: Chaperone system: GroEL/GroES
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 9759498, Title: Structure and function in GroEL-mediated protein folding., Authors: Sigler PB, Xu Z, Rye HS, Burston SG, Fenton WA, Horwich AL;, Citation: Annu Rev Biochem. 1998;67:581-608., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12796498, Title: Coexistence of group I and group II chaperonins in the archaeon Methanosarcina mazei., Authors: Klunker D, Haas B, Hirtreiter A, Figueiredo L, Naylor DJ, Pfeifer G, Müller V, Deppenmeier U, Gottschalk G, Hartl FU, Hayer-Hartl M;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2003;278:33256-33267.]
children.description: GroEL and GroES comprise the bacterial group I chaperonin, a toroidal complex involved in folding or refolding proteins in the cytosol[1]. Archaea and Eukaryotes have instead (with a few rare cases of overlap) a group II chaperonin complex, usually called the thermosome in the Archaea and CCT in the Eukaryota. At least one member of the archaeal genus Methanosarcina, has both[2].

children.description: The archaeal thermosome system is a group II chaperonin, closely related to the CCT complex of eukaryotes. Thermosome subunits show clear remote sequence similarity to GroEL of the bacterial group I chaperonin system[1,2]. Prefoldin, with alpha and beta subunits, works with the chaperonin. The number of distinct but homologous genes for subunits of the thermosome ranges from one to five in the archaea.

children.name: OMP chaperone system: SurA-Skp-DegP
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 17908933, Title: Defining the roles of the periplasmic chaperones SurA, Skp, and DegP in Escherichia coli., Authors: Sklar JG, Wu T, Kahne D, Silhavy TJ;, Citation: Genes Dev. 2007;21:2473-2484.]
children.description: Outer membrane beta-barrel proteins are translocated into the periplasm by the Sec system and subsequently properly folded and inserted into the outer membrane by the beta-barrel assembly machine (Bam). In the periplasm, chaperones prevent misfolding and aggregation, and facilitate the transit across the periplasmic space. The SurA protein appears to be the primary chaperone, at least in E. coli [1], while Skp and DegP may act to rescue any OMPs which fall off of the SurA complex.

children.name: GroEL-GroES complex
children.description: Member of the chaperonin class of molecular chaperones required for the ATP-driven assisted folding of many proteins. Direct contact between substrate proteins and the C-terminal tails of the GroEL subunits helps prevent premature substrate protein escape during encapsulation. Encapsulation seals the GroEL cavity and results in the release of the substrate protein into an enlarged GroEL-GroES chamber. Protein folding is initiated by a conformational shift within the GroEL-GroES complex. Hydrolysis of ATP and binding of a new substrate protein to the opposite cavity sends an allosteric signal causing GroES and the encapsulated protein to be released into the cytosol.

children.name: 19S proteasome cap
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 1317798, Title: Demonstration that a human 26S proteolytic complex consists of a proteasome and multiple associated protein components and hydrolyzes ATP and ubiquitin-ligated proteins by closely linked mechanisms., Authors: Kanayama HO; Tamura T; Ugai S; Kagawa S; Tanahashi N; Yoshimura T; Tanaka K; Ichihara A;, Citation: Eur J Biochem. 1992;206:567-578., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 27428775, Title: An atomic structure of the human 26S proteasome., Authors: Huang X; Luan B; Wu J; Shi Y;, Citation: Nat Struct Mol Biol. 2016;23:778-785., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 15826667, Title: Structure of S5a bound to monoubiquitin provides a model for polyubiquitin recognition., Authors: Wang Q; Young P; Walters KJ;, Citation: J. Mol. Biol. 2005;348:727-739., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 19490896, Title: Assembly pathway of the mammalian proteasome base subcomplex is mediated by multiple specific chaperones., Authors: Kaneko T; Hamazaki J; Iemura S; Sasaki K; Furuyama K; Natsume T; Tanaka K; Murata S;, Citation: Cell 2009;137:914-925., Ref 5, Pubmed ID: 19412159, Title: Chaperone-mediated pathway of proteasome regulatory particle assembly., Authors: Roelofs J; Park S; Haas W; Tian G; McAllister FE; Huo Y; Lee BH; Zhang F; Shi Y; Gygi SP; Finley D;, Citation: Nature 2009;459:861-865.]
children.description: The 20S proteasome is converted to the 26S proteasome by addition of the 19S cap.This is a complex of eighteen proteins, six AAA-ATPases and fourteen that are not ATPases.Non-ATPase regulatory subunit 14 is a metallo-dependent deubiquitinating enzyme from peptidase family M67.Non-ATPase regulatory subunit 4 binds ubiquitin. Ubiquitin receptor ADRM1 also binds ubiquitin and activates non-ATPase regulatory subunit 14, but is absent from the solved tertiary structures [1,2]. Non-ATPase regulatory subunits 5, 9, 10 and 11 are required for proteasome assembly. The 19S complex consists of a base, containing the six AAA-ATPases and three non-ATPase regulatory subunits, and a lid containing all the remaining non-ATPase regulatory subunits [4,5]. The functions of the 19S cap are to remove ubiquitin from targeted proteins, and to denature proteins prior to entry into the central cavity of the proteasome [3].

children.name: ClpXP degradation machine
children.description: This property describes an energy-dependent protease, one of whose tasks is degradation of abortively translated proteins tagged by the tmRNA trans-translation system. ClpX is an ATPase that unfolds target proteins for degradation; ClpP is a protease in complex with ClpX. SspB is an example of an adaptor that brings targets, including but not restricted to proteins tagged by trans-translation, to the ClpXP machine.

children.name: Proteasome-targeting modification by pupylation
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 18832610, Title: Ubiquitin-like protein involved in the proteasome pathway of Mycobacterium tuberculosis., Authors: Pearce MJ, Mintseris J, Ferreyra J, Gygi SP, Darwin KH;, Citation: Science. 2008;322:1104-1107., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 17277063, Title: Characterization of the proteasome accessory factor (paf) operon in Mycobacterium tuberculosis., Authors: Festa RA, Pearce MJ, Darwin KH;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2007;189:3044-3050.]
children.description: Pupylation is the process by which the small protein Pup is conjugated to proteins through its C-terminus to a lysine epsilon-amino group of the target. This modification, analogous to ubiquitination in eukaryotes, targets proteins for degradation by archaeal-type proteasomes in Mycobacterium tuberculosis and related Actinobacteria.

children.name: Proteasome, bacterial
children.description: The proteasome, a large complex formed of alpha and beta subunits, performs protein degradation in eukaryotes, archaea, and bacteria. This Genome Property describes a bacterial 20S proteasome that approximates being restricted to and universal in the Actinobacteria. Nearly all bacteria with this proteasomal system use pupylation to tag proteins as proteasomal targets. The HslVU system in many bacteria is related, with HslV homologous to the proteasome beta subunit, but that system is outside the scope of the archaeal-type bacterial 20S proteasome described here.

children.name: ATP-dependent protease HslVU
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 9288941, Title: The heat-shock protein HslVU from Escherichia coli is a protein-activated ATPase as well as an ATP-dependent proteinase., Authors: Seol JH, Yoo SJ, Shin DH, Shim YK, Kang MS, Goldberg AL, Chung CH;, Citation: Eur J Biochem. 1997;247:1143-1150.]
children.description: HslVU, also known as ClpQY, is an ATP-dependent protease that resembles proteasomes. The ATPase HslU acts in protein unfolding, while the threonine-type endopeptidase HslV is homologous to the proteasome beta subunit and acts in protein degradation. Members of this family frequently are described as heat shock proteins.

children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 9636708, Title: Different pathways for protein degradation by the FtsH/HflKC membrane-embedded protease complex: an implication from the interference by a mutant form of a new substrate protein, YccA., Authors: Kihara A, Akiyama Y, Ito K;, Citation: J Mol Biol. 1998;279:175-188.]
children.description: FtsH/HflKC protease complex is a membrane-embedded protease complex that degrades uncomplexed forms of the SecY subunit of protein translocase. It is composed of FtsH (HflB), an ATP-dependent zinc-metalloproteinase, HflK and HflC. HflK and HflC are periplasmically exposed membrane proteins, which together form a complex (HflKC) which in turn complexes with FtsH [1].

children.description: Fibrinolysis is the disolving of the blood clot and naturally follows coagulation. Plasmin cleaves alpha, beta and gamma chains of fibrin, thereby releasing the N-terminal peptides where the isopeptide bonds, which cross-link fibrin fibres, are formed [1].

children.name: Fibrinogen
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 7649481, Title: Resolution of spontaneous bleeding events but failure of pregnancy in fibrinogen-deficient mice., Authors: Suh TT, Holmback K, Jensen NJ, Daugherty CC, Small K, Simon DI, Potter S, Degen JL;, Citation: Genes Dev. 1995;9:2020-2033.]
children.description: Fibrinogen is the precursor of fibrin.During hemostasis, thrombin activates fibrin which then cross-links to form an insoluble matrix. Three subunits, alpha, beta and gamma, form fibrinogen [1].Thrombin releases fibrinopeptides A and B from the N-termini of the alpha and beta chains respectively.Factor XIII is an transglutaminase which catalyses formation of isopeptide bonds between subunits via the newly exposed N-termini.

children.name: 26S proteasome
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 1317798, Title: Demonstration that a human 26S proteolytic complex consists of a proteasome and multiple associated protein components and hydrolyzes ATP and ubiquitin-ligated proteins by closely linked mechanisms., Authors: Kanayama HO; Tamura T; Ugai S; Kagawa S; Tanahashi N; Yoshimura T; Tanaka K; Ichihara A;, Citation: Eur J Biochem. 1992;206:567-578., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 27428775, Title: An atomic structure of the human 26S proteasome., Authors: Huang X; Luan B; Wu J; Shi Y;, Citation: Nat Struct Mol Biol. 2016;23:778-785.]
children.description: The 26S proteasome is a complex of the 20S proteasome and the 19S proteasome cap.The cap denatures proteins tagged with ubiquitin for degradation, releases ubiquitin and controls access to the central cavity of the 20S proteasome where degradation takes place [1].

children.name: Eukaryote 20S proteasome
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 9087403, Title: Structure of 20S proteasome from yeast at 2.4 A resolution., Authors: Groll M; Ditzel L; Löwe J; Stock D; Bochtler M; Bartunik HD; Huber R;, Citation: Nature 1997;386:463-471., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12015144, Title: The structure of the mammalian 20S proteasome at 2.75 A resolution., Authors: Unno M; Mizushima T; Morimoto Y; Tomisugi Y; Tanaka K; Yasuoka N; Tsukihara T;, Citation: Structure 2002;10:609-618., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 28460188, Title: Proteasomal and Autophagic Degradation Systems., Authors: Dikic I;, Citation: Annu Rev Biochem. 2017;86:193-224.]
children.description: The 20S proteasome is an intracellular complex of fourteen homologous proteins known as alpha and beta subunits.The subunits are arranged in rings of seven and then stacked.Each ring contains only alpha or beta subunits, and these are arranged alpha-beta-beta-alpha in the stack.Three of the beta components are N-terminal nucleophile hydrolases that are threonine-type endopeptidases, with the N-terminal threonine being the nucleophile in the reaction.The active sites are directed towards the central cavity, so that a protein threaded through the central cavity is processed into short peptides.The three catalytically active beta subunits have different specificities, known as trypsin-like, chymotrypsin-like and caspase-like [1,2]. Substrates include intracellular proteins tagged for degradation by polyubiquitination and viral proteins.Peptide products may be trafficked to the major histocompatability complex for presentation as antigens on T-cells.Modified versions of the proteasome occur in immune cells, the thymus and the testis; in these some of the beta or alpha subunits are replaced.Most protein substrates must be denatured before being cleaved by the proteasome, and an additional complex, known as the 19S cap, can be added to either or both ends of the proteasome.The 19S cap includes ATPases and a deubiquitinating enzyme.This larger complex of the 20S proteasome and 19S cap is known as the 26S proteasome [3]. The 20S proteasome is found in all eukaryotes.In archaea and some bacteria, a much simpler assembly exists in which each ring is a homoheptamer of a single alpha or beta subunit.

children.name: 19S proteasome cap
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 1317798, Title: Demonstration that a human 26S proteolytic complex consists of a proteasome and multiple associated protein components and hydrolyzes ATP and ubiquitin-ligated proteins by closely linked mechanisms., Authors: Kanayama HO; Tamura T; Ugai S; Kagawa S; Tanahashi N; Yoshimura T; Tanaka K; Ichihara A;, Citation: Eur J Biochem. 1992;206:567-578., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 27428775, Title: An atomic structure of the human 26S proteasome., Authors: Huang X; Luan B; Wu J; Shi Y;, Citation: Nat Struct Mol Biol. 2016;23:778-785., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 15826667, Title: Structure of S5a bound to monoubiquitin provides a model for polyubiquitin recognition., Authors: Wang Q; Young P; Walters KJ;, Citation: J. Mol. Biol. 2005;348:727-739., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 19490896, Title: Assembly pathway of the mammalian proteasome base subcomplex is mediated by multiple specific chaperones., Authors: Kaneko T; Hamazaki J; Iemura S; Sasaki K; Furuyama K; Natsume T; Tanaka K; Murata S;, Citation: Cell 2009;137:914-925., Ref 5, Pubmed ID: 19412159, Title: Chaperone-mediated pathway of proteasome regulatory particle assembly., Authors: Roelofs J; Park S; Haas W; Tian G; McAllister FE; Huo Y; Lee BH; Zhang F; Shi Y; Gygi SP; Finley D;, Citation: Nature 2009;459:861-865.]
children.description: The 20S proteasome is converted to the 26S proteasome by addition of the 19S cap.This is a complex of eighteen proteins, six AAA-ATPases and fourteen that are not ATPases.Non-ATPase regulatory subunit 14 is a metallo-dependent deubiquitinating enzyme from peptidase family M67.Non-ATPase regulatory subunit 4 binds ubiquitin. Ubiquitin receptor ADRM1 also binds ubiquitin and activates non-ATPase regulatory subunit 14, but is absent from the solved tertiary structures [1,2]. Non-ATPase regulatory subunits 5, 9, 10 and 11 are required for proteasome assembly. The 19S complex consists of a base, containing the six AAA-ATPases and three non-ATPase regulatory subunits, and a lid containing all the remaining non-ATPase regulatory subunits [4,5]. The functions of the 19S cap are to remove ubiquitin from targeted proteins, and to denature proteins prior to entry into the central cavity of the proteasome [3].

children.name: Immunoproteasome
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12015144, Title: The structure of the mammalian 20S proteasome at 2.75 A resolution., Authors: Unno M; Mizushima T; Morimoto Y; Tomisugi Y; Tanaka K; Yasuoka N; Tsukihara T;, Citation: Structure 2002;10:609-618., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 11265247, Title: Antigen processing by the proteasome., Authors: Kloetzel PM;, Citation: Nat Rev Mol Cell Biol. 2001;2:179-188., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 28460188, Title: Proteasomal and Autophagic Degradation Systems., Authors: Dikic I;, Citation: Annu Rev Biochem. 2017;86:193-224.]
children.description: The immunoproteasome is a specialist form of the eukaryote 20S proteasome [1] in which the three catalytic beta subunits are replaced by three different catalytic beta subunits known as beta1i (beta type-9), beta2i (beta type-10) and beta5i (beta type-8) [2].Interferon gamma induces production of these subunits as well as the down-regulation of production of the usual beta1, beta2 and beta5 subunits.The interferon-induced subunits have modified specificities and the immunoproteasome generates peptides that act as ligands for the major histocompatibility complex [3].

children.name: Initiator caspases of the apoptosis extrinsic pathway
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 14499155, Title: Apoptosis: the complex scenario for a silent cell death., Authors: Bohm I, Schild H;, Citation: Mol Imaging Biol. 2003;5:2-14., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 9006941, Title: FLICE induced apoptosis in a cell-free system. Cleavage of caspase zymogens., Authors: Muzio M; Salvesen GS; Dixit VM;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1997;272:2952-2956.]
children.description: Apoptosis or programmed cell death is the mechanism by which cells in eukaryotes are killed. Cysteine endopeptidases known as caspases are activated and these deactivate cellular proteins, often by cleaving within interdomain regions, thereby separating binding domains of signal reception and transduction domains [1]. Caspases have a specificity for aspartyl bonds, which occur frequently in surface loops and interdomain regions of proteins. Caspases involved in apoptosis are of two kinds: initiators and executors. Initiator caspases activate the executor caspases which cleave other proteins in the cell [2]. There are at least four routes by which the initiator caspase precursors are activated. This Genome Property includes the extrinsic pathway initiator caspases.

children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 14499155, Title: Apoptosis: the complex scenario for a silent cell death., Authors: Bohm I, Schild H;, Citation: Mol Imaging Biol. 2003;5:2-14., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 21456965, Title: Caspase substrates and cellular remodeling., Authors: Crawford ED; Wells JA;, Citation: Annu Rev Biochem. 2001;80:1055-1087., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 9852092, Title: Granzyme B mimics apical caspases. Description of a unified pathway for trans-activation of executioner caspase-3 and -7., Authors: Yang X; Stennicke HR; Wang B; Green DR; Jänicke RU; Srinivasan A; Seth P; Salvesen GS; Froelich CJ;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1998;273:34278-34283., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 8900201, Title: The Ced-3/interleukin 1beta converting enzyme-like homolog Mch6 and the lamin-cleaving enzyme Mch2alpha are substrates for the apoptotic mediator CPP32., Authors: Srinivasula SM; Fernandes-Alnemri T; Zangrilli J; Robertson N; Armstrong RC; Wang L; Trapani JA; Tomaselli KJ; Litwack G; Alnemri ES;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1998;271:27099-27106.]
children.description: Apoptosis or programmed cell death is the mechanism by which cells in eukaryotes are killed. Cysteine endopeptidases known as caspases are activated and these deactivate cellular proteins, often by cleaving within interdomain regions, thereby separating binding domains or signal reception and transduction domains [1]. Caspases have a specificity for aspartyl bonds, which occur frequently in surface loops and interdomain regions of proteins [2]. Caspases involved in apoptosis are of two kinds: initiators and executors. Initiator caspases activate the executor caspases which cleave other proteins in the cell [3,4]. This Genome Property includes the executor caspases.

children.description: The KICSTOR complex functions in the TORC1 signaling pathway and is an amino acid-sensor.In the absence of amino acids, KICSTOR recruits the GATOR1 complex to lysosomal membranes and permits interaction with GATOR2 and the RAG GTPases. This negatively regulates mTORC1 signaling.In the absence of KICSTOR, mTORC1 is localized to the lysosome and activated. The mTORC1 complex is a regulator of cell growth [1].

children.name: Detoxification
children.description: The process of making deleterious compounds, whether exogenous or generated within the cell, less dangerous via the mechanisms of chemical conversion, transport or sequestration.

children.name: Resistance to mercury
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12917805, Title: Operon mer: bacterial resistance to mercury and potential for bioremediation of contaminated environments., Authors: Nascimento AM, Chartone-Souza E;, Citation: Genet Mol Res. 2003;2:92-101.]
children.description: Detoxification of inorganic and organic mercury compounds involves the enzymatic reduction of extracellular mercuric ions or organomercurials into less-toxic metallic mercury, which is released into the cytoplasm and then volatilizes from the cell. Mercuric ions diffuse across the outer membrane by a mer transport system, which binds and transfers mercury ions via a pair of cysteine residues to the active site of a mercuric reductase. Alternatively, an organomercurial lyase is required for hydrolysis of the carbon-mercury bond of organomercurial compounds before reduction proceeds. Transcribed separately and divergently, a mercury-sensitive transcriptional activator both positively and negatively regulates mer expression, while a co-transcribed secondary regulatory protein down-regulates this mer operon. This resistance system, often encoded on plasmids and transferred via transposons, is found in both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria [1].

children.name: Arsenical resistance system
children.description: A characteristic four-gene system for arsenic (and antimony) resistance is found in many prokaryotic genomes. The system includes a pump for extrusion of arsenite, an arsenate reductase that converts arsenate to arsenite for transport, a protein ArsH of unknown function that is sometimes not required, and a regulatory protein. Several distinct families are known for the arsenate reductase, ArsC, which may be dependent on glutaredoxin or thioredoxin in different instances.

children.name: Formaldehyde detoxification, glutathione-dependent
children.description: Formaldehyde, a toxic metabolite because it reacts easily with protein or DNA, naturally combines with reduced glutathione (GSH) to form S-hydroxymethyl-glutathione. In some species, this reaction is accelerated by the enzyme S-(hydroxymethyl)glutathione synthase, also called glutathione-dependent formaldehyde activating enzyme. A class III alcohol dehydrogenase, with activity for a variety of medium chain alcohols (but poor activity for ethanol) can convert S-(hydroxymethyl)glutathione to S-formylglutathione, and therefore has been called glutathione-dependent formaldehyde dehydrogenase but is more properly called S-(hydroxymethyl)glutathione dehydrogenase for this activity. Finally, S-formylglutathione is converted to glutathione and formate by S-formylglutathione hydrolase, which has a dual role as a broadly specific esterase, called esterase D in animals. While the two essential enzymes of this pathway both have broad specificities, the pairing in operons in so many genomes demonstrates the recurring importance of formaldehyde detoxification.

children.name: Ribulose monophosphate pathway
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16788179, Title: The ribulose monophosphate pathway substitutes for the missing pentose phosphate pathway in the archaeon Thermococcus kodakaraensis., Authors: Orita I, Sato T, Yurimoto H, Kato N, Atomi H, Imanaka T, Sakai Y;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2006;188:4698-4704., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 16237021, Title: Ribose-5-phosphate biosynthesis in Methanocaldococcus jannaschii occurs in the absence of a pentose-phosphate pathway., Authors: Grochowski LL, Xu H, White RH;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2005;187:7382-7389., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 15978081, Title: HxlR, a member of the DUF24 protein family, is a DNA-binding protein that acts as a positive regulator of the formaldehyde-inducible hxlAB operon in Bacillus subtilis., Authors: Yurimoto H, Hirai R, Matsuno N, Yasueda H, Kato N, Sakai Y;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2005;57:511-519.]
children.description: The ribulose monophosphate pathway consists of two enzyme, 3-hexulose-6-phosphate synthase (HPS) and 6-phospho-3-hexuloisomerase (PHI). In one direction, this pathway removes the toxic metabolite formaldehyde by assimilation. In the other direction, in certain species lacking the complete pentose phosphate pathway, this pathway releases formaldehyde in order to produce ribulose-5-phosphate, essential for nucleotide biosynthesis. The two enzymes may occur as a fusion protein, as in Thermococcus kodakaraensis.

children.name: Alkylhydroperoxide reductase AhpCF (peroxiredoxin)
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10482511, Title: Role of the alkyl hydroperoxide reductase (ahpCF) gene in oxidative stress defense of the obligate Anaerobe bacteroides fragilis., Authors: Rocha ER, Smith CJ;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1999;181:5701-5710.]
children.description: This two-gene peroxiredoxin consists of ahpC and ahpF, ususally as tandem genes in an apparent operon. Peroxiredoxin detoxifies alkyl hydroperoxides by catalyzing the oxidation of an active site cysteine (on AhpC) to a sulfenic acid. This subsequently becomes a disulfide which is then resolved by reduction. AhpF contains an FAD-binding domain along with a NAD(P)H binding domain (PF07992).

children.name: Tryptophan biosynthesis from ribose-5-phosphate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12966138, Title: Ancient origin of the tryptophan operon and the dynamics of evolutionary change., Authors: Xie G, Keyhani NO, Bonner CA, Jensen RA;, Citation: Microbiol Mol Biol Rev. 2003;67:303-42.]
children.description: The essential amino acid tryptophan is synthesized in prokaryotes, plants, and fungi via a conserved six step pathway from the branchpoint compound chrosimate, a common precursor in the biosynthesis of aromatic amino acids. Seven catalytic domains and two alpha/beta subunit complexes comprise this pathway. Individually expressed in some organisms, gene fusions encoding single proteins possessing two or more of these catalytic domains have been observed for every trp gene. Although the occurance of gene fusions have been shown to be phylogenetically unrelated, a conserved gene order can be discerned within the domain Bacteria. Occasionally gene(s) dissociations disrupt gene order as in Campylobacter jejuni and Deinococcus radiodurans, or the pathway is found split between two separate chromosomes as in Rhodobacter sphaeroides. In cyanobacteria, such as Nostoc and Anabaena, it is not uncommon to observe paralogous trp genes as part of a larger "supraoperon" including other aromatic amino acid synthesizing genes as well as their trp counterparts [1].

children.name: Histidine biosynthesis from ribose-5-phosphate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 8852895, Title: Histidine biosynthetic pathway and genes: structure, regulation, and evolution., Authors: Alifano P, Fani R, Liò P, Lazcano A, Bazzicalupo M, Carlomagno MS, Bruni CB;, Citation: Microbiol Rev. 1996;60:44-69., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 11842181, Title: Mechanism of action and NAD+-binding mode revealed by the crystal structure of L-histidinol dehydrogenase., Authors: Barbosa JA, Sivaraman J, Li Y, Larocque R, Matte A, Schrag JD, Cygler M;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2002;99:1859-1864.]
children.description: Histidine is synthesized from phosphoribosyl-pyrophosphate in a ten step pathway found in bacteria, archaebacteria, fungi, and plants. The early stage of this pathway takes a ribose and transforms it into imadiazoleglycerol phosphate. Once the imadiazole ring is formed, glutamate donates the a-amino group and the newly formed amine is oxidized to histidine [1]. In Salmonella typhimurium and Escherichia coli, this pathway is carried out by the eight genes in the 'his' operon. hisI, hisB, and hisD are bifunctional enzymes, hisF and hisH form a monofunctional dimer, and the rest are monofunctional enzymes [2].

children.name: Proline biosynthesis from glutamate
children.description: The amino acid proline is synthesized in three steps from glutamate via L-glutamate-5-semialdehyde which non-enzymatically cyclizes to delta-1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate. Glutamate semialdehyde can also arise from transamination of ornithine. Proline may also be synthesized directly from ornithine by the action of ornithine cyclodeaminase. These alternate paths are not covered by this property.

children.name: Arginine biosynthesis from ornithine, carbamoyl-p and aspartate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 9501170, Title: The crystal structure of Pyrococcus furiosus ornithine carbamoyltransferase reveals a key role for oligomerization in enzyme stability at extremely high temperatures., Authors: Villeret V, Clantin B, Tricot C, Legrain C, Roovers M, Stalon V, Glansdorff N, Van Beeumen J;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 1998;95:2801-2806.]
children.description: The arginine biosynthesis pathway is a three step process and a part of the urea cycle. The first enzyme, ornithine carbamoyltransferase (OTCase) carries out the reaction anabolically in arginine biosynthesis, but in some cases, it carries out catabolic reactions. Most OTCases are homotrimers, but the homotrimers are organized into dodecamers built from four trimers in at least two species; the catabolic OTCase of Pseudomonas aeruginosa is allosterically regulated, while OTCase of the extreme thermophile Pyrococcus furiosus shows both allostery and thermophily [1]. The third step of the pathway yields L-arginine by argininosuccinate lyase, and the amino acid can be cleaved by arginase, yielding urea and reconstituting ornithine.

children.description: This pathway results in the creation of ornithine for use in the biosynthesis of arginine and in the urea cycle. Ornithine can also be interconverted with glutamate semialdehyde from the proline biosynthetic pathway. This pathway represents one of two possible branches for the creation of ornithine from glutamate.

children.name: Threonine biosynthesis from aspartate semialdehyde
children.description: Threonine is synthesised from aspartate semialdehyde, a branch point intermediate in the synthesis of lysine. The aspartate semialdehyde is derived from aspartate, which in turn is derived from the Krebs cycle intermediate oxaloacetate. Homoserine, an intermediate in this pathway is a branchpoint for the biosynthesis of methionine. Threonine itself is utilized as a starting point for the biosynthesis of isoleucine.

children.name: Aspartate semialdehyde biosynthesis from aspartate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 2892836, Title: Structure of the yeast HOM3 gene which encodes aspartokinase., Authors: Rafalski JA, Falco SC;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1988;263:2146-2151.]
children.description: Aspartate semialdehyde biosynthesis is a two step pathway. The product of this pathway can be used in lysine biosynthesis, or in the pathway leading to homoserine, which is involved in threonine, isoleucine and methionine biosynthesis. There are three isozymes that differ in their sensitivity to regulation by Lys, Met and Thr in Escherichia coli [1].

children.name: Isoleucine biosynthesis from threonine and pyruvate
children.description: The branched amino acid isoleucine is biosynthesized from the central intermediary metabolite pyruvate and the amino acid threonine via a five step pathway. Four enzymes in this pathway are common to the pathways for the biosynthesis of leucine and valine, although specialized versions of these enzymes may exist in certain species which have a narrowed substrate range or amino acid-specific regulatory mechanisms. Unlike those other two pathways in which two molecules of pyruvate are condensed, here threonine is converted first to 2-oxobutyrate and then condensed with pyruvate. Thus, the enzymes common to the pathways are acting on distinct substrates. 2-oxobutyrate for this pathway may also be generated by a separate path from glutamate via mesaconate in certain organisms. The penultimate intermediate in this pathway, 2-oxo-3-methylvalerate may also be incorporated into branched-chain fatty acids

children.name: Valine biosynthesis from pyruvate
children.description: The branched amino acid valine is biosynthesized from the central intermediary metabolite pyruvate via a four step pathway. All four enzymes in this pathway are common to the pathways for the biosynthesis of isoleucine from 2-oxobutyrate and leucine from pyruvate, although specialized versions of these enzymes may exist in certain species which have a narrowed substrate range or amino acid-specific regulatory mechanisms. The product of the third step in this pathway, 2-oxoisovalerate is a branchpoint metabolite required for the biosynthesis of Coenzyme A, branched-chain fatty acids, and leucine. Similarly, the product of the first step, (S)-2-acetolactate is common to the pathway to (R,R)-2,3-butanediol in the mixed-acid fermentation of pyruvate. The first step of the pathway, acetolactate synthase, requires thiamine pyrophosphate and two molecules of pyruvate, one of which is decarboxylated to the acetoacetate adduct, 2-(alpha-hydroxyethyl)-ThPP.

children.name: Leucine biosynthesis from pyruvate and acetyl-CoA
children.description: The branched amino acid leucine is biosynthesized from the central intermediary metabolites pyruvate and acetyl-CoA via a seven step pathway. Four of these steps are shared with the valine and isoleucine pathways, although specialized versions of these enzymes may exist in certain species which have a narrowed substrate range or amino acid-specific regulatory mechanisms. The product of the third step in this pathway, 2-oxoisovalerate is a branchpoint metabolite required for the biosynthesis of Coenzyme A, branched-chain fatty acids and valine. Similarly, the product of the first step, (S)-2-acetolactate is common to the pathway to (R,R)-2,3-butanediol in the mixed-acid fermentation of pyruvate. The first step of the pathway, acetolactate synthase, requires thiamine pyrophosphate and two molecules of pyruvate, one of which is decarboxylated to the acetoacetate adduct, 2-(alpha-hydroxyethyl)-ThPP. The acetyl-CoA required for the fourth step, 2-isopropylmalate synthase, may also derive from this ThPP adduct by oxidation.

children.description: The glycine cleavage system (GCS), also known as the glycine decarboxylase system (GDC) consists of a set of four enzymes, which are involved in a multi-step reaction to catalyse the cleavage of glycine molecules. The constituents enzymes are, P protein, H protein, T protein, and L protein (dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase)[1].

children.name: Lysine biosynthesis
children.description: The basic amino acid lysine may be synthesized by one of two types of pathways in prokaryotes, diaminopimelate (DAP) pathways and the alpha-aminoadipate (AAA) pathway. DAP pathways have several variants including the dehydrogenase (reductive) pathway which requires ammonia and NADPH, and the acetylated and succinylated pathways which do not. A non-reductive pathway which uses neither acetate or succinate protecting groups is found in plants but has not been observed in prokaryotes. The AAA pathway has a variant found in fungi and plants which has not been observed in prokaryotes.

children.name: Lysine biosynthesis via diaminopimelate (DAP)
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 17093042, Title: L,L-diaminopimelate aminotransferase, a trans-kingdom enzyme shared by Chlamydia and plants for synthesis of diaminopimelate/lysine., Authors: McCoy AJ, Adams NE, Hudson AO, Gilvarg C, Leustek T, Maurelli AT;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2006;103:17909-17914.]
children.description: The basic amino acid lysine is synthesized in most bacteria and plants via a nine step pathway from aspartate (via aspartate semialdehyde which is also used in a number of other pathways). Most species utilize succinate (from succinyl-CoA) to make an important amide linkage in the ring-opening of piperidine dicarboxylate. The succinate is then hydrolyzed several steps later. Other species carry out analogous transformations with acetate (from acetyl-CoA). Chlamydia and cyanobacteria have been shown to utilize a direct aminotransferase path without the acylation/deacylation steps, and a number of other species apparently also use this variant [1]. Each of these variants are included within this property. Certain obligate intracellular organisms such as Coxiella, Rickettsia and Wolbachia, contain all but the final step (diaminopimelate decarboxylase) of this pathway. Presumably these organisms have no need of lysine biosynthesis, being able to obtain it from their hosts. The products of the penultimate two steps however, LL- and meso-diaminopimelate, are required components of the bacterial cell wall, and so the rest of the pathway persists. There is a possibility that the decarboxylase exists in these organsims but is undetected.

children.name: Aspartate semialdehyde biosynthesis from aspartate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 2892836, Title: Structure of the yeast HOM3 gene which encodes aspartokinase., Authors: Rafalski JA, Falco SC;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1988;263:2146-2151.]
children.description: Aspartate semialdehyde biosynthesis is a two step pathway. The product of this pathway can be used in lysine biosynthesis, or in the pathway leading to homoserine, which is involved in threonine, isoleucine and methionine biosynthesis. There are three isozymes that differ in their sensitivity to regulation by Lys, Met and Thr in Escherichia coli [1].

children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 20418392, Title: Methanococci use the diaminopimelate aminotransferase (DapL) pathway for lysine biosynthesis., Authors: Liu Y, White RH, Whitman WB;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2010;192(13):3304-3310.]
children.description: There are four known variations (branches) of the lysine biosynthesis pathway via diaminopimelate (DAP). The variations occur in the steps converting L-2,3,4,5-tetrahydrodipicolinate (THDPA) to LL-2,6-diaminopimelate. This property refers to the acetylated branch of this pathway which generates N-acetyl intermediates. This branch is limited to certain Bacillus species [1].

children.name: Lysine biosynthesis via diaminopimelate (DAP), succinylated branch
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 20418392, Title: Methanococci use the diaminopimelate aminotransferase (DapL) pathway for lysine biosynthesis., Authors: Liu Y, White RH, Whitman WB;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2010;192(13):3304-3310.]
children.description: There are four known variations (branches) of the lysine biosynthesis pathway via diaminopimelate (DAP). The variations occur in the steps converting L-2,3,4,5-tetrahydrodipicolinate (THDPA) to LL-2,6-diaminopimelate. This property refers to the succinylated branch of this pathway. This branch acylates THDPA with succinyl-CoA to generate N-succinyl-ll-2-amino-6-ketopimelate and forms meso-DAP by subsequent transamination, desuccinylation, and epimerization. This branch is utilized by proteobacteria as well as many firmicutes and actinobacteria [1].

children.name: Lysine biosynthesis via alpha-aminoadipate (AAA pathway)
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10613839, Title: A prokaryotic gene cluster involved in synthesis of lysine through the amino adipate pathway: a key to the evolution of amino acid biosynthesis., Authors: Nishida H, Nishiyama M, Kobashi N, Kosuge T, Hoshino T, Yamane H;, Citation: Genome Res. 1999;9:1175-1183.]
children.description: Lysine biosynthesis in fungi has been characterized and begins with the condensation of 2-oxoglutarate and acetyl-CoA to homocitrate and continues through the distinctive intermediate, alpha-aminoadipate. This pathway is distinct in every respect from the diaminopimelate pathway commonly found in bacteria and animals.Recently, an alpha-aminoadipate pathway closely related to the fungal version has been characterized in Thermus thermophilus [1] and appears to be widely distributed among the archaea.

children.name: Lysine biosynthesis via diaminopimelate (DAP) utilizing ammonia and NADPH
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 1906065, Title: A functionally split pathway for lysine synthesis in Corynebacterium glutamicium., Authors: Schrumpf B, Schwarzer A, Kalinowski J, Pühler A, Eggeling L, Sahm H;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1991;173:4510-4516.]
children.description: This pathway for the biosynthesis of L-lysine differs from the more common diaminopimelate pathway by the action of diaminopimelate dehydrogenase (ddh). This enzyme requires both ammonia as a nitrogen source (instead of an amino acid via a transaminase) and reductive power in the form of NADPH. Additionally, this pathway does not require the acetyl/succinyl protecting group transformations found in the standard pathway, nor does it require the action of diaminopimelate epimerase. This enzyme has been best characterized in Corynebacterium glutamicum and Bacillus sphaericus. One should note that the ddh enzyme is shown acting on the compound L-2-amino-6-oxoheptanedioate in EC and KEGG representations. This is merely the ring-opened form of 2,3,4,5-tetrahydropicolinate with which it is in equilibrium, and upon which the acyltransferases of the common pathway act.

children.name: Cysteine biosynthesis, tRNA-dependent
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15790858, Title: RNA-dependent cysteine biosynthesis in archaea., Authors: Sauerwald A, Zhu W, Major TA, Roy H, Palioura S, Jahn D, Whitman WB, Yates JR, Ibba M, Söll D;, Citation: Science. 2005;307:1969-1972.]
children.description: Methanocaldococcus jannaschii is a model archaeal species that lacks a direct cys--tRNA ligase. In a system analogous to pyrrolysine and (in many species) asparagine tRNA aminoacylation, the tRNA is misacylated and then the attached amino acid is modified. This two-step pathway is conducted by proteins in the families of MJ1660 (sepS) and MJ1678 (pscS). This pathway assumes 0-phosphoserine, whose biosynthesis is proposed to require D-3-phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase (TIGR01327) and an unidentified aminotransferase.

children.name: Methionine salvage from methylthioadenosine
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15102328, Title: Bacterial variations on the methionine salvage pathway., Authors: Sekowska A, Dénervaud V, Ashida H, Michoud K, Haas D, Yokota A, Danchin A;, Citation: BMC Microbiol. 2004;4:9.]
children.description: Methylthioadenosine (MTA) is a sulfur-containing by-product from the use of S-adenosylmethionine in spermidine or polyamine biosynthesis and certain other pathways. A series of reactions, with considerable species-specific variation, recycles MTA to methionine in a wide range of organisms. In a new nomenclature, these genes are now designated mtn (MethylThioNucleoside). An interesting enzyme in this system is MtnD, the aci-reductone dioxygenase. This enzyme has two different enzymatic activities, depending on whether Ni2+ or Fe2+ is bound. The action of the single enzyme MtnP is replaced by two enzymes, MtnN and MtnK in some species. Likewise, the enolase-phosphatase MtnC is replaced by MtnW and MtnX in the Bacillus lineage. The final step in the pathway, a transamination that generates methionine from 2-keto-4-methylthiobutyrate, apparantly can be catalyzed by a large number of functional analogs using different amino donors, and so is not included explicitly in the reconstruction.

children.name: Methylthioribose-1-phosphate isomerase/mtnA
children.functional_elements: [(ID: Methylthioribose-1-phosphate isomerase, Name: Methylthioribose-1-phosphate isomerase/mtnA, Evidences: [(Evidence_IDs: ['IPR005251', 'TIGR00512'], GO Terms: ['GO:0019509'], Sufficient: False)], Required: True)]

children.name: Methylthioribulose-1-phosphate dehydratase/mtnB
children.functional_elements: [(ID: Methylthioribulose-1-phosphate dehydratase, Name: Methylthioribulose-1-phosphate dehydratase/mtnB, Evidences: [(Evidence_IDs: ['IPR017714', 'TIGR03328'], GO Terms: ['GO:0019509'], Sufficient: False)], Required: True)]

children.name: Methionine salvage enolase-phosphate pair MtnW/MtnX
children.description: In many species with methionine salvage from methylthioadenosine, a single protein (MtnC) acts as an enolase-phosphatase. However, in Bacillus subtilis and related species, the enolase and phosphate are separate proteins designated MtnW and MtnX. The former resembles RuBisCO and the latter belongs to the HAD superfamily hydrolases.

children.name: Selenocysteinyl-tRNA, PSTK/SepSecS pathway
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 18174226, Title: Characterization and evolutionary history of an archaeal kinase involved in selenocysteinyl-tRNA formation., Authors: Sherrer RL, O'Donoghue P, Söll D;, Citation: Nucleic Acids Res. 2008;36:1247-1259., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 15317934, Title: Identification and characterization of phosphoseryl-tRNA[Ser]Sec kinase., Authors: Carlson BA, Xu XM, Kryukov GV, Rao M, Berry MJ, Gladyshev VN, Hatfield DL;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2004;101:12848-12853.]
children.description: This pathway is the archaeal and eukaryotic system for converting the serine on selenocysteine-tRNA to selenocysteine. This first enzyme is a kinase, L-seryl-tRNA(Sec) kinase (PSTK). The second is Sep-tRNA:Sec-tRNA synthase (SepSecS). In bacteria, this two-enzyme pathway is replaced by SelA (TIGR00474).

children.name: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase complex
children.description: Plays a key role in both pyrimidine and arginine biosynthesis by catalyzing the production of carbamoyl phosphate from one molecule of bicarbonate, two molecules of MgATP, and one molecule of glutamine. Consists of two polypeptide chains referred to as the small and large subunits, which contain a total of three separate active sites that are connected by an intramolecular tunnel. The small subunit harbors one of these active sites and is responsible for the hydrolysis of glutamine to glutamate and ammonia. The large subunit binds the two required molecules of MgATP and is involved in assembling the final product. Compounds such as L-ornithine, UMP, and IMP allosterically regulate the enzyme.

children.name: Amino acid salvage
children.description: Any process which produces an amino acid from derivatives of it, without de novo synthesis.

children.name: Reduction of oxidized methionine
children.description: Methionine, free or in proteins, is susceptible to oxidation damage. R- and S-conformation enantiomers of methionine sulfoxide can be repaired by different reductases. MsrB (TIGR00357) was previously designated PilB because of altered cytoadherence in a mutant. MsrA and MsrB are sometimes expressed as a fusion protein.

children.name: Methionine salvage from methylthioadenosine
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15102328, Title: Bacterial variations on the methionine salvage pathway., Authors: Sekowska A, Dénervaud V, Ashida H, Michoud K, Haas D, Yokota A, Danchin A;, Citation: BMC Microbiol. 2004;4:9.]
children.description: Methylthioadenosine (MTA) is a sulfur-containing by-product from the use of S-adenosylmethionine in spermidine or polyamine biosynthesis and certain other pathways. A series of reactions, with considerable species-specific variation, recycles MTA to methionine in a wide range of organisms. In a new nomenclature, these genes are now designated mtn (MethylThioNucleoside). An interesting enzyme in this system is MtnD, the aci-reductone dioxygenase. This enzyme has two different enzymatic activities, depending on whether Ni2+ or Fe2+ is bound. The action of the single enzyme MtnP is replaced by two enzymes, MtnN and MtnK in some species. Likewise, the enolase-phosphatase MtnC is replaced by MtnW and MtnX in the Bacillus lineage. The final step in the pathway, a transamination that generates methionine from 2-keto-4-methylthiobutyrate, apparantly can be catalyzed by a large number of functional analogs using different amino donors, and so is not included explicitly in the reconstruction.

children.name: Methionine salvage enolase-phosphate pair MtnW/MtnX
children.description: In many species with methionine salvage from methylthioadenosine, a single protein (MtnC) acts as an enolase-phosphatase. However, in Bacillus subtilis and related species, the enolase and phosphate are separate proteins designated MtnW and MtnX. The former resembles RuBisCO and the latter belongs to the HAD superfamily hydrolases.

children.description: The chemical reactions and pathways resulting in the breakdown of amino acids (organic acids containing one or more amino substituents).

children.name: Degradation of tyrosine via homogentisate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15262943, Title: The homogentisate pathway: a central catabolic pathway involved in the degradation of L-phenylalanine, L-tyrosine, and 3-hydroxyphenylacetate in Pseudomonas putida., Authors: Arias-Barrau E, Olivera ER, Luengo JM, Fernández C, Galán B, García JL, Díaz E, Miñambres B;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2004;186(15):5062-5077.]
children.description: Tyrosine is degraded to produce fumarate and acetoacetate via the intermediate homogentisate, in a five-step pathway. Tyrosine is converted to 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate by TyrB (tyrosine transaminase also known as tyrosine aminotransferase or PhhC) and then to homogentisate by Hpd (4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase). The second part of the pathway (the catabolism of homogentisate) involves three enzymes: HmgA (homogentisate dioxygenase); HmgB (fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase, also known as Fah); and HmgC (maleylacetoacetate isomerase, also known as Mai) [1].

children.name: Attenuation system: tryptophanase
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 9045840, Title: Regulation of the Escherichia coli tna operon: nascent leader peptide control at the tnaC stop codon., Authors: Konan KV, Yanofsky C;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1997;179:1774-1779.]
children.description: This property is characterized by two components. One is the enzyme tryptophanase, capabable of degrading tryptophan. The other is the tryptophanase leader peptide, TnaC, encoded upstream of the enzyme. The ribosome that translates the leader peptide may stall at either of two points: the trp codon (when trp is scarce) or the stop codon. The leader peptide may interact with ribosome to delay release at its stop codon. Whether the ribosome stalls at the trp codon or continues to the stop codon controls what mRNA secondary structure may form as the trytophanase message is synthesized. When trp is scarce, and the enzyme should not be made, a terminator forms and transcription ends. Examples of this mechanism for controlling transcription at termination are called transcriptional attenuation.

children.name: Homocysteine regeneration from S-adenosylhomocysteine
children.description: S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) is used in cells as a methyl donor by a large guild of methyltransferases, leaving S-adenosylhomocysteine (SAH). SAH can be cleaved in one step to adenosine and homocysteine by adenosylhomocysteinase (EC 3.3.1.1). The homocysteine can then be used to regenerate methionine. Alternatively, it can be cleaved in two steps. First adenine is removed by adenosylhomocysteine nucleosidase (EC 3.2.2.9) to leave S-ribosylhomocysteine. Next, S-ribosylhomocysteinase acts to produce homocysteine and 4,5-dihydroxypentan-2,3-dione, which cyclizes spontaneously and binds borate to become autoinducer-2 (AI-2), a quorum-sensing molecule produced and recognized by a wide range of bacteria. This property represents the presence of at least one of these two mechanisms to regenerate homocysteine.

children.name: Quorum-sensing, autoinducer-2 system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16101288, Title: Mutational analysis of a nucleosidase involved in quorum-sensing autoinducer-2 biosynthesis., Authors: Lee JE, Luong W, Huang DJ, Cornell KA, Riscoe MK, Howell PL;, Citation: Biochemistry. 2005;44:11049-11057., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 15456522, Title: Is autoinducer-2 a universal signal for interspecies communication: a comparative genomic and phylogenetic analysis of the synthesis and signal transduction pathways., Authors: Sun J, Daniel R, Wagner-Döbler I, Zeng AP;, Citation: BMC Evol Biol. 2004;4:36.]
children.description: S-ribosylhomocysteine lyase (LuxS) is an iron(2+)-containing protein. Its immediate product, 4,5-dihydroxypentan-2,3-dione, cyclizes spontaneously and binds borate to become autoinducer-2 (AI-2), a quorum-sensing molecule produced and recognized by a wide range of bacteria. LuxS serves as a marker for this system, while MTA/SAH nucleosidase is essential both for this and other systems.

children.name: Iron metabolism
children.description: Properties in this catergory cover processes that import, export and transform the chemical state of the iron atom.

children.name: Iron-sulfur cluster assembly systems
children.description: At least three different systems have been described for iron cluster assembly, the NIF system provides clusters to nitrogenase, the ISC system may provide both 2Fe-2S and 4Fe-4S clusters for various enzymes in Proteobacteria and the SUF system is capable of functioning in the presence of oxidative stress.

children.name: Iron-sulfur cluster assembly SUF system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12089140, Title: A third bacterial system for the assembly of iron-sulfur clusters with homologs in archaea and plastids., Authors: Takahashi Y, Tokumoto U;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2002;277:28380-28383., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12876288, Title: Biogenesis of Fe-S cluster by the bacterial Suf system: SufS and SufE form a new type of cysteine desulfurase., Authors: Loiseau L, Ollagnier-de-Choudens S, Nachin L, Fontecave M, Barras F;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2003;278:38352-38359., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 12554644, Title: SufC: an unorthodox cytoplasmic ABC/ATPase required for [Fe-S] biogenesis under oxidative stress., Authors: Nachin L, Loiseau L, Expert D, Barras F;, Citation: EMBO J. 2003;22:427-437.]
children.description: The iron-sulfur cluster assembly SUF system is one of three iron-sulfur assembly systems present in a wide range of bacteria, archeae, and plastids. The other two mechanisms for iron-sulfur cluster assembly are the ISC (iron-sulfur cluster) system, composed of at least six components and found broadly distributed from bacteria to higher eukaryotes, and the NIF (nitrogen fixation) system, which is required for nitrogenase maturation [1]. The SUF (mobilization of sulfur) system is composed of a six gene cluster with protein complexes responsible for cysteine desulfuration of sulfur atoms from cysteine, cytosolic ATPase activity, and a protein scaffold for iron and sulfur cluster assembly and transfer to protein targets [2]. Operational under stressful growth conditions, such as iron limitation and oxidative stress, the SUF system has been shown to be an important factor for bacterial pathogenicity [3].

children.name: Iron-sulfur cluster assembly iscSUA-hscBA-fdx system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12089140, Title: A third bacterial system for the assembly of iron-sulfur clusters with homologs in archaea and plastids., Authors: Takahashi Y, Tokumoto U;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2002;277:28380-28383.]
children.description: At least three different systems have been described for 2Fe-2S cluster assembly. The NIF system provides an iron-sulfur cluster to nitrogenase in certain nitrogen-fixing species. SUF, described the most recently, can operate despite aerobic stress. This property describes the ISC system as found in E. coli and many other proteobacteria, containing at least the following elements: a characteristic cysteine desulfurase IscS, a characteristic ferredoxin, chaperones called heat shock cognate proteins A and B, and an assembly scaffold protein resembling the N terminus of the scaffold protein of the NIF system [1].

children.name: Iron-sulfur cluster assembly CsdA-CsdE system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15901727, Title: Analysis of the heteromeric CsdA-CsdE cysteine desulfurase, assisting Fe-S cluster biogenesis in Escherichia coli., Authors: Loiseau L, Ollagnier-de Choudens S, Lascoux D, Forest E, Fontecave M, Barras F;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2005;280:26760-26769.]
children.description: The heteromeric complex of CsdA and CsdE plays a role in iron-sulfur (Fe-S) cluster biosynthesis, as do the better-known systems ISC, SUF, and NIF. CdsA, a homolog of SufS, IscS, and NifS, is a cysteine desulfurase catalytic subunit. CdsE, a SufE homolog, physically interacts and accepts a sulfur at Cys-61 (numbered as in Escherichia coli). In contrast to sulfur-accepting components such as NifU and IscU, CsdE does not bind iron and is not viewed as a scaffold on which Fe-S cluster biosynthesis can be completed prior to transfer to other proteins. Rather, the simplicity of this system may reflect a limited role for the maturation of specific Fe-S cluster-containing proteins.

children.name: Cysteine desulfurase, sulfur acceptor subunit CsdE
children.functional_elements: [(ID: Cysteine desulfurase, sulfur acceptor subunit CsdE, Name: Cysteine desulfurase, sulfur acceptor subunit CsdE, Evidences: [(Evidence_IDs: ['IPR017763', 'TIGR03391'], GO Terms: ['GO:0016226'], Sufficient: False)], Required: True)]

children.name: Iron-sulfur cluster assembly NIF system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10639125, Title: NifS-directed assembly of a transient [2Fe-2S] cluster within the NifU protein., Authors: Yuvaniyama P, Agar JN, Cash VL, Johnson MK, Dean DR;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2000;97:599-604., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 15667274, Title: NifU and NifS are required for the maturation of nitrogenase and cannot replace the function of isc-gene products in Azotobacter vinelandii., Authors: Johnson DC, Dos Santos PC, Dean DR;, Citation: Biochem Soc Trans. 2005;33:90-93.]
children.description: Iron-sulfur (FeS) cluster assembly systems include the NIF system, which is part of nitrogen fixation clusters in a number of bacteria, as well as the ISC and SUF systems. The latter two make FeS clusters for a wide variety of proteins, while NIF and a related system called CsdA-CsdE may produce FeS clusters for only a small range of target proteins. The defining components of the NIF-type systems described here are the cysteine desulfurase NifS and the FeS cluster assembly scaffold protein NifU. The terms NifS and NifU are applied not only to components of nitrogen fixation systems, but also to tandem gene pairs in other organisms such as Helicobacter pylori. These NifU-like and NifS-like proteins largely fall into separate clades, and are best modeled by separate HMMs, but are included in this Genome Property as components of NIF-type systems. NifS/NifU or NifS-like/NifU-like pairs may produce FeS clusters for a limited range of target proteins, as in Azotobacter vinelandii, or uniquely within the cell, as in Helicobacter pylori.

children.name: SufBCD complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 20857974, Title: SufD and SufC ATPase activity are required for iron acquisition during in vivo Fe-S cluster formation on SufB., Authors: Saini A, Mapolelo DT, Chahal HK, Johnson MK, Outten FW, Citation: Biochemistry. 2010;49:9402-9412, Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12941942, Title: The SufE protein and the SufBCD complex enhance SufS cysteine desulfurase activity as part of a sulfur transfer pathway for Fe-S cluster assembly in Escherichia coli., Authors: Outten FW, Wood MJ, Munoz FM, Storz G, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2003;278:45713-45719]
children.description: Scaffold complex that assembles an Fe-S cluster. The SufB protomer of the SufBCD complex accepts the atomic sulfur from the sulfur transfer protein SufE (CPX-2125 [SufE dimer], EBI-8844754 [transfer interaction]) and incorporates it into an [4Fe-4S] cluster in an as yet undiscovered manner. SufBCD further transfers the Fe-S cluster to the carrier protein SufA (CPX-2142 [dimer], EBI-8805910 [transfer interaction]). SufBCD is a component of the sufABCDSE operon, which is activated and required under specific conditions such as oxidative stress and iron limitation. The SufBCD complex is a putative ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter complex, inferred by its structural similarity with other ABC transporters. SufC has been shown to be an ATPase whose activity is enhanced by the presence of SufB and SufD [1]. The precise function of FADH2 is not yet clear. Under aerobic conditions FADH2 is oxidised to FAD and dissociates from SufBCD.

children.name: Heme uptake system, NEAT-domain mediated
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 18676371, Title: Demonstration of the iron-regulated surface determinant (Isd) heme transfer pathway in Staphylococcus aureus., Authors: Muryoi N, Tiedemann MT, Pluym M, Cheung J, Heinrichs DE, Stillman MJ;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2008;283:28125-28136., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 17229211, Title: Haem recognition by a Staphylococcus aureus NEAT domain., Authors: Grigg JC, Vermeiren CL, Heinrichs DE, Murphy ME;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2007;63:139-149., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 18725935, Title: Bacillus anthracis secretes proteins that mediate heme acquisition from hemoglobin., Authors: Maresso AW, Garufi G, Schneewind O;, Citation: PLoS Pathog. 2008;4:e1000132., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 14570922, Title: IsdG and IsdI, heme-degrading enzymes in the cytoplasm of Staphylococcus aureus., Authors: Skaar EP, Gaspar AH, Schneewind O;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2004;279:436-443.]
children.description: This system is found in certain lineages of the Bacillus/Clostridium group, including a number of pathogenic species. In order to obtain iron, this system utilizes a number of NEAT domain containing proteins to scavenge heme from host hemoproteins and convey them across the cell wall to an ABC transporter in the cytoplasmic membrane. Cell wall localization of these components is generally mediated by sortases, SrtB being particularly critical to this system in many organisms. Heme is often oxidized to biliverdin by heme oxygenases in the cytoplasm, releasing iron.Genes of this system are generally given "isd" gene symbols where isd stands for Iron-regulated Surface Determinant proteins.

children.name: Heme metabolism pair HutWX
children.description: The hutW and hutX genes are found in Vibrio cholerae next to hutZ, which is essential for heme utilization. HutW is homologous to the heme carrier protein HemS, while HutW is homologous to (but does not complement) the heme biosynthesis protein HemN. The gene pair is occasionally fused, and may perform a salvage-like function, converting one form of heme into another. HutZ, which resembles the PPOX class heme oxidase HugZ, accompanies roughly half of the occurrences of HutW and HutX.

children.name: Nitrogen fixation
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15629911, Title: Maturation of nitrogenase: a biochemical puzzle., Authors: Rubio LM, Ludden PW;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2005;187:405-414.]
children.description: Nitrogen fixation is the conversion of atmospheric nitrogen, N2 (with its difficult-to-cleave triple bond) into usable forms such as NH3. Conditions should be anaerobic or microaerophilic. The characteristic enzyme is nitrogenase, but many other proteins are involved. Nitrogenase is a complex composed of dinitrogenase (MoFe protein), which is a homodimer, and dinitrogenase reductase (Fe protein) that is a heterotetramer. Expected along with nitrogenase are several accessory proteins, the transcriptional regulator NifA, a ferredoxin or flavodoxin, downstream genes for nitrogen assimilation (NtrC, GlnA), and genes for protection from oxygen (e.g. leghemoglobin in root nodule bacteria).

children.name: Nitrogenase, Mo-containing
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 25139995, Title: Reconstruction and minimal gene requirements for the alternative iron-only nitrogenase in Escherichia coli., Authors: Yang J, Xie X, Wang X, Dixon R, Wang YP;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2014;111:E3718-E3725.]
children.description: There are three distict types of nitrogenase system that exist in bacteria and archea, acting in nitrogen fixation. The most common type of nitrogenase contains molybdenum as well as iron (MoFe nitrogenase). Alternative nitrogenases with homologous alpha and beta subunits, but somewhat different sets of accessory proteins, use vanadium and iron, or just iron. All species studied so far with one or more alternative nitrogenases, also contain a MoFe nitrogenase. This genome property consists of the structural subunits of the MoFe nitrogenase [1].

children.name: Nitrogenase, Fe-only

children.description: There are three homologous types of nitrogenase; the common molybdenum-containing, the alternative vanadium (V)-containing, and the alterantive iron (Fe)-only. This Genome Property represents the Fe-only nitrogenase system (which acts in nitrogen fixation) and its accessory proteins. Fe-only nitrogenase is composed of 2 copies each of an alpha, beta and delta subunit, forming a hexameric structure. The exact function of the accessory protein included in this property is not yet known [1].

children.name: Inteins
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11092822, Title: Evolution and Application of Inteins in Candida species: A Review., Authors: Liu XQ;, Citation: Annu Rev Genet. 2000;34:61-76.]
children.description: Inteins are protein insertion sequences that are embedded in host protein sequences. They are post-translationally excised from the host protein by a self-catalytic protein splicing process, in which the intein sequence is precisely excised, and the flanking host protein sequences (N- and C-exteins) are re-ligated to create a functional protein. The region between the N- and C-terminal splicing regions may show endonuclease homology[1].

children.name: Integron
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 14702391, Title: Integrons or super integrons?, Authors: Hall RM, Stokes HW;, Citation: Microbiology. 2004;150:3-4.]
children.description: An integron is a system that enables capture and expression of small mobile elements called cassettes. An integron should contain an intI gene, of any of several classes, encoding an integrase. It should have a promoter to drive expression, an attI site, ability to incorporate cassettes, and multiple attC sites (also called 59-base element) flanking the cassettes. The attC sites may exhibit high homology to each other in a long integron, but are best recognized by imperfect dyad symmetry at their outer ends. A single genome may have several integrons, and one integron may contain dozens of cassettes. Note that an integron cassette with a defective integron integrase, carried by a Tn7 transposon, is called a class 2 integron.

children.name: Toxin-antitoxin system, type II
children.description: Pairs of genes are often found to maintain plasmids by a mechanism of post-segregational killing. One protein is a short-lived antidote, the other a long-lived toxin, and the two encoded together. Loss of the gene pair, as from a cell division in which one of the daughter cells does not receive a copy of the plasmid, leads to loss of the antidote faster than the toxin, and therefore to cell death. Such pairs are called addition modules, and may be chromosomal rather than plasmid. Chromosomal pairs frequently have mRNA-cleaving activity with bacteriostatic rather than bacteriocidal activity, and may benefit the host cell by enabling a persister state in response to certain challenges.

children.name: Protein-coding palindromic elements
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15936655, Title: Discovery of protein-coding palindromic repeats in Wolbachia., Authors: Ogata H, Suhre K, Claverie JM;, Citation: Trends Microbiol. 2005;13:253-255., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 11030655, Title: Selfish DNA in protein-coding genes of Rickettsia., Authors: Ogata H, Audic S, Barbe V, Artiguenave F, Fournier PE, Raoult D, Claverie JM;, Citation: Science. 2000;290:347-350.]
children.description: Two different classes are known, so far, of mobile palindromic elements that insert in-frame into genes of certain obligate intracellular bacteria and code for an amino acid insert in the host protein. In contrast to inteins, the insert is relatively small and does not get spliced out. Rather, it appears the affected protein continues to function because the location of the insert is not destructive to correct protein folding. The two classes described so far are designated RPE, discovered in Rickettsia, and WPE, discovered in Wolbachia.

children.name: Addiction module, RelE-RelB class
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11717402, Title: RelE, a global inhibitor of translation, is activated during nutritional stress., Authors: Christensen SK, Mikkelsen M, Pedersen K, Gerdes K;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2001;98:14328-14333.]
children.description: Toxin-antitoxin gene pairs, called addiction modules, are found often on plasmids but also on the chromosome. These modules can promote plasmid stability in populations by killing daughter cells that don't receive a copy of the plasmid during cell division. The phenomenon, called post-segregational killing, occurs because the antitoxin has a shorter biological half-life than the toxin. Some chromosomal toxin-antitoxin gene pairs appear to act in regulation of cellular processes and are not necessarily selfish genetic elements. The antitoxin generally is a transcription factor. The toxin may act in several ways. This addiction module property describes the RelE system, where RelE acts by cleaving ribosome-associated transcripts.

children.description: This Genome Property collects HMMs that describe characteristic proteins from examples of orbivirus such as bluetongue virus (BTV). Note that NS3A from BTV differs from NS3 by starting from an alternate initiator that makes it 13 amino acids shorter.

children.description: Toxin-antitoxin gene pairs, called addiction modules, are found often on plasmids but also on the chromosome. These modules can promote plasmid stability in populations by killing daughter cells that don't receive a copy of the plasmid during cell division. The phenomenon, called post-segregational killing, occurs because the antitoxin has a shorter biological half-life than the toxin. Some chromosomal toxin-antitoxin gene pairs appear to act in regulation of cellular processes and are not necessarily selfish genetic elements. The antitoxin generally is a transcription factor. The toxin may act in several ways. This addiction module property describes the ParE system where ParE inhibits gyrase and thereby blocks chromosome replication [1].

children.name: HipBA toxin-antitoxin complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 25056321, Title: The bacterial antitoxin HipB establishes a ternary complex with operator DNA and phosphorylated toxin HipA to regulate bacterial persistence., Authors: Wen Y, Behiels E, Felix J, Elegheert J, Vergauwen B, Devreese B, Savvides SN, Citation: Nucleic Acids Res. 2014;42:10134-10147, Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 19150849, Title: Molecular mechanisms of HipA-mediated multidrug tolerance and its neutralization by HipB., Authors: Schumacher MA, Piro KM, Xu W, Hansen S, Lewis K, Brennan RG, Citation: Science. 2009;323:396-401, Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 26222023, Title: HipBA-promoter structures reveal the basis of heritable multidrug tolerance., Authors: Schumacher MA, Balani P, Min J, Chinnam NB, Hansen S, Vulić M, Lewis K, Brennan RG, Citation: Nature. 2015;524:59-64, Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 1715862, Title: Structure and organization of hip, an operon that affects lethality due to inhibition of peptidoglycan or DNA synthesis., Authors: Black DS, Kelly AJ, Mardis MJ, Moyed HS, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1991;173:5732-5739]
children.description: Toxin-antitoxin (TA) complex. TA systems act as effectors of dormancy and persistence and are composed of a toxin, which causes growth arrest by interfering with a vital cellular process, and a cognate antitoxin, which neutralizes the toxin activity during normal growth conditions. Under conditions of stress the antitoxins are selectively degraded, leaving the toxins to exert their toxic effects, leading to growth arrest and dormancy. Type II TA complexes are small protein-protein pairs; under growth conditions, the toxin is bound to the antitoxin, which inhibits its activity. Both the antitoxin and, in most cases, the TA complex bind the TA promoter to repress transcription. Under stress conditions, cellular proteases such as Lon (P0A9M0) and ClpXP (CPX-3176) are activated that preferentially cleave the antitoxins, freeing the toxins to inhibit growth by inhibiting translation or replication, enabling cells to enter a metabolically dormant state until the stress is removed. Complex formation prevents the protein kinase HipA acting as a persistence factor, inducing multi-drug tolerance by triggering growth arrest. HipA activity is inhibited upon binding to HipB through sequestration to the nucleoid and binding to DNA. HipB and HipAB act as transcriptional autoregulators of the hipBA operon.
