children.name: MqsRA toxin-antitoxin complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 26991085, Title: Toxin-antitoxin systems in bacterial growth arrest and persistence., Authors: Page R, Peti W, Citation: Nat Chem Biol. 2016;12:208-214, Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 20041169, Title: Three dimensional structure of the MqsR:MqsA complex: a novel TA pair comprised of a toxin homologous to RelE and an antitoxin with unique properties., Authors: Brown BL, Grigoriu S, Kim Y, Arruda JM, Davenport A, Wood TK, Peti W, Page R, Citation: PLoS Pathog. 2009;5:e1000706]
children.description: Type II toxin-antitoxin (TA) module consisting of MqsR toxins bound to MqsA antitoxin dimer. TA systems act as effectors of dormancy and persistence and are composed of a toxin, which causes growth arrest by interfering with a vital cellular process, and a cognate antitoxin, which neutralizes the toxin activity during normal growth conditions. Under conditions of stress the antitoxins are selectively degraded, leaving the toxins to exert their toxic effects, leading to growth arrest and dormancy. Type II TA complexes are small protein-protein pairs; under growth conditions, the toxin is bound to the antitoxin, which inhibits its activity. Both the antitoxin and, in most cases, the TA complex bind the TA promoter to repress transcription. Under stress conditions, cellular proteases such as Lon (P0A9M0) and ClpXP (CPX-3176) are activated that preferentially cleave the antitoxins, freeing the toxins to inhibit growth by inhibiting translation or replication, enabling cells to enter a metabolically dormant state until the stress is removed. MqsR toxin is the most up-regulated gene in the persister phenotype of cells. When active, MqsA binds its promoter with extremely tight affinity, however this is destabilized by TA complex formation as the binding sites of MqsR and MqsA on DNA overlap and their binding is mutually exclusive. Plays a role in biofilm formation.

children.name: RelBE toxin-antitoxin complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 22981948, Title: The crystal structure of the intact E. coli RelBE toxin-antitoxin complex provides the structural basis for conditional cooperativity., Authors: Bøggild A, Sofos N, Andersen KR, Feddersen A, Easter AD, Passmore LA, Brodersen DE, Citation: Structure. 2012;20:1641-1648, Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 26991085, Title: Toxin-antitoxin systems in bacterial growth arrest and persistence., Authors: Page R, Peti W, Citation: Nat Chem Biol. 2016;12:208-214]
children.description: Type II toxin-antitoxin (TA) module consisting of relA toxin and relB antitoxin. TA systems act as effectors of dormancy and persistence and are composed of a toxin, which causes growth arrest by interfering with a vital cellular process, and a cognate antitoxin, which neutralizes the toxin activity during normal growth conditions. Under conditions of stress the antitoxins are selectively degraded, leaving the toxins to exert their toxic effects, leading to growth arrest and dormancy. Type II TA complexes are small protein-protein pairs; under growth conditions, the toxin is bound to the antitoxin, which inhibits its activity. Both the antitoxin and, in most cases, the TA complex bind the TA promoter to repress transcription. Under stress conditions, cellular proteases such as Lon (P0A9M0) and ClpXP (CPX-3176) are activated that preferentially cleave the antitoxins, freeing the toxins to inhibit growth by inhibiting translation or replication, enabling cells to enter a metabolically dormant state until the stress is removed. Free RelE toxin is capable of cleaving mRNA during translation at the ribosomal A site, thus inhibiting translation during amino acid starvation (the stringent response). The antitoxin, RelB, both binds and inhibits RelE by inducing conformational changes in the RelE active site, and regulates transcription through operator binding and conditional cooperativity controlled by RelE. During nutritional stress, the labile RelB is degraded by Lon, releasing RelE.

children.name: Lipopolysaccharide biosynthesis
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 28551077, Title: Lipopolysaccharide Detection across the Kingdoms of Life., Authors: Kagan JC;, Citation: Trends Immunol. 2017; [Epub ahead of print]]
children.description: Lipopolysaccharide (also known as LPS, lipoglycan and endotoxin) is the major component of the Gram-negative bacterial cell wall. Lipopolysaccharide is composed of three parts, lipid A, a core oligosaccharide, and the O-antigen [1].

children.name: LPS inner core biosynthesis, ketodeoxyoctonate and heptose type
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 26981280, Title: Synthesis and Evaluation of Mannitol-Based Inhibitors for Lipopolysaccharide Biosynthesis., Authors: Johnsson RE;, Citation: Int J Med Chem. 2016;2016:3475235.]
children.description: Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) occurs broadly in Gram-negative bacterial outer membrane. Three parts are termed lipid A, the oligosaccharide core, and O antigen [1]. If lacking the repeating O-antigen, it may be termed Lipooligosaccharide (LOS). The core is often described as having inner and outer regions, and is variable among species that contain LPS/LOS. This property describes a widely distributed common chemistry for the inner core. At least two residues of 3-deoxy-D-manno-oct-2-ulosonic acid (Kdo) are present, one of which has the lipid A moeity is attached. The inner core in E. coli and many other bacteria also contains at least two heptose residues, added by distinct heptosyltransferases I and II.

children.name: KDO(2)-lipid A (Re LPS) biosynthesis and delivery
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 17056748, Title: Characterization of lptA and lptB, two essential genes implicated in lipopolysaccharide transport to the outer membrane of Escherichia coli., Authors: Sperandeo P, Cescutti R, Villa R, Di Benedetto C, Candia D, Dehò G, Polissi A;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2007;189:244-253.]
children.description: Lipid A is a component of the outer leaflet of the outer membrane of most gram-negative bacteria. It is one of three regions of bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS), along with the oligosaccharide core and the repeating O-antigen. In some strains, O-antigen may be missing and the lipid A-containing material may be designated lipooligosaccharide (LOS). Lipid A consists of a disaccharide (often beta-D-GlcN-(1-->6)-D-GlcN) with four attached acyl groups. Lipid A is attached to a 3-deoxy-D-manno-oct-2-ulosonic acid (KDO), a sugar moeity that becomes part of the LPS oligosaccharide inner core. Two of the acyl groups of lipid A are then modified by further acylations into branched structures; acylation varies somewhat by species, and sometimes according to conditions within a species. The inner core typically contains at least two KDO and two heptose residues. The outer core and O-antigen regions are far more variable, and their biosynthesis is modeled in this property. LPS biosynthesis mutational studies have shown that in a number of species, lipid A with two KDO residues but no additional residues of the inner core, is the minimum required form of LPS for viability, called Re LPS or Re endotoxin. This genome property describes a set of well-conserved enzymes for the biosynthesis of KDO(2)-lipid A that resembles, but is not necessarily identical to (nor as active in endotoxin assays as), the Re endotoxin of E. coli, as well as a transporter (or flippase) responsible in most Proteobacteria for positioning lipid A in the outer membrane.

children.name: UDP-N-acetylglucosamine biosynthesis from fructose-6-phosphate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 8407787, Title: Identification of the glmU gene encoding N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphate uridyltransferase in Escherichia coli., Authors: Mengin-Lecreulx D, van Heijenoort J;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1993;175:6150-6157.]
children.description: This pathway converts fructose-6-phosphate in four steps to activated N-acetylglucosamine. GlmS produces glucosamine-6-phosphate. GlmM isomerizes this product to glucosamine-1-phosphate. GlmU, which is bifunctional, adds an acetyl group from acetyl-CoA, then acts as N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase [1]. The product, UDP-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine, is then used both for murein biosynthesis and (in species with LPS) for lipopolysaccharide biosynthesis.

children.name: Protein sorting system, PEP-CTERM/exosortase (generic)
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16930487, Title: Exopolysaccharide-associated protein sorting in environmental organisms: the PEP-CTERM/EpsH system. Application of a novel phylogenetic profiling heuristic., Authors: Haft DH, Paulsen IT, Ward N, Selengut JD;, Citation: BMC Biol. 2006;4:29.]
children.description: This Genome Property describes a proposed protein sorting system associated with exopolysaccharide loci in many Gram-negative bacteria. One hallmark is the presence of a paralogous domain at the C-termini of a substantial number of proteins in a single genome, usually from four to sixty-five. Features of this domain, described by TIGRFAMs model TIGR02595, are a conserved motif PEP, a transmembrane domain, and a cluster of basic residues for a total length of about 24 amino acids. Wecall this domain PEP-CTERM, and note that is shares a number of properties with the the LPXTG-type Gram-positive cell-wall targeting sequence. Another hallmark of this system is the presence of one or more homologs of EpsH (TIGR02602), a highly hydrophobic protein that spans the membrane eight or more times. Its surrounding genes nearly always pertain to exopolysaccharide biosynthesis. We have proposed that TIGR02602 models a transpeptidase that cleaves PEP-CTERM proteins, attaches them transiently to an active site Cys, then attaches them covalently to an unknown substrate for sorting to the outer surface of the cell, closely analogous to the action of sortase in Gram-positive bacteria. We suggest the name exosortase for EpsH homologs involved in this process. In Proteobacterial species with a the PEP-CTERM/exsortase system, a sensor histidine kinase (TIGR02916) and a sigma-54-dependent DNA-binding response regulator (TIGR02915) are present and appear to bind a conserved regulatory site found upstream of most PEP-CTERM genes.

children.name: Protein sorting system, sortase type, LPXTG/SrtA class
children.description: This property describes the common subtype of the sortase system for targeting cell wall proteins in the Firmicutes by recognition of the LPXTG C-terminal motif. The presence of one or more sortases and their target sequences should be universal in Gram-positive organisms with cell walls. Sortase is a transpeptidase; sortases belonging to this Genome Property resemble SrtA, and the sorting signal generally resembles LPXTG. Several SrtA paralogs can be found in some genomes, as well as the substantially different SrtB and other families of sortase and their cognate sequences.

children.name: Protein sorting system, sortase type, SrtB class
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 15028680, Title: Sortase B, a new class of sortase in Listeria monocytogenes., Authors: Bierne H, Garandeau C, Pucciarelli MG, Sabet C, Newton S, Garcia-del Portillo F, Cossart P, Charbit A;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2004;186:1972-1982., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 16247833, Title: Identification of substrates of the Listeria monocytogenes sortases A and B by anon-gel proteomic analysis., Authors: Pucciarelli MG, Calvo E, Sabet C, Bierne H, Cossart P, Garcia-del Portillo F;, Citation: Proteomics. 2005;5:4808-4817., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 11914350, Title: Differential recognition of surface proteins in Streptococcus pyogenes by two sortase gene homologs., Authors: Barnett TC, Scott JR;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2002;184:2181-2191., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 15317792, Title: A novel sortase, SrtC2, from Streptococcus pyogenes anchors a surface protein containing a QVPTGV motif to the cell wall., Authors: Barnett TC, Patel AR, Scott JR;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2004;186:5865-5875.]
children.description: This is a family of sortases and their substrates, less abundant than the housekeeping sortase, SrtA, and the LPXTG-like target sequences [1]. SrtB in Listeria monocytogenes appears to process two classes of signal, NXZTN and NPKXZ [2]. Note that the protein called SrtB in Streptococcus pyogenes [3] is a member of the SrtA family, not the family described here, while the protein called SrtC2 is a member of the SrtB family [4].

children.name: OMP chaperone system: SurA-Skp-DegP
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 17908933, Title: Defining the roles of the periplasmic chaperones SurA, Skp, and DegP in Escherichia coli., Authors: Sklar JG, Wu T, Kahne D, Silhavy TJ;, Citation: Genes Dev. 2007;21:2473-2484.]
children.description: Outer membrane beta-barrel proteins are translocated into the periplasm by the Sec system and subsequently properly folded and inserted into the outer membrane by the beta-barrel assembly machine (Bam). In the periplasm, chaperones prevent misfolding and aggregation, and facilitate the transit across the periplasmic space. The SurA protein appears to be the primary chaperone, at least in E. coli [1], while Skp and DegP may act to rescue any OMPs which fall off of the SurA complex.

children.name: Anchored repeat-class ABC transporter, P. acnes type
children.description: Model TIGR03769 describes a protein region that occurs several times per genome in several Actinobacteria. Typically, it occurs once in an ABC transporter substrate binding protein and two to three times in a neighboring gene that is anchored to the Gram-positive cell wall by a sortase/LPXTG system. This genome property describes the three genes of the ABC transporter cassette and the neighboring LPXTG-anchored repeat protein. This system is analogous to the NEAT domain system found in some pathogenic Firmicutes.

children.name: Protein sorting system, proteobacterial dedicated sortase type
children.description: This property represents a specialization of SrtA-like sortase systems in the Proteobacteria, including many marine species. In contrast to sortase A systems in the Firmicutes, where a single transpeptidase serves multiple target proteins, this system is characterized by a single sorting target protein, conserved across species, adjacent to the sorting enzyme itself. In a majority of species with this system, the sortase and target pair are accompanied by a histidine kinase and response regulator pair.

children.name: Type III secretion
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11018143, Title: Assembly and function of type III secretory systems., Authors: Cornelis GR, Van Gijsegem F;, Citation: Annu Rev Microbiol. 2000;54:735-774., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 15629935, Title: The Erwinia chrysanthemi type III secretion system is required for multicellular behavior., Authors: Yap MN, Yang CH, Barak JD, Jahn CE, Charkowski AO;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2005;187:639-648., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 15808742, Title: Bioinformatics, genomics and evolution of non-flagellar type-III secretion systems: a Darwinian perspective., Authors: Pallen MJ, Beatson SA, Bailey CM;, Citation: FEMS Microbiol Rev. 2005;29:201-229.]
children.description: Type III secretion systems are found in a number of pathogenenic gram-negative bacteria. These systems consist of approximately twenty-five translocation proteins, as well as those proteins that are transported either across the bacterial inner and outer membrane, into the medium, or further across a eukaryotic target cell membrane. Substrates for type III secretion are not cleaved during transport, although the signal for transport appears to lie near the N-terminus (or in the RNA); chaperones act as well for some substrates and may be a second signal. Proteins delivered to the target cell cytosol and active in pathogenesis are termed effectors. Type III secretion systems resemble some of the flagellar export apparatus. In some cases, a type III pilus is observed and required for effector delivery. Gene nomeclature transposes across genomes: ysc in Yersinia, bsc in Bordetella, esc in enteropathogenic E. coli, hrc in plant pathogens, etc., so that YscD, EscD, HrcD, etc. are homologous and functionally analogous [1,2,3].

children.name: Type II secretion
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11309111, Title: Biology of type II secretion., Authors: Sandkvist M;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2001;40:271-283., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 11726509, Title: Involvement of the twin-arginine translocation system in protein secretion via the type II pathway., Authors: Voulhoux R, Ball G, Ize B, Vasil ML, Lazdunski A, Wu LF, Filloux A;, Citation: EMBO J. 2001;20(23):6735-6741.]
children.description: Type II secretion is also known as the main terminal branch of the general secretion pathway. Type II secretion systems transport folded proteins across the outer membrane. These proteins have previously come unfolded across the inner membrane by the general secretory pathway (Sec) and are then fully folded in the periplasm [1]. It has been reported that some proteins may cross the inner membrane by Tat (Sec-independent) protein export rather than by Sec prior to type II secretion [2].

children.name: Type I secretion
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11157948, Title: Subset of hybrid eukaryotic proteins is exported by the type I secretion system of Erwinia chrysanthemi., Authors: Palacios JL, Zaror I, Martínez P, Uribe F, Opazo P, Socías T, Gidekel M, Venegas A., Citation: J Bacteriol. 2001;183(4):1346-1358.]
children.description: A type I protein secretion system is an ABC (ATP-binding cassette) transporter. The system is Sec-independent. ATP drives the transport of target proteins across both inner and outer membranes and into the extracellular medium. There is no cleaved N-terminal signal sequence. Instead, the type I system recognizes C-terminal information, localized to the last 50 amino acids or less. Characteristic sequence found nearby, such as repeats of the motif GGXGXDXXX in Erwinia, may play a supporting role, possibly for chaperoning the rest of the protein rather than for recognition of the export signal [1].This property does NOT cover ABC transporter-mediated processing and secretion of class II bacteriocins of certain Gram-positive bacteria.

children.name: Tat (Sec-independent) protein export
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12562823, Title: Prokaryotic utilization of the twin-arginine translocation pathway: a genomic survey., Authors: Dilks K, Rose RW, Hartmann E, Pohlschröder M;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2003;185:1478-1483., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 17901208, Title: Structural diversity in twin-arginine signal peptide-binding proteins., Authors: Maillard J, Spronk CA, Buchanan G, Lyall V, Richardson DJ, Palmer T, Vuister GW, Sargent F;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2007;104:15641-15646.]
children.description: The twin-arginine dependent translocation (Tat) system of protein transport differs from Sec-dependent translocation in that the Tat system transports folded proteins while Sec feeds through unfolded, nascent proteins that fold after they cross the membrane. The significance is that Tat lets cofactors such as flavins or iron-sulfur clusters be retained during transit across the membrane. Targets for the system can often be recognized by a characteristic signal sequence with an Arg-Arg motif. The target proteins usually are predicted to perform redox functions [1]. This property reflects detection of the whole system: components of the translocase and at least one example of a predicted Tat signal sequence. Every system must have at least one TatA homolog (other than TatB) and at least one TatC homolog. TatB occurs only in Proteobacteria and is required at least in E. coli. Recently, several proteins (TorD, NapD) have been shown to act as chaperones that bind the TAT signal peptide of a specific protein and delay translocation until the cofactor has bound [2].

children.name: Lipoprotein localization system lolABCDE
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10783239, Title: A new ABC transporter mediating the detachment of lipid-modified proteins from membranes., Authors: Yakushi T, Masuda K, Narita S, Matsuyama S, Tokuda H;, Citation: Nat Cell Biol. 2000;2:212-218., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12823819, Title: A mutation in the membrane subunit of an ABC transporter LolCDE complex causing outer membrane localization of lipoproteins against their inner membrane-specific signals., Authors: Narita S, Kanamaru K, Matsuyama S, Tokuda H;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2003;49:167-177., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 11673422, Title: Deletion of lolB, encoding an outer membrane lipoprotein, is lethal for Escherichia coli and causes accumulation of lipoprotein localization intermediates in the periplasm., Authors: Tanaka K, Matsuyama SI, Tokuda H;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2001;183:6538-6542.]
children.description: Bacterial lipoproteins have a modified amino terminal Cys residue with a covalently attached lipid moiety that serves as a membrane anchor. The lol system is responsible for moving lipoproteins from the periplasmic side of the inner membrane to the periplasmic side of the outer membrane. LolD is homologous to the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transport family [1,2]. LolC and LolE are homologous to each other (in species that have both rather than just one) and have several membrane-spanning segments, much like ABC transport permeases[3]. However, the LolCDE complex differs from other ABC transporters in that is does not move a substrate across a membrane. Instead, it detaches lipoproteins from the inner membrane. LolA and LolB act to chaperone lipoproteins, including LolB itself, to the outer membrane. This system is less broadly distributed than the lgt/lsp/lnt system for lipoprotein N-terminal modification.

children.name: Sec system preprotein translocase
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 22411975, Title: The bacterial Sec-translocase: structure and mechanism., Authors: Lycklama A Nijeholt JA, Driessen AJ;, Citation: Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci. 2012;367:1016-1028.]
children.description: This property describes the bacterial preprotein translocase Sec[1]. The analogous process occurs in eukaryotes and archaea (little studied in the archaea), but the component proteins are different enough not to be described by the same set of hidden Markov models. SecB is a cytosolic export-specific chaperone in E. coli and some related species, but is not broadly distributed. SecA, the ATPase that powers the translocase, is a peripheral membrane protein. SecY, SecE, and SecG form the heterotrimeric translocase, although SecG is not essential at some temperatures. SecD, SecG, and YajC form an accessory complex that may prevent backsliding of proteins being translocated, and may not be essential proteins.

children.name: Protein sorting system, PEP-CTERM/exosortase (generic)
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16930487, Title: Exopolysaccharide-associated protein sorting in environmental organisms: the PEP-CTERM/EpsH system. Application of a novel phylogenetic profiling heuristic., Authors: Haft DH, Paulsen IT, Ward N, Selengut JD;, Citation: BMC Biol. 2006;4:29.]
children.description: This Genome Property describes a proposed protein sorting system associated with exopolysaccharide loci in many Gram-negative bacteria. One hallmark is the presence of a paralogous domain at the C-termini of a substantial number of proteins in a single genome, usually from four to sixty-five. Features of this domain, described by TIGRFAMs model TIGR02595, are a conserved motif PEP, a transmembrane domain, and a cluster of basic residues for a total length of about 24 amino acids. Wecall this domain PEP-CTERM, and note that is shares a number of properties with the the LPXTG-type Gram-positive cell-wall targeting sequence. Another hallmark of this system is the presence of one or more homologs of EpsH (TIGR02602), a highly hydrophobic protein that spans the membrane eight or more times. Its surrounding genes nearly always pertain to exopolysaccharide biosynthesis. We have proposed that TIGR02602 models a transpeptidase that cleaves PEP-CTERM proteins, attaches them transiently to an active site Cys, then attaches them covalently to an unknown substrate for sorting to the outer surface of the cell, closely analogous to the action of sortase in Gram-positive bacteria. We suggest the name exosortase for EpsH homologs involved in this process. In Proteobacterial species with a the PEP-CTERM/exsortase system, a sensor histidine kinase (TIGR02916) and a sigma-54-dependent DNA-binding response regulator (TIGR02915) are present and appear to bind a conserved regulatory site found upstream of most PEP-CTERM genes.

children.name: Protein sorting system, sortase type, LPXTG/SrtA class
children.description: This property describes the common subtype of the sortase system for targeting cell wall proteins in the Firmicutes by recognition of the LPXTG C-terminal motif. The presence of one or more sortases and their target sequences should be universal in Gram-positive organisms with cell walls. Sortase is a transpeptidase; sortases belonging to this Genome Property resemble SrtA, and the sorting signal generally resembles LPXTG. Several SrtA paralogs can be found in some genomes, as well as the substantially different SrtB and other families of sortase and their cognate sequences.

children.description: This is a family of sortases and their substrates, less abundant than the housekeeping sortase, SrtA, and the LPXTG-like target sequences [1]. SrtB in Listeria monocytogenes appears to process two classes of signal, NXZTN and NPKXZ [2]. Note that the protein called SrtB in Streptococcus pyogenes [3] is a member of the SrtA family, not the family described here, while the protein called SrtC2 is a member of the SrtB family [4].

children.name: Protein sorting system, putative, exosortase G class
children.description: For several non-pathogenic Gram-positive bacteria, a protein family showing considerable sequence similarity to the proposed exosortases of Gram-negative bacteria occurs in a conserved gene neighborhood. This property describes that neighborhood, which also includes a glycosyltransferase and a domain related to 6-pyruvoyl tetrahydropterin synthases. These regions also include a family of proteins in the which the well-conserved C-terminal region (TIGR04145) resembles PEP-CTERM and LPXTG protein C-terminal regions. This last family may be the protein-sorting target.

children.name: Type VI secretion
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16432199, Title: Identification of a conserved bacterial protein secretion system in Vibrio cholerae using the Dictyostelium host model system., Authors: Pukatzki S, Ma AT, Sturtevant D, Krastins B, Sarracino D, Nelson WC, Heidelberg JF, Mekalanos JJ;, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2006;103:1528-1533., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 17558395, Title: Threonine phosphorylation post-translationally regulates protein secretion in Pseudomonas aeruginosa., Authors: Mougous JD, Gifford CA, Ramsdell TL, Mekalanos JJ;, Citation: Nat Cell Biol. 2007;9:797-803., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 16930487, Title: Exopolysaccharide-associated protein sorting in environmental organisms: the PEP-CTERM/EpsH system. Application of a novel phylogenetic profiling heuristic., Authors: Haft DH, Paulsen IT, Ward N, Selengut JD;, Citation: BMC Biol. 2006;4:29., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 16763151, Title: A virulence locus of Pseudomonas aeruginosa encodes a protein secretion apparatus., Authors: Mougous JD, Cuff ME, Raunser S, Shen A, Zhou M, Gifford CA, Goodman AL, Joachimiak G, Ordoñez CL, Lory S, Walz T, Joachimiak A, Mekalanos JJ;, Citation: Science. 2006;312:1526-1530., Ref 5, Pubmed ID: 15228535, Title: Use of proteomics to identify novel virulence determinants that are required for Edwardsiella tarda pathogenesis., Authors: Rao PS, Yamada Y, Tan YP, Leung KY;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2004;53:573-586., Ref 6, Pubmed ID: 20865170, Title: Burkholderia type VI secretion systems have distinct roles in eukaryotic and bacterial cell interactions., Authors: Schwarz S, West TE, Boyer F, Chiang WC, Carl MA, Hood RD, Rohmer L, Tolker-Nielsen T, Skerrett SJ, Mougous JD;, Citation: PLoS Pathog. 2010;6:e1001068.]
children.description: The protein secretion system now called type VI (T6SS) has been described by Pukatzki, et al. [1], Mougous. et al. [2] and others. Two components of the system resemble components of type IV secretion systems (T4SS). Many species that carry this system have known pathogenic activity, but T6SS may be directed against other bacteria rather than eukaryotic cells. In addition to protein families for this system identified in various publications, several were identified by the partial phylogenetic programming algorithm [3], supported by proximity to other type VI secretion genes.

children.name: OMP chaperone system: SurA-Skp-DegP
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 17908933, Title: Defining the roles of the periplasmic chaperones SurA, Skp, and DegP in Escherichia coli., Authors: Sklar JG, Wu T, Kahne D, Silhavy TJ;, Citation: Genes Dev. 2007;21:2473-2484.]
children.description: Outer membrane beta-barrel proteins are translocated into the periplasm by the Sec system and subsequently properly folded and inserted into the outer membrane by the beta-barrel assembly machine (Bam). In the periplasm, chaperones prevent misfolding and aggregation, and facilitate the transit across the periplasmic space. The SurA protein appears to be the primary chaperone, at least in E. coli [1], while Skp and DegP may act to rescue any OMPs which fall off of the SurA complex.

children.name: Protein sorting system, GlyGly-CTERM/rhombosortase
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 22194940, Title: GlyGly-CTERM and rhombosortase: a C-terminal protein processing signal in a many-to-one pairing with a rhomboid family intramembrane serine protease., Authors: Haft DH, Varghese N;, Citation: PLoS One. 2011;6:e28886., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 21385872, Title: Proteomic analysis of the Vibrio cholerae type II secretome reveals new proteins, including three related serine proteases., Authors: Sikora AE, Zielke RA, Lawrence DA, Andrews PC, Sandkvist M;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2011;286:16555-16566.]
children.description: The GlyGly-CTERM domain, previously called the gammaproteobacterial enzyme C-terminal transmembrane domain or rhombotail, appears to be a protein sorting signal analogous to LPXTG and PEP-CTERM. Every genome that encodes a set of GlyGly-CTERM proteins also encodes a rhomboid family enzyme, designated rhombosortase, in a many-to-one relationship. Rhomboid proteases are serine proteases with the active site Ser within the membrane, and they are capable of cleaving hydrophobic transmembrane segments. In general, genomes that encode GlyGly-CTERM proteins and rhombosortase also encode a type 2 secretion system (T2SS). Several GlyGly-CTERM proteins have been shown to undergo T2SS-mediated secretion.

children.name: Protein sorting system, KxYKxGKxW class
children.description: Analogous to YSIRK, this property describes a subclass of N-terminal signal sequence in Firmicutes (low-GC Gram-positive bacteria). As with YSIRK, many proteins with this N-terminal domain have an LPXTG C-terminal anchor. However, most of these proteins have extended regions of low-complexity sequence, usually serine-rich. We propose that this signal domain is recognized by cellular machinery that delays protein translocation until glycosylation or other post-translational modifications are complete.

children.name: Exosporium

children.description: The exosporium is an outermost extra surface layer of spores formed by some members of the genus Bacillus, including pathogens B. anthracis and B. cereus. It consists of a basal layer and a nap of hair-like filaments.

children.name: Protein sorting system, proteobacterial dedicated sortase type
children.description: This property represents a specialization of SrtA-like sortase systems in the Proteobacteria, including many marine species. In contrast to sortase A systems in the Firmicutes, where a single transpeptidase serves multiple target proteins, this system is characterized by a single sorting target protein, conserved across species, adjacent to the sorting enzyme itself. In a majority of species with this system, the sortase and target pair are accompanied by a histidine kinase and response regulator pair.

children.name: Type VII secretion, Actinobacteria form
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 19876390, Title: Systematic genetic nomenclature for type VII secretion systems., Authors: Bitter W, Houben EN, Bottai D, Brodin P, Brown EJ, Cox JS, Derbyshire K, Fortune SM, Gao LY, Liu J, Gey van Pittius NC, Pym AS, Rubin EJ, Sherman DR, Cole ST, Brosch R;, Citation: PLoS Pathog. 2009;5:e1000507.]
children.description: Type VII secretion (T7S) (also called ESAT-6-, SNM-, or ESX-secretion) occurs in Mycobacterium. Mycobacterium has an impermeable cell envelope that contains long-chain mycolic acids in an outer membrane; T7S provides a means to transport proteins through this barrier. Multiple T7S loci can occur in one species, with different secretion targets for different systems. The system includes a subtilisin-like protease called mycosin and membrane proteins with a new nomenclature starting with ecc (esx conserved component).

children.name: Protein sorting system, putative, exosortase F class
children.description: This system occurs in the lineage Bacteriodetes, and contains a homolog to exosortase (EpsH). Like archaeal homologs, it is shorter by about 70 amino acids towards the N terminus, and it lacks an EpsI-like domain. Species with this system lack a classical PEP-CTERM, PEF-CTERM, or PGF-CTERM-like protein sorting C-terminal domain.

children.name: Protein sorting system, VPXXXP-CTERM/archaeosortase B
children.description: This Genome Property is a strictly archaeal, narrowly distributed protein sorting system, featuring a variant class of exosortase (TIGR04144) and five to nine target proteins per genome with the VPXXXP-CTERM target sequence (TIGR04143). Target proteins tend to be repetitive and most show extensive mutual sequence homology. The first identified species with this system are Methanohalophilus mahii DSM 5219 and Methanohalobium evestigatum Z-7303.

children.name: Protein sorting system, cyano-PEP-CTERM class
children.description: This Genome Property describes a uniquely cyanobacterial subclass of the PEP-CTERM/exosortase system, restricted to but found in nearly every cyanobacterium outside of Prochlorococcus. The PEP-CTERM variant is somewhat longer at its C terminus, with much stronger conservation throughout the transmembrane region. At least one of two forms of cyanobacterial-restricted exosortase (cyanosortase) always occurs as well, occasionally adjacent to a PEP-CTERM protein.

children.name: Protein sorting system, VPEID-CTERM/exosortase E
children.description: This protein-sorting system occurs so far only in the alpha Proteobacteria. The system is largely dedicated, in the sense that the presumed substrate is usually one-per-genome and usually adjacent. Substrates contain the motif (V)PEID and are among the smallest of any proposed exosortase targets. The processing enzyme is an unusual fusion of an N-terminal exosortase region and a C-terminal region related to eukaryotic CAAX prenyl proteases and bacterial bacteriocin self-immunity proteins.

children.name: Protein sorting system, PIP-CTERM/archaeosortase D
children.description: This Genome Property is a strictly archaeal dedicated protein sorting system, featuring a variant class of archaeosortase (TIGR04175) and always exactly one target protein, with target sequence PIP-CTERM (TIGR04173). In each cassette known so far, a short protein with a class III signal peptide sits between the two enzymes.

These occur in a range of species that include Porphyromonas gingivalis, Fibrobacter succinogenes, Flavobacterium johnsoniae, Cytophaga hutchinsonii, Gramella forsetii, Prevotella intermedia, and Salinibacter ruber.

children.name: Protein sorting system, putative, exosortase J class
children.description: This Genome Property describes a paralogous system from Acidobacterium sp. MP5ACTX8. One component is a novel exosortase subtype designated XrtJ, with a large unique C-terminal region. The other component is its putative target, consisting of an N-terminal signal sequence ending in a suggestive GC motif, then a PEP-CTERM-like motif PExP, then a C-terminal transmembrane domain ending in a basic cluster, all in ~ 62 residues.

children.name: Protein sorting system, PEFG-CTERM/thaumarchaeosortase
children.description: Thaumarchaeosortase (archaeosortase G, ArtG) is a member of the exosortase/archaeosortase family of putative protein-processing enzymes. It is restricted to the Thaumarchaeota, a branch of the Archaea. Species with ArtG each have roughly ten sequences with a C-terminal putative protein-sorting domain, PEFG-CTERM. This system is unusual in that the Cys conserved in all other subfamilies described in the exosortase/archaeosortase family, and thought to be part of the active site, is replaced by Ser in ArtG.

children.name: Type V secretion
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 22411980, Title: Type V secretion: mechanism(s) of autotransport through the bacterial outer membrane., Authors: Leo JC, Grin I, Linke D;, Citation: Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci. 2012;367:1088-1101.]
children.description: Type V secretion systems (T5SS) are most commonly the classical monomeric autotransporters (type Va), in which a C-terminal outer membrane (OM) beta barrel domain functions as a translocator through the OM for an N-terminal passenger domain of the same polypeptide chain. Many type Va autotransporters cleave autocatalytically to release the passenger domain. In type Vb systems, called two-partner secretion systems, the passenger and translocator domains are in separate polypeptides. Additional variant forms Vc, Vd, and Ve have also been described. A special type of signal peptide (PF13018) tethers the nascent polypeptide chain to the Sec apparatus in some autotransporters to allow proper completion of C-terminal domain folding in the OM.

children.name: Protein sorting system, vault protein/exosortase N
children.description: This dedicated protein-sorting system occurs so far only in the class Bacteriodetes or in the genus Leptospira. The two proteins are exosortase N and a member of the vault protein inter-alpha-trypsin inhibitor (VIT) family. The VIT family protein PEP-CTERM region usually begins VPEPxEWxL, but usually scores poorly to the generic PEP-CTERM model.

children.name: Protein sorting system, CGP-CTERM/unknown of Thermococcaceae
children.description: This C-terminal protein sorting signal domain CGP-CTERM (TIGR04288) is restricted to the the family Thermococcaceae (including Thermococcus, Pyrococcus, and Palaeococcus) within the Euryarchaeota. It may be universal in that family. The sorting family is unknown. By analogy to the sortase, exosortase/archaeosortase, and rhombosortase systems, it is predicted that some protein sorting and processing enzyme recognizes and cleaves the C-terminal region. The unknown putative sorting enzyme may act as a transpeptidase.

children.name: Protein sorting system, Synergist-CTERM/unknown of Synergistetes
children.description: This property describes a putative bacterial C-terminal protein-sorting system restricted to the Synergistetes, but not universal in that lineage. Model genomes from at least seven genera average ten proteins apiece with the Synergist-CTERM signal. Some protein-sorting signals have the signature motif separated from the transmembrane helix (TM) by a spacer region (e.g. LPXTG and MYXO-CTERM) while others are have it flush against the TM (PGF-CTERM, GlyGly-CTERM, and this one). The lack of spacer suggests that the unknown sorting enzyme is a multiple membrane-spanning protein, like archaeosortase and rhombosortase, rather than a predominantly hydrophilic enzyme like sortase, whose targets have a spacer.

children.name: Small molecule transport
children.description: The translocation of small molecules and ions across biological membranes or other layers.

children.name: PTS transport system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 28168775, Title: Structural characterization of the PTS IIA and IIB proteins associated with pneumococcal fucose utilization., Authors: Higgins MA, Hamilton AM, Boraston AB;, Citation: Proteins. 2017;]
children.description: Phosphotransferase system (PTS) is a phosphorylation cascade that allows various carbohydrates to be transported accross a membrane at the expense of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP). First, a phosphoryl group is donated from PEP to a general (non sugar-specific) enzyme I (phosphotransferase system, enzyme I), and then on to a phosphocarrier protein (HPr). HPr then dontaes the phosphoryl group to the sugar-specific EIIA (enzyme IIA), and then on to EIIB (enzyme IIB), before being transferred to the incoming carbohydrate. The carbohydrate is transported by EIIC (enzyme IIC), and occasionally EIID (enzyme IID), which are sugar-specific transmembrane components [1].

children.name: Potassium-transporting ATPase KdpFABC
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 14604015, Title: The roles and regulation of potassium in bacteria., Authors: Epstein W;, Citation: Prog Nucleic Acid Res Mol Biol. 2003;75:293-320., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 11248697, Title: Analysis of KdpC of the K(+)-transporting KdpFABC complex of Escherichia coli., Authors: Gassel M, Altendorf K;, Citation: Eur J Biochem. 2001;268:1772-1781.]
children.description: The Kdp complex is a high affinity P-type ATPase potassium ion transport system, found widely distributed among prokaryotes. Regulated by increases in osmolarity and/or reduction in external potassium, Kdp is the only K+ transport system whose expression is regulated by environmental conditions [1]. Kdp is composed of four membrane-bound subunits responsible for potassium ion binding and transport, ATP hydrolysis, and complex assembly and stability [2]. Not defined by this property are the sensor kinase and response regulator components, which once stimulated by specific environmental signals, induce expression of the adjacent Kdp gene cluster [1,2].

children.name: TRAP-T (tripartite ATP-independent periplasmic transporters) family transporters
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11524131, Title: The tripartite ATP-independent periplasmic (TRAP) transporters of bacteria and archaea., Authors: Kelly DJ, Thomas GH;, Citation: FEMS Microbiol Rev. 2001;25:405-424., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 10627041, Title: TRAP transporters: an ancient family of extracytoplasmic solute-receptor-dependent secondary active transporters., Authors: Rabus R, Jack DL, Kelly DJ, Saier MH;, Citation: Microbiology. 1999;145 ( Pt 12):3431-3445.]
children.description: This property represents the presence of three-subunit transporters related to the DctPQM system for dicarboxylate transport in Rhodobacter capsulatus. These are secondary transporters, energized by ion gradients, rather than primary transporters powered by ATP directly [1]. The acronym TRAP, or TRAP-T, stands for Tripartite ATP-independent Periplasmic Transporters. The characteristic architecture includes an integral membrane protein with 12 predicted transmembrane (TM) regions (e.g.DctM) and another with 4 predicted TM regions (e.g. DctQ). These two are fused in some species [2]. Also present is an extracytoplasmic solute receptor (ESR). In addition to C4 dicarboxylates, substrates moved by related transporters appear to include mannitol, aspartate derivative ectoine, and other as yet uncharacterized solutes. Some bacteria, such as Bradyrhizobium japonicum, may contain over a dozen such transporters.

children.description: This property represents an ABC-type transporter for inorganic phosphate P(i), consisting of genes related to the pstSCAB genes in Escherichia coli. In E. coli,pstSCAB represents a high-affinity transporter and is induced by low external P(i) concentrations; a constitutive, low affinity transporter PitA, is also found[1]. Included in this property is PhoU, a regulatory protein of unknown mechanism, generally found adjacent to the pstSCAB genes.

children.name: Sulfate/thiosulfate ABC transporter
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 7608089, Title: Sulfate and thiosulfate transport in Escherichia coli K-12: evidence for a functional overlapping of sulfate- and thiosulfate-binding proteins., Authors: Sirko A, Zatyka M, Sadowy E, Hulanicka D;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1995;177:4134-4136., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 3897189, Title: Single transporter for sulfate, selenate, and selenite in Escherichia coli K-12., Authors: Lindblow-Kull C, Kull FJ, Shrift A;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1985;163:1267-1269., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 11421278, Title: Molybdate transport., Authors: Self WT, Grunden AM, Hasona A, Shanmugam KT;, Citation: Res Microbiol. 2001;152:311-321.]
children.description: This property describes an ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter complex for sulfate and some related anions. Gene symbols for these proteins reflect a role of sulfate import in cysteine biosynthesis. The complex consists of four proteins, an ATP-binding protein CysA, two homologous permeases CysT and CysW, and a binding protein. In the model bacterium Escherichia coli, two binding proteins designated Sbp and CysP are present, and appear to facilitate transport of both sulfate and thiosulfate ions [1]. Unlike the case for phosphate uptake, ABC transport appears to be the only mechanism for sulfate uptake. An older report finds the sulfate transporter in E. coli is also the sole transporter for selenate and selenite [2], and a review on the molybdate ABC transporter notes that, in absense of such a transporter, the sulfate transporter can take up molybdate [3].

children.name: Molybdate ABC transporter
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11421278, Title: Molybdate transport., Authors: Self WT, Grunden AM, Hasona A, Shanmugam KT;, Citation: Res Microbiol. 2001;152:311-321.]
children.description: The high-affinity molybdate ABC transporter imports molybdate for the biosythesis of cofactors such as molybdopterin. Three structural components of this typical ABC transporter are the ATPase subunit, permease, and binding protein. These structural components appear in three gene clusters. A molybdate transport repressor is included as a non-required part of the system. It is noted that molybdate can also be transported by some sulfate/thiosulfate ABC transporters and non-specific anion transporters [1].

children.name: Ion-motive antiporter cycles
children.description: Properties in this category describe the general class of biological system in which an essentially irreversible enzymatic process (such as decarboxylation) converts one substrate of an antiporter into the other, so that extrusion of the enzymatic product leads to import of new substrate. An example of such a system is the pairing of asparate decarboxylase (which produces alanine plus CO2) with an aspartate alanine antiporter. The net result of each cycle is removal of one cytosolic proton, therefore such systems can and do confer acid resistance.

children.description: Arginine may be degraded to generate ammonia, ATP and ornithine via citrulline and carbamoyl phosphate. The ornithine may be further processed via putrescine.

children.description: This Genome Property represents a proton-motive cycle. A cycle of decarboxylating an aspartate to alanine plus CO2, then exchanging the cytosolic alanine for an extracellular asparate, has the net effect of consuming one proton. Analogous systems for antiport of substrates related by decarboxylation include the pairing of an acid-induced arginine decarboxylase with an arginine-agmatine antiporter as in Escherichia coli.

children.description: The decarboxylation of L-ornithine to putrescine consumes a proton. Exchange of putrescine for L-ornithine by an antiporter completes a cycle that effectively removes a cytosolic protein. Decarboxylation/antiporter systems for this and other (e.g. aspartate-alanine) substrate pairs can provide protection against acidic pH.

children.name: Decarboxylation/antiport proton-motive cycle: oxalate-formate
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 7823041, Title: Bacterial anion exchange: reductionist and integrative approaches to membrane biology., Authors: Maloney PC, Yan RT, Abe K;, Citation: J Exp Biol. 1994;196:471-482., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 2708365, Title: Oxalate:formate exchange. The basis for energy coupling in Oxalobacter., Authors: Anantharam V, Allison MJ, Maloney PC;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 1989;264:7244-7250., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 18359395, Title: The roles and mechanisms of intestinal oxalate transport in oxalate homeostasis., Authors: Hatch M, Freel RW;, Citation: Semin Nephrol. 2008;28:143-151.]
children.description: This Genome Property represents a proton-motive cycle. The cycle of decarboxylating oxalate, a dicarboxylic acid, to formate plus CO2, then exchanging the cytosolic formate for an extracellular oxalate, has the net effect of consuming one proton. This property has been studied extensively in Oxalobacter formigenes, which appears in the human microbiome and affects oxalate homeostasis.

children.name: Oxalate degradation
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16517636, Title: Transcriptional and functional analysis of oxalyl-coenzyme A (CoA) decarboxylase and formyl-CoA transferase genes from Lactobacillus acidophilus., Authors: Azcarate-Peril MA, Bruno-Bárcena JM, Hassan HM, Klaenhammer TR;, Citation: Appl Environ Microbiol. 2006;72:1891-1899., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12844490, Title: The crystal structure of the Escherichia coli YfdW gene product reveals a new fold of two interlaced rings identifying a wide family of CoA transferases., Authors: Gruez A, Roig-Zamboni V, Valencia C, Campanacci V, Cambillau C;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2003;278:34582-34586.]
children.description: A two-enzyme pathway degrades oxalate, a toxic metabolite. Formyl-CoA transferase transfers coenzyme A from formyl-CoA to oxalate, leaving formate. Oxalyl-CoA decarboxylase, a TPP-containing enzyme, removes C02 to regenerate formyl-CoA. The net result is conversion of oxalate to formate and CO2. This system was originally described in Oxalobacter formigenes from the human gut, and is found in a number of other gut bacteria.

children.name: Phosphonates ABC transport
children.description: Phosphonates are a varied class of compound with a direct C-P bond that can be significantly more stable than indirect C-O-P bond of organic phosphates. Phosphonates may be toxic but also may be utilized as a sorce of phosphorus, carbon, and energy. Some species appear to have a (sometimes two) membrane-associated C-P lyase complex, PhnGHIJKLM, for degradation of many different (but not all) phosphonates, while other species have single gene-encoded phosphonatases active on specific compounds. This property represents the presence of transporters for phosphonates and related C-P bond-containing compounds (e.g. phosphites); it should be found in association with either the C-P lysase membrane complex or specific phoshonatases, but not all of the latter are known.

children.name: Tol-Pal system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11200223, Title: Organisation and evolution of the tol-pal gene cluster., Authors: Sturgis JN;, Citation: J Mol Microbiol Biotechnol. 2001;3:113-122., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 16207916, Title: Tol-Pal proteins are critical cell envelope components of Erwinia chrysanthemi affecting cell morphology and virulence., Authors: Dubuisson JF, Vianney A, Hugouvieux-Cotte-Pattat N, Lazzaroni JC;, Citation: Microbiology. 2005;151:3337-3347., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 12486055, Title: Transcriptional organization of the Pseudomonas putida tol-oprL genes., Authors: Llamas MA, Ramos JL, Rodríguez-Herva JJ;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2003;185:184-195., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 11959124, Title: The YbgC protein encoded by the ybgC gene of the tol-pal gene cluster of Haemophilus influenzae catalyzes acyl-coenzyme A thioester hydrolysis., Authors: Zhuang Z, Song F, Martin BM, Dunaway-Mariano D;, Citation: FEBS Lett. 2002;516:161-163., Ref 5, Pubmed ID: 11722743, Title: The TolQ-TolR proteins energize TolA and share homologies with the flagellar motor proteins MotA-MotB., Authors: Cascales E, Lloubès R, Sturgis JN;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2001;42:795-807., Ref 6, Pubmed ID: 14731286, Title: Deletion analyses of the peptidoglycan-associated lipoprotein Pal reveals three independent binding sequences including a TolA box., Authors: Cascales E, Lloubès R;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2004;51:873-885., Ref 7, Pubmed ID: 12896989, Title: Role of Pseudomonas putida tol-oprL gene products in uptake of solutes through the cytoplasmic membrane., Authors: Llamas MA, Rodríguez-Herva JJ, Hancock RE, Bitter W, Tommassen J, Ramos JL;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2003;185:4707-4716.]
children.description: A complex of TolQ, TolR, and TolA in the inner membrane, interacting through TolA with a complex of TolB and Pal (also called OprL) present at the outer membrane, is pivotal to maintaining morphology and outer membrane integrity in many Gram-negative bacteria. The tol operon(s) routinely also contain ybgC (orf1) and ybgF (orf2) genes, although these are not clearly associated with mutant phenotypes. The TolA protein, homologous to TonB from a similar complex, is the most divergent, as it consists largely of very low complexity sequence. TolB contains a variable number of beta-propellar repeats.

children.name: TonB-dependent transport
children.description: The components of a TonB-dependent transport system include ExbB, ExbD, and TonB, respectively homologous to TolQ, TolR, and TolA of related tol-pal system. But while the tol-pal system includes seven genes altogether, including the peptidoglycan associated lipoprotein Pal, and seems required for maintaining integrity of the outer membrane, TonB systems tend to be required for siderophore or B12 uptake when mutant phenotypes are observed. At least two different exbB/exbD gene pair families exist, and two different pairs of HMMs currently model two different classes. The capacity for TonB-dependent transport is also marked by the presence of TonB-dependent transporters, which share a region of homology and may number more than 50 in a single genome.

children.description: Ectoine, and its derivative hydroxyectoine, are nitrogen-containing compatible solutes that protect enzymes from the stress of high osmolarity. Bacteria may synthesize or import it, or both. This transporter was partially characterized in Sinorhizobium, where it is encoded along with genes for ectoine catabolism. All subunits are homologous to various amino acid transporter subunits.

children.name: Fructose utilization as fructose-1,6-bisphosphate
children.description: Fructose may be imported into the cell as a carbon source via the fructose-specific phosphotransferase system (PTS) and converted to the glycolysis pathway intermediate fructose-1,6-bisphosphate by the action of 1-phosphofructokinase.

children.name: PTS transport system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 28168775, Title: Structural characterization of the PTS IIA and IIB proteins associated with pneumococcal fucose utilization., Authors: Higgins MA, Hamilton AM, Boraston AB;, Citation: Proteins. 2017;]
children.description: Phosphotransferase system (PTS) is a phosphorylation cascade that allows various carbohydrates to be transported accross a membrane at the expense of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP). First, a phosphoryl group is donated from PEP to a general (non sugar-specific) enzyme I (phosphotransferase system, enzyme I), and then on to a phosphocarrier protein (HPr). HPr then dontaes the phosphoryl group to the sugar-specific EIIA (enzyme IIA), and then on to EIIB (enzyme IIB), before being transferred to the incoming carbohydrate. The carbohydrate is transported by EIIC (enzyme IIC), and occasionally EIID (enzyme IID), which are sugar-specific transmembrane components [1].

children.name: 2-aminoethylphosphonate (AEP) ABC transporter, type II
children.description: This ABC transporter is found in a number of genomes in operon-like contexts, strongly suggesting a substrate specificity for 2-aminoethylphosphonate (2-AEP, ciliatine). children.name: Urea ABC transporter UrtABCDE
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16930487, Title: Exopolysaccharide-associated protein sorting in environmental organisms: the PEP-CTERM/EpsH system. Application of a novel phylogenetic profiling heuristic., Authors: Haft DH, Paulsen IT, Ward N, Selengut JD;, Citation: BMC Biol. 2006;4:29., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 11929526, Title: An ABC-type, high-affinity urea permease identified in cyanobacteria., Authors: Valladares A, Montesinos ML, Herrero A, Flores E;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2002;43:703-715.]
children.description: This property represents a conserved five-gene operon for an ABC transporter with a substrate-binding protein, two permeases, and two ATP-binding cassette proteins. All five genes from this operon are detected in Burkholderia mallei, at very high confidence levels, by means of the partial phylogenetic profiling algorithm [1] vs. a profile for urease, and the operon occurs next to urease genes in B. mallei and most other species. In Cyanobacteria, high-affinity urea transport is shown to be eliminated by mutations to any of several different proteins in this system [2].

children.description: This Genome Property describes a family of quaternary amine transporters that appears, based on physical characterization in Sinorhizobium meliloti and on bioinformatic methods, to import choline. children.name: Choline sulfate utilization
children.description: This property describes a gene pair for choline sulfate utilization. Choline is a precursor to the osmoprotectant glycine-betaine and to acetylcholine, and can be used as an energy source. One member of the gene pair is a choline-sulfatase, as in Sinorhizobium meliloti and Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1. The other gene is a periplasmic binding protein for the ABC transporters responsible for choline uptake. It appears that several different periplasmic binding proteins interact with the same permease and ATP-binding subunit.

children.name: Heme uptake system, NEAT-domain mediated
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 18676371, Title: Demonstration of the iron-regulated surface determinant (Isd) heme transfer pathway in Staphylococcus aureus., Authors: Muryoi N, Tiedemann MT, Pluym M, Cheung J, Heinrichs DE, Stillman MJ;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2008;283:28125-28136., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 17229211, Title: Haem recognition by a Staphylococcus aureus NEAT domain., Authors: Grigg JC, Vermeiren CL, Heinrichs DE, Murphy ME;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2007;63:139-149., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 18725935, Title: Bacillus anthracis secretes proteins that mediate heme acquisition from hemoglobin., Authors: Maresso AW, Garufi G, Schneewind O;, Citation: PLoS Pathog. 2008;4:e1000132., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 14570922, Title: IsdG and IsdI, heme-degrading enzymes in the cytoplasm of Staphylococcus aureus., Authors: Skaar EP, Gaspar AH, Schneewind O;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2004;279:436-443.]
children.description: This system is found in certain lineages of the Bacillus/Clostridium group, including a number of pathogenic species. In order to obtain iron, this system utilizes a number of NEAT domain containing proteins to scavenge heme from host hemoproteins and convey them across the cell wall to an ABC transporter in the cytoplasmic membrane. Cell wall localization of these components is generally mediated by sortases, SrtB being particularly critical to this system in many organisms. Heme is often oxidized to biliverdin by heme oxygenases in the cytoplasm, releasing iron.Genes of this system are generally given "isd" gene symbols where isd stands for Iron-regulated Surface Determinant proteins.

children.name: Lantibiotic system, gallidermin/epidermin family
children.description: A specialized ABC transporter occurs both in species that make lantibiotics in the gallidermin family and as orphans in species that lack both the lantibiotic precursor molecule and the corresponding synthases. It appears these transporters are responsible for self-protection in species that make lantibiotics, and defense in those that do not.

children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 7934931, Title: The nik operon of Escherichia coli encodes a periplasmic binding-protein-dependent transport system for nickel., Authors: Navarro C, Wu LF, Mandrand-Berthelot MA;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 1993;9:1181-1191., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 23139401, Title: Helicobacter hepaticus NikR controls urease and hydrogenase activities via the NikABDE and HH0418 putative nickel import proteins., Authors: Benoit SL, Seshadri S, Lamichhane-Khadka R, Maier RJ;, Citation: Microbiology. 2013;159:136-146., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 9882686, Title: Isolation and characterization of the nikR gene encoding a nickel-responsive regulator in Escherichia coli., Authors: De Pina K, Desjardin V, Mandrand-Berthelot MA, Giordano G, Wu LF;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 1999;181:670-674.]
children.description: Nickel is an essential trace element, but is also toxic at high levels. This genome property descibes a specifc ABC transporter that is responsible for the uptake of nickel. The transporter is encoded by the nikABCDE operon. This property also includes nikR which has been shown to function as a regulator for this transporter [1,2,3].

children.name: ATP-dependent methionine-importing complex
children.description: An ABC transporter complex that transports extracellular methionine from the periplasm into the cytoplasm in an ATP-dependent manner. ATP hydrolysis at the dimerization interface of the MetN subunit opens up the dimerization interface of MetI and MetN allowing the methionine to travel through the plasma membrane. MetQ (P28635) is thought to be the periplasmic methionine-chaperon protein, although its interaction with methionine or MetI has yet to be demonstrated.

children.description: Belongs to the family of ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter proteins complexes. It is capable of translocating a wide variety of solutes (e.g. glycine betaine) across the plasma membrane. The proVWX operon is activated under osmotic stress conditions.

children.name: Glutathione-regulated potassium-efflux system KefC-KefF complex
children.description: Potassium efflux pore which protects the bacteria from the toxic effects of electrophilic compounds which react with nucleophiles found in the bases of DNA and the side chains of proteins, especially cysteine. Potassium efflux via KefC is accompanied by H+ and Na+ influx and hence causes acidification of the cytoplasm. KefC is activated by glutathione adducts and inactivated by glutathione which bind to the cytosolic regulatory K+ transport and nucleotide binding domain of KefC.

children.name: Cytochrome o ubiquinol oxidase complex
children.description: A protein complex integral to the bacterial electron transport chain. Electrons are donated by the oxidation of ubiquinol to ubiquinone, transferred to a slow-spinning heme b and subsequently accepted by a binuclear centre consisting of a heme o3 and a copper ion. In the process, the ubiquinol oxidase functions as a proton pump creating a transmembrane electrochemical gradient as 4 hydrogen ions are pumped through the membrane into the periplasmic space while 1/2 O2 molecule is oxidized to water. The electron transport happens exclusively in subunit I (cyoB). Ubiquinol oxidase is the final electron acceptor in the bacterial respiratory chain and thought to possess one of the most important functions in the cellular system due to its anti-oxidant properties.

children.name: Cus cation efflux complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 23122209, Title: Evolution and diversity of periplasmic proteins involved in copper homeostasis in gamma proteobacteria., Authors: Hernández-Montes G, Argüello JM, Valderrama B, Citation: BMC Microbiol. 2012;12:249]
children.description: Transmembrane complex that mediates resistance to copper and silver by cation efflux directly from the cell using the proton-motive force. Spans the inner membrane, periplasm, and outer membrane. CusF delivers metal ions to the CusCBA tripartite efflux system in the periplasm, CusB then appears to deliver the bound metal ion from CusBto the three-methionine cluster (Met-573, Met-623 and Met-672) inside the periplasmic cleft of CusA from where it is passed into the central funnel of CusA and eventually the CusC channel for final extrusion. Primarily activated under anaerobic conditions by CusR (P0ACZ8) and CusS (P77485) but also expressed under extreme copper stress, in aerobic growth.

children.name: F-type conjugation system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16138100, Title: Mobile genetic elements: the agents of open source evolution., Authors: Frost LS, Leplae R, Summers AO, Toussaint A;, Citation: Nat Rev Microbiol. 2005;3:722-732., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 12855161, Title: F factor conjugation is a true type IV secretion system., Authors: Lawley TD, Klimke WA, Gubbins MJ, Frost LS;, Citation: FEMS Microbiol Lett. 2003;224:1-15., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 15292150, Title: Tra proteins characteristic of F-like type IV secretion systems constitute an interaction group by yeast two-hybrid analysis., Authors: Harris RL, Silverman PM;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2004;186:5480-5485.]
children.description: F-type plasmid conjugation systems are those distinctive of the F-plasmid first described in E.coli. This system consists of a type-IV pilus specialized for plasmid DNA transduction as well as specialized machinery for mating-type recognition in the recipient cell and a relaxosome and coupling protein system for initiating and providing energy for the transfer. Two genome properties, GenProp0484 and GenProp0485, encapsulate the F-type-specific and generic components repectively. The generic components are found in non-F-type conjugative systems such as the P and I-like systems.

children.name: F and P-type conjugation systems (type IV secretion), common components
children.description: Both the F-type (F factor like) and P-type (Ti plasmid like) conjucation systems use a core set of structures for the elaboration of a conjugative pilus. Components specific to these two systems are found in related Genome Properties.

children.name: Heterocyst-related ABC exporter DevBCA
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11371545, Title: NtcA-dependent expression of the devBCA operon, encoding a heterocyst-specific ATP-binding cassette transporter in Anabaena spp., Authors: Fiedler G, Muro-Pastor AM, Flores E, Maldener I;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2001;183:3795-3799.]
children.description: Most genomes in which the set of three tandemly-encoded genes for the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) exporter complex similar to the DevBCA complex of Anabaena are Cyanobacteria capable of heterocyst formation. Roughly every tenth cell in colonies of certain species of cyanobacteria differentiate into heterocysts under conditions of nitrogen starvation, with a loss of CO2 fixation, reduction of O2 permeability, and development of the ability to fix nitrogen. The DevBCA transporter most likely acts by exporting a glycolipid (or an enzyme) specific to heterocyst formation.

The shorter protein, found almost invariably immediately upstream, is highly hydrophobic but uncharacterized. The pair is found in about one in six completed prokaryotic genomes.

children.name: Anchored repeat-class ABC transporter, P. acnes type
children.description: Model TIGR03769 describes a protein region that occurs several times per genome in several Actinobacteria. Typically, it occurs once in an ABC transporter substrate binding protein and two to three times in a neighboring gene that is anchored to the Gram-positive cell wall by a sortase/LPXTG system. This genome property describes the three genes of the ABC transporter cassette and the neighboring LPXTG-anchored repeat protein. This system is analogous to the NEAT domain system found in some pathogenic Firmicutes.

children.name: Alcohol ABC transporter, PedABC-type

children.description: A conserved four-gene operon, found regularly in genomes with PQQ biosynthesis and with PQQ-dependent enzymes for catabolism of various alcohols, appears to represent an alcohol import ABC transporter. This conclusion is based partly on recognizing one member of the operon as a likely periplasmic substrate-binding protein. An earlier view [1] suggests this system to be an efflux transporter for removal of toxic intermediates during catabolism.

children.name: Energy-coupling factor transporters
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 18931129, Title: A novel class of modular transporters for vitamins in prokaryotes., Authors: Rodionov DA, Hebbeln P, Eudes A, ter Beek J, Rodionova IA, Erkens GB, Slotboom DJ, Gelfand MS, Osterman AL, Hanson AD, Eitinger T;, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2009;191:42-51.]
children.description: This Genome Property consists of a form of ATP-energized transport in which two subunits resemble ABC transporter ATP-binding subunits, but the other two are distinct. The T component marks the transporter class, and generally is encoded adjacent the ATP-binding subunits. The substrate capture component S spans the membrane multiple times, and somewhat more than half the time is encoded away from the other subunits. In these systems, a single T subunit may transfer energy to a number of different S subunits.

children.name: Proposed F420-0 transporter
children.description: This small clade of ABC-type transporters are found in Actinobacteria containing numerous genes requiring the coenzyme F420. This property was defined based on five such organisms, four of which are lacking all F420 biosynthetic capability save the final side-chain polyglutamate attachment step (via the gene cofE). In Jonesia denitrificans DSM 20603 and marine actinobacterium PHSC20C1, this cassette is in an apparent operon with the cofE gene and, in PHSC20C1, also with a F420-dependent glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase. Based on these observations we propose that this is an F420-0 (F420 lacking only the polyglutamate tail) ABC transporter.

children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 27924919, Title: A central cavity within the holo-translocon suggests a mechanism for membrane protein insertion., Authors: Botte M, Zaccai NR, Nijeholt JL, Martin R, Knoops K, Papai G, Zou J, Deniaud A, Karuppasamy M, Jiang Q, Roy AS, Schulten K, Schultz P, Rappsilber J, Zaccai G, Berger I, Collinson I, Schaffitzel C, Citation: Sci Rep. 2016;6:38399]
children.description: Functions in both protein secretion to the trans side of the plasma membrane and insertion of membrane proteins into the lipid bilayer. The HTL complex is more proficient in cotranslational membrane protein insertion compared with SecYEG (CPX-1096) alone, and the post-translational secretion of a beta-barreled outer-membrane protein driven by secA and ATP becomes much more dependent on the proton-motive force than is the case for SecYEG. children.name: MacAB-TolC complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 20307498, Title: The tip region of the MacA alpha-hairpin is important for the binding to TolC to the Escherichia coli MacAB-TolC pump., Authors: Xu Y, Sim SH, Song S, Piao S, Kim HM, Jin XL, Lee K, Ha NC, Citation: Biochem Biophys Res Commun. 2010;394:962-965]
children.description: Tripartite, ATP-dependent efflux pump spanning the entire cell membrane system. Confers resistance to antibiotics and other toxins (specifically macrolide compounds containing 14- and 15-membered lactones) by transporting them out of the bacterial cell. MacB is the dimeric, non-canonical ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter subunit containing 4 transmembrane domains which span the entire inner membrane, an N-terminal nucleotide binding domain, and a central hydrophilic periplasmic domain. It binds to the periplasmic membrane fusion protein MacA. Whether it also binds directly to TolC is unclear (EBI-6305934 shows a very weak reaction). MacA is hexameric and binds directly to MacB and TolC facilitating direct channelling of toxins out of the cell. It consists of an alpha-helical, TolC-binding barrel domain, an intermediate lipyl domain, and a beta-barrel domain which is the likely MacB binding domain. It may also have a plasma membrane binding domain (through its N and C termini), but does not bind directly to the outer membrane. It appears to enhance the ATPase activity of MacB. TolC is trimeric and has two major domains, a transmembrane beta-barrel spanning the entire outer membrane, and an alpha-helical periplasmic barrel domain through which it binds to MacA. MacA and TolC appear to interact allosterically in a tip-to-tip fashion through the 'cogwheel' alpha-hairpin tip regions of both complexes.

children.name: Vitamin B12 outer membrane transporter complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16741124, Title: Outer membrane active transport: structure of the BtuB:TonB complex., Authors: Shultis DD, Purdy MD, Banchs CN, Wiener MC, Citation: Science. 2006;312:1396-1399]
children.description: A member of the TonB-dependent transporter family (TBDTs) which binds and then transports cobalamine (vitamin B12) across the outer membrane. TBDTs are energy-dependent gated channels that usually transport large metal complexes which cannot fit through porins, and are too scarce to enter by mass-action-driven transport. Energy-dependent uptake through TBDTs requires interaction with TonB in complex with ExbB and ExbD in the inner membrane, ExbBD. TonB undergoes rapid energized movement driven by ExbBD which harvests the electrochemical force from the proton gradient across the inner membrane and converts it into rotational motion. Hence, TonB may pull or twist the N-termini of TBDTs to promote transport of substrates into the periplasm. ATP-binding-cassette (ABC) transporters subsequently move the cyanocobalamine through the periplasm and inner membrane.

children.name: IscS-IscU complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 22203963, Title: Disordered form of the scaffold protein IscU is the substrate for iron-sulfur cluster assembly on cysteine desulfurase., Authors: Kim JH, Tonelli M, Markley JL, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2012;109:454-459, Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 20404999, Title: Structural basis for Fe-S cluster assembly and tRNA thiolation mediated by IscS protein-protein interactions., Authors: Shi R, Proteau A, Villarroya M, Moukadiri I, Zhang L, Trempe JF, Matte A, Armengod ME, Cygler M, Citation: PLoS Biol. 2010;8:e1000354, Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 16387657, Title: Mechanistic insights into sulfur relay by multiple sulfur mediators involved in thiouridine biosynthesis at tRNA wobble positions., Authors: Ikeuchi Y, Shigi N, Kato J, Nishimura A, Suzuki T, Citation: Mol Cell. 2006;21:97-108]
children.description: Involved in the sulfur transfer during iron-sulfur cluster assembly and in the modification of tRNA wobble positions. IscS desulfurases L-cysteine and transfers sulfur on IscU while the latter is in the D-state, a partly disordered state that contains an ordered domain that stabilizes two cis peptidyl-prolyl peptide bonds. After Fe-S cluster formation on IscU, IscU converts to the S-state, which has a lower affinity for IscS and minimizes product inhibition.

children.name: PhnGHIJKL complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 21705661, Title: Five phosphonate operon gene products as components of a multi-subunit complex of the carbon-phosphorus lyase pathway., Authors: Jochimsen B, Lolle S, McSorley FR, Nabi M, Stougaard J, Zechel DL, Hove-Jensen B, Citation: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2011;108:11393-11398, Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 22089136, Title: Intermediates in the transformation of phosphonates to phosphate by bacteria., Authors: Kamat SS, Williams HJ, Raushel FM, Citation: Nature. 2011;480:570-573, Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 23830682, Title: The enzymatic conversion of phosphonates to phosphate by bacteria., Authors: Kamat SS, Raushel FM, Citation: Curr Opin Chem Biol. 2013;17:589-596]
children.description: Formed from components of the phn operon in gram-negative bacteria that facilitates the internalization and degradation of organophosphonates. Carbon-phosphorous lyase (CP lyase) and alpha-D-ribose 1-methylphosphonate 5-triphosphate synthase activites have been attributed to at least the PhnG, PhnH, PhnI, PhnJ, PhnK and PhnL components of the Phn operon. It is unclear which of the subunits are absolutely necessary for each activity. PhnG, PhnH, PhnI and PhnL have alpha-D-ribose 1-methylphosphonate 5-triphosphate synthase activity and PhnJ has alpha-D-ribose 1-methylphosphonate 5-phosphate C-P-lyase activity in vitro. However, PhnJ can only be isolated in a complex of at least PhnG, PhnH, PhnI, PhnJ and PhnK but this complex is catalytically inactive, possibly because it lacks PhnL.

children.description: Acts as a L-cysteine desulfurase and sufurtransferase. CsdA desulfurases L-cysteine to produce L-alanine atomic sulfur (in the form of a persulfide). It transfers the sulfur to CsdE which increases the cysteine desulfurase activity of CsdA. CsdE accepts the sulfur on Cys61. While the CsdE dimer can be isolated in vitro it is uncertain whether it also exists on its own in vivo.

children.name: Protein-conducting channel SecYEG complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16292303, Title: Structure of the E. coli protein-conducting channel bound to a translating ribosome., Authors: Mitra K, Schaffitzel C, Shaikh T, Tama F, Jenni S, Brooks CL, Ban N, Frank J, Citation: Nature. 2005;438:318-324]
children.description: Functions in both protein secretion to the trans side of the plasma membrane and insertion of membrane proteins into the lipid bilayer. Associates with the motor ATPase SecA, which drives post-translational translocation of pre-proteins across the membrane.Membrane proteins are targeted to the membrane co-translationally by the signal recognition particle (SRP) associating with its receptor at the cytosolic surface. The ribosome nascent chain complex is then passed onto the dimeric SecYEG complex and the nascent membrane protein is threaded through the protein channel and into the bilayer via a lateral gate. Also forms a holo-translocon super-complex comprising of the SecYEG core complex, the accessory sub-complex SecDF-YajC and YidC.

children.name: MdtBC complex
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 12107133, Title: The putative response regulator BaeR stimulates multidrug resistance of Escherichia coli via a novel multidrug exporter system, MdtABC., Authors: Nagakubo S, Nishino K, Hirata T, Yamaguchi A, Citation: J Bacteriol. 2002;184:4161-4167]
children.description: Involved in the resistance of gram negative bacteria to novobiocin, deoxycholate and beta-lactams. MdtB and MdtC are transmembrane proteins facilitating drug export while MdtA is the (cytoplasmic?) membrane fusion protein associated with MdtBC (no binding data available yet). MdtABC requires TolC (P02930), an outer membrane 'channel-tunnel' trimer, for its function. The composition of the MdtABC holo-transporter may be variably composed of the MdtA, MdtB and MdtC subunits, however, either MdtB or MdtC must the present. The mdtABC operon is transcriptionally activated by BaeR (P69228).
