children.name: CRISPR system, III-A/Mtube subtype
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 11952905, Title: Identification of genes that are associated with DNA repeats in prokaryotes., Authors: Jansen R, Embden JD, Gaastra W, Schouls LM;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2002;43:1565-1575., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 16292354, Title: A guild of 45 CRISPR-associated (Cas) protein families and multiple CRISPR/Cas subtypes exist in prokaryotic genomes., Authors: Haft DH, Selengut J, Mongodin EF, Nelson KE;, Citation: PLoS Comput Biol. 2005;1:e60.]
children.description: CRISPR repeats are by definition Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats, described by Jansen [1]. Certain proteins, including Cas1 to Cas4, are found only in genomes with CRISPR repeats, and are near these repeats. Jansen, et al. describe CRISPR loci as having direct repeats, varying in size from 21 to 37 bp, interspaced by similarly sized non-repetitive sequences. Variants of CRISP/Cas loci (subtypes) have been described [2] in which certain groups of subtype-specific genes are found in addition to characteristic sets of the more widely distributed cas genes. The Mtube subtype, so named because this subtype is the only one found in the genome of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, consists of cas1, cas2, and the subtype specific genes csm1-5. Csm3, 4 and 5 are members of the RAMP superfamily, and this subtype shares some similarities with the CRISPR RAMP module in that it tends to be associated with other subtypes and often forms hybrid-subtype loci.

children.description: CRISPR repeats are by definition Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats, described by Jansen [1]. Certain proteins, including Cas1 to Cas4, are found only in genomes with CRISPR repeats, and are near these repeats. Jansen, et al. describe CRISPR loci as having direct repeats, varying in size from 21 to 37 bp, interspaced by similarly sized non-repetitive sequences. Variants of CRISP/Cas loci (subtypes) have been described [2] in which certain groups of subtype-specific genes are found in addition to characteristic sets of the more widely distributed cas genes. The Apern subtype, so named because this subtype is the only one found in the genome of Archaeoglobus pernix, consists of cas1-6, the subtype specific genes csa1-3 and either csa4 or csa5. The repeats associated with this subtype tend to have a periodicity of 66 nucleotides. This subtype is found exclusively in Archaea, primarily in the Chrenarchaeota.

children.name: CRISPR system, Aferr subtype
children.description: At least ten different systems of proteins associated with CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) have been described, such as the Ecoli, Ypest, Nmeni, and Dvulg subtypes. We designate this type Aferr, after Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans ATCC 23270, where this system is carried on the chromosome rather than on a plasmid, and where it is the only CRISPR subtype in the species. None of the familiar core cas genes, cas1-cas4, are found in A. ferrooxidans, making this type of CRISPR/cas locus unusual.

children.name: CRISPR system, PreFran subtype
children.description: CRISPR repeats are by definition Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats. The repeats vary in size from 24 to 48 bp, interspaced by similarly sized non-repetitive sequences. These spacers often are derived from phage and other exogenous DNA, are transcribed into RNA, and confer resistance to those same phage. Several CRISPR-associated sequences (cas genes) are nearly as widespread as CRISPR itself and nearly always are found near repeat loci. Others represent minor cas genes that serve as markers for specific subtypes of CRISPR/cas system, each with characteristic cas gene makeup, repeat structure, and spacer length. The PreFran subtype is found in multiple reference genomes of Prevotella and Francisella, and found also in several additional species. It has a single long protein, Cpf1 (Cas protein 1 of PreFran subtype), in addition to Cas4, Cas1, and Cas2. The typical repeat has length 36.

children.description: Type I restriction endonucleases are components of prokaryotic DNA restriction-modification mechanisms that protects the organism against invading foreign DNA. Type I enzymes have three different subunits, M (modification), S (specificity), and R (restriction), that form multifunctional enzymes with restriction, methylase, and ATPase activities [1,2].

children.name: DNA sulfur modification system dnd
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 17439960, Title: DNA modification by sulfur: analysis of the sequence recognition specificity surrounding the modification sites., Authors: Liang J, Wang Z, He X, Li J, Zhou X, Deng Z;, Citation: Nucleic Acids Res. 2007;35:2944-2954., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 16102010, Title: A novel DNA modification by sulphur., Authors: Zhou X, He X, Liang J, Li A, Xu T, Kieser T, Helmann JD, Deng Z;, Citation: Mol Microbiol. 2005;57:1428-1438., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 19232083, Title: DNA phosphorothioation in Streptomyces lividans: mutational analysis of the dnd locus., Authors: Xu T, Liang J, Chen S, Wang L, He X, You D, Wang Z, Li A, Xu Z, Zhou X, Deng Z;, Citation: BMC Microbiol. 2009;9:41.]
children.description: Several bacteria have an unusual DNA phenotype, Dnd (degradation during electrophoresis). This property results from a sulfur modification on a G residue, shown in one example to occur at a rate of about one sulfur per 6000 base pairs. Study of Streptomyces lividans 1326 showed a stringent requirement for a core motif GGCC within a longer recognition region represented as cGGCCgccg [1]. Five characteristic genes, including a predicted cysteine sulfurtransferase related to IscS, appear responsible for the dnd phenotype. Through comparative genomic studies, we find that, beyond a core set of three genes dndC, dndD, and dndE, other proteins may be associated. That is, they show up specifically in genomes that carry dndCDE and occur nearby, but do not show up in all such genomes.

children.name: Abortive infection proteins
children.description: An abortive infection system is any system that interferes with the ability of a phage to replicate successfully after it has infected a prokaryotic cell. Mechanisms vary widely, and may include blockage of a specific step in phage replication, or else shutdown and/or death of the host cell. This Genome Property is designed as a guild for proteins that have been described in publications as abortive infection proteins and that do not belong to CRISPR or restriction enzyme systems.

children.name: Complement activation, common pathway 1
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 26489954, Title: Complement activation, regulation, and molecular basis for complement- related diseases., Authors: Bajic G; Degn SE; Thiel S; Andersen GR;, Citation: EMBO J. 2015;34:2735-2757.]
children.description: Complement is a ring-shaped complex that forms pores in bacterial cell membranes, making the cells leak and thus kill invading bacteria and other pathogens. There are three pathways by which complement is activated, known as the classical, alternative and lectin pathways. Activation involves proteolytic cascades which are different for each of the activation pathways.The classical and lectin pathways converge at the activation of the C2/C4 complex, whereas the alternative pathway converges at C5 activation [1].The pathways are found only in chordates.

children.name: Renin-Angiotensin system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 10619573, Title: The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system: a specific target for hypertension management., Authors: Weir MR; Dzau VJ;, Citation: Am J Hypertens 1999;12:205S-213S., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 11707427, Title: Evidence that the angiotensin IV (AT(4)) receptor is the enzyme insulin-regulated aminopeptidase., Authors: Albiston AL; McDowall SG; Matsacos D; Sim P; Clune E; Mustafa T; Lee J;Mendelsohn FA; Simpson RJ; Connolly LM; Chai SY;, Citation: J Biol Chem. 2001;276:48623-48626., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 1653799, Title: Evidence that prolyl endopeptidase participates in the processing of brain angiotensin., Authors: Welches WR; Santos RA; Chappell MC; Brosnihan KB; Greene LJ; Ferrario CM;, Citation: J Hypertens 1991;9:631-638., Ref 4, Pubmed ID: 26102692, Title: The role of neprilysin in angiotensin 1-7 formation in the kidney., Authors: Domenig O; Manzel A; Grobe N; Kaltenecker C; Kovarik J; Stegbauer J; Gurley SB; Antlanger M; Elased K; Saemann M; Linker R; Poglitsch M;, Citation: J Hypertens 2015;33 Suppl 1:e114-e115., Ref 5, Pubmed ID: 15809376, Title: G-protein-coupled receptor Mas is a physiological antagonist of the angiotensin II type 1 receptor., Authors: Kostenis E; Milligan G; Christopoulos A; Sanchez-Ferrer CF; Heringer-Walther S; Sexton PM; Gembardt F; Kellett E; Martini L; Vanderheyden P; Schultheiss HP; Walther T;, Citation: Circulation 2005;111:1806-1813., Ref 6, Pubmed ID: 24760442, Title: New components of the renin-angiotensin system: alamandine and the MAS-related G protein-coupled receptor D., Authors: Etelvino GM; Peluso AA; Santos RA;, Citation: Curr Hypertens Rep 2014;16:433.]
children.description: Blood pressure and hydro-electrolyte balance is regulated by the peptide hormone angiotensin, which is secreted as a precursor, angiotensinogen, by the kidney. The aspastic endopeptidase releases the active decapeptide angiotensin I which is in turn cleaved by the metalloendopeptidase ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) to generate angiotensin II. The binding of angiotensin II to its cell-surface receptor AT1R brings about vasoconstriction, absorption of sodium in the kidney and aldosterone secretion, all of which increase blood pressure and hypertension. Glutamyl aminopeptidase converts angiotensin II to angiotensin III, which leads to aldosterone release from the adrenal glands. Aldosterone is essential for sodium conservation in the kidney, salivary glands, sweat glands and colon [1]. Membrane alanyl aminopeptidase (aminopeptidase N) generates angiotensin IV. Cystinyl aminopeptidase is the angiotensin IV receptor [2]. Neprilysin and prolyl oligopeptidase generate angiotensin 1-7 [3,4]. MAS1 is the angiotensin 1-7 receptor and an antagnoist of AT1R [5]. Alamandine is derived from angiotensin 1-7 by decarboxylation or by cleavage of angiotensin A by ACE2. Alamandine binds to the Mas-related G protein coupled receptor D and induces vasorelaxation [6].

children.description: The binding of insulin to its receptor INSR leads to the phosphorylation and activation of the receptor, which is also a tyrosine kinase [1].INSR then phosphorylates various proteins known as insulin receptor substrates. These then associate with the regulatory subunit of phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) [2].PI3K activates 3-phosphoinositide-dependent protein kinase 1 [3], which in turn activates serine kinase Akt [4].Akt deactivates glycogen synthase kinase 3 [5] which leads to the activation of glycogen synthase and thus glycogen synthesis [6].

children.description: Glucagon is counter-regulatory to insulin and increases the levels of glucose in the blood by promoting its release from stores of glycogen, increasing biosynthesis of glucose and glycogen, and reducing glycolysis. The activation of adenylate cyclase is crucial to all these roles [1,2]. Production of cAMP activates protein kinase A [3], which phosphorylates many cellular proteins including phosphorylase kinase [4]. Glycogenolysis [5] is brought about by phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase. Glucose-1- phosphate is released from glycogen, converted to glucose by glucose-6-phosphatase and transported across the plasma membrane by facilitated glucose transporters [6].

children.description: The binding of insulin to its receptor INSR leads to the phosphorylation and activation of the receptor, which is also a tyrosine kinase [1]. INSR then phosphorylates various proteins known as insulin receptor substrates. These then associate with the regulatory subunit of phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) [2]. PI3K activates 3-phosphoinositide-dependent protein kinase 1 [3], which in turn activates serine kinase Akt [4]. Akt phosphorylates the Rab protein TBC1D4, inhibiting its GTPase activating domain and allowing it to change from its GDP- to its GTP- bound state. Other proteins in the cascade remain in their activated state, stimulating the glucose transporter GLUT4 to be expressed on the plasma membrane, leading to glucose uptake.

children.description: Insulin is secreted by the pancreatic beta cells. Its secretion can be stimulated by the import of glucose via a surface transporter. Metabolism of glucose increases intracellular ATP, inhibiting ATP-sensitive potassium channels, causing an influx of calcium into the cell [1]. Alternatively, there are surface receptors for peptide hormones such as glucagon-like peptide 1. Binding triggers an increase in cAMP, activation of G proteins, leading to insulin secretion via binding of storage vesicles to the membrane [2]. Depolarization of the plasma membrane leads to an influx of calcium, activation of calcium/calmodulin- dependent protein kinase and translocation of insulin- containing vesicles to the cell surface [3].

children.description: Insulin is secreted by the pancreatic beta cells. Its secretion can be stimulated by the import of glucose via a surface transporter, and metabolism of glucose increases intracellular ATP, inhibiting ATP-sensitive potassium channels, causing an influx of calcium into the cell.Alternatively, there are surface receptors for peptide hormones such as glucogon-like peptide 1. Binding triggers adenylyl cyclase activation, an increase in cAMP, activation of cAMP-dependent second messengers such as protein kinase A, and secretion of insulin from vesicles [1-3]. This property describes the steps of the pathway leading to an increase in cAMP.

children.name: Insulin secretion via PKC

children.description: Insulin is secreted by the pancreatic beta cells. Its secretion can be stimulated by the import of glucose via a surface transporter, and metabolism of glucose increases intracellular ATP, inhibiting ATP-sensitive potassium channels, causing an influx of calcium into the cell [1]. Alternatively, there are surface receptors for acetylcholine, CCK and FA. Binding leads to activation of PLC, which generates the second messenger diacylglycerol, and PKC [2], followed by release of insulin from insulin secretory granules.

children.description: Insulin is secreted by the pancreatic beta cells. Its secretion can be stimulated by the import of glucose via a surface transporter, and metabolism of glucose increases intracellular ATP, inhibiting ATP-sensitive potassium channels, causing an influx of calcium into the cell [1].Alternatively, there are surface receptors for acetylcholine, CCK and FA.Binding leads to activation of PLC, which generates the second messenger inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) [2].The binding of IP3 to a receptor of the endoplasmic reticulum surface, leads to calcium release into the cyoplasm and activation of CAMK.This leads to release of insulin from insulin secretory granules.

children.name: TCA cycle
children.description: The TCA cycle (also known as the Krebs cycle, citrate acid cycle, and tricarboxylic acid cycle) is performed in eukaryotic mitochondria and in many prokaryotes. This property refers to the forward direction: from oxaloacetate and acetate to citrate, to isocitrate, to 2-oxoglutarate, to succinate, to fumarate, to malate, to oxaloacetate, with the release of two molecules of CO2. It runs only under aerobic conditions. The state YES means the cycle is complete. A complete TCA cycle may correlate with use of TCA intermediates as biosynthetic precursors and with anaplerotic (TCA cycle intermediate-replenishing) reactions such as the glyoxylate shunt. The state PARTIAL indicates the pathway does not form a full cycle but may contain several consecutive steps. The direction of flux through this arc is not specified when the PARTIAL state is set, and so it may be in the reductive (reverse) direction. The full reverse TCA cycle, an alternative to the Calvin cycle for carbon dioxide fixation, is covered by a separate property.

children.name: 2-oxoglutarate dehydrogenase system
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 16321804, Title: Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: a target and generator of oxidative stress., Authors: Tretter L, Adam-Vizi V;, Citation: Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci. 2005;360:2335-2345.]
children.description: This enzyme system utilizes three components E1 (thiamine pyrophosphate-binding subunit, SucA), E2 (dihydrolipoamide succinyltransferase, SucB) and E3 (dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase, LpdA) for the interconversion of 2-oxoglutarate (alpha-ketoglutarate) and succinyl-CoA. In addition to lipoate and thiamine pyrophosphate, FAD is also involved. In the course of the reaction CO2 is released and one molecule of NAD+ is converted to NADH. This reaction is an essential component of the TCA (Krebs) cycle [1].

children.name: Insulin release from secretory granules
children.references: [Ref 1, Pubmed ID: 9914469, Title: Molecular mechanisms and regulation of insulin exocytosis as a paradigm of endocrine secretion., Authors: Lang J;, Citation: Eur J Biochem 1999;259:3-17., Ref 2, Pubmed ID: 9715374, Title: Protein kinases, protein phosphorylation, and the regulation of insulin secretion from pancreatic beta- cells., Authors: Jones PMl Persaud SJ;, Citation: Endocr Rev 1998;19:429-461., Ref 3, Pubmed ID: 9759724, Title: Crystal structure of a SNARE complex involved in synaptic exocytosis at 2.4 A resolution., Authors: Sutton RB; Fasshauer D; Jahn R; Brunger AT;, Citation: Nature 1998;395:347-353.]
children.description: Insulin is secreted by the pancreatic beta cells. There are numerous stilumi that promote release of the hormone from secretory granules [1,2]. Fusion of the granule and plasma membranes is brought about by the association of VAMP2 with the syntaxin/SNAP25 complex [3].
